government_functions.details:
Kuwait is a hereditary emirate. The chief of state is the Amir, who is chosen from within the ruling family and confirmed by the National Assembly. The Prime Minister is appointed by the Amir, as is the Crown Prince, who also must be approved by the National Assembly. The Crown Prince is also designated as the Heir Apparent and the National Assembly must swear fealty to the Crown Prince. 

Kuwait has a unicameral National Assembly (Majlis al-Umma), which has 50 members and 15 ex-officio seats reserved for cabinet ministers. Per the Constitution, there may be more ministers (and thus ex-officio members) so long as the number of ministers does not exceed one-third of the total assembly. 

The highest courts in Kuwait are the Constitutional Court and the Supreme Court. All judges are appointed by the Amir on the recommendation of the Supreme Judicial Council.

voting_methods.instructions: Electors cast their vote at a specified polling station in the locality of their domicile where they are registered for national elections. Upon arrival at the polling station, the voter should submit a certificate of his/her registration and present his/her nationality certificate which is then stamped with a special seal. The voter must also present a civil identification card that shows the person's address. If the certificate of registration was lost, provided the voter's name is on the voter list, he/she can vote. The head of the polling committee hands each voter a ballot paper and the voters goes to one of the areas designated for voting in secret inside the polling hall. After the voter marks the ballot, he/she returns it to the chairperson who puts it in the ballot box. The polling clerk then enters a mark in the voter list in front of the name of the voter who cast his/her ballot to indicate the voter has voted.  A voter who is unable to independently mark the ballot can state his/her choice orally so that only the members of the polling committee can hear it (or just the chairperson) and the chairperson marks the voter's choice on the ballot paper and puts it in the ballot box.

campaign_finance.details: Political parties are not recognized in Kuwait; therefore, all candidates run as independents. There is no campaign finance legislation.

voting_methods.instructions: Voter can invalidate cancel his/her early vote by casting a ballot on election day. The law provides that pre-election voting can start as soon as possible after the election date has been advertised, but not earlier than eight weeks before election day.

An elector shall vote at the polling station at the location of domicile unless otherwise prescribed. To take a vote, an elector shall receive a ballot by his/her ID card unless otherwise prescribed. After having received the ballot, the electors shall vote by themselves. The electors shall arrive at the polling stations within the specified time limit to vote, and may not enter the polling stations out of time.

election_issues: Economy; inflation; demand for democracy; separation of powers; bribery and corruption; refugee crisis; freedom of expression; oppression of minorities (Kurds and Alevis)
election_commission_historical_context: During the 2018 general elections, the technical aspects of the election administration were carried out in an efficient manner. However, the Supreme Board of Elections did not exercise oversight over the lower election boards and failed to produce manuals or voting education materials. Overall transparency in the election administration was also lacking, including the election board's failure to publish all its decisions as required by law.  Upon governors' requests based on security considerations, the election board relocated and merged a number of polling stations affecting some 120,000 voters in 16 provinces.The election board did not publish the numbers and locations of the polling stations moved, the number of voters affected, or the justification for these decisions. Some of these changes were done after the legal deadline. The measures resulted in some voters having to travel several kilometres to vote, and voters were not informed in a systematic manner of their new places for voting.  Various stakeholers noted that the affected communities opposed these measures and expressed concerns that the measures were aimed at lowering the voter turnout in areas considered to be HDP strongholds. Complaints were lodged against the decisions.

government_functions.details: Turkey is a presidential republic. The President serves as both the chief of state and head of government. The president is directly elected for a 5-year term and is eligible to serve two terms.   Turkey has a unicameral Grand National Assembly (Buyuk Millet Meclisi) which has 600 members. Members are directly elected in multi-seat constituencies to serve 5-year terms.   The highest courts are the Constitutional Court (Anayasa Mahkemesi), Court of Cassation, and the Council of State.

institution.term_details: The president may serve for up to two terms, with the possibility of a third term if an early presidential election is called while the second term is being served.

voting_methods.instructions: Only voters registered on the Overseas Electoral Register can vote overseas. The Overseas Electoral Register includes the records of Turkish citizens residing abroad taken from the address registration system of the General Directorate of Population and Citizenship Affairs by the General Directorate of Electoral Register.  Overseas voting is implemented by several methods: in-person at foreign representations (or other designated locations), at customs gates, and by-mail. Electronic voting for overseas voters can also be implemented by decision of the Supreme Board of Elections, in which case voters are to be provided with passwords and similar safety measures are to be taken to prevent multiple voting. If electronic voting is used, it is to begin 30 days before election day and end 17:00 on election day. The Supreme Board of Elections, based on the opinion of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, determines separately or individually, the voting methods either using electronic or paper ballots, considering the type of elections and conditions of the country. The foreign representations (and other designated places) where voting will take place in-person are determined by the Supreme Board of Elections, based on the opinion Ministry of Foreign Affairs.  Overseas voters may vote in the presidential election and the proportional part of the parliamentary election (not majoritarian elections.) For by-mail overseas voting, specially manufactured ballot papers and coloured voting envelopes are used, which are sent to the addresses of the overseas voters five days before the election.  One small envelope carries the seal of the foreign district election board in which the ballot is included. This envelope is to be put in another medium envelope in which the words "foreign district election board Ankara/Turkiye" is written and this envelope is put in a third larger envelope on which the the voters' foreign address is written. After marking the ballot paper with an 'X' beside the column of the preferred political party or presidential candidate, the voter puts the ballot paper in the small envelope and closes it. This envelope is put in the  medium envelope which is then sealed and the voter sends it in a way to arrive at the foreign district election board at the latest at 17:00 on election day. For in-person voting at polling stations located at  foreign representations (and other designated places), secrecy of the vote must be respected.  The ballots and envelopes for overseas voting in-person are specially  manufactured in special colours. When the voters comes to vote, the president of the ballot box committee checks the voters identification document and whether the voter has already voted, over a computer supported central electoral roll system. If the voter has not yet voted, he/she is given a stamped ballot paper and the 'yes' or 'preference' stamp. After voting, the voter signs on the electoral roll next to his/her name.  The sealed envelopes with the ballots are put in a bag along with the other voting materials, and sent to the overseas district election board for counting. For voting at customs gates, the period of voting begins 45 days before election day and ends 17:00 on election day; voting hours are 8:00 to 17:00. Specially manufactured ballot papers and envelopes in special colours are used for customs gate voting. The designated customs gates are determined by the Supreme Board of Elections. Secrecy of the vote must be guaranteed.  When a voter comes to a customs gate to vote, the president of the ballot box committee checks his/her identity document and that he/she has not already voted, as indicated on the computer supported central electoral roll. The voter is given a stamped ballot paper and a 'yes' or 'preference' stamp, and enters the secret voting area and completes the voting process. The voter then signs the electoral roll.  Ballots are counted at the customs gates.

Voters must vote at the polling station at which they appear on the voter list (absentee voting is not permitted), unless the voter has a decision of the district election board to be presented to the ballot box committee. Poll workers and law enforcement officers are provided documentation from the distriction election board to vote at the polling station to which they are assigned (MPs and candidates can vote at any polling station by presenting their voter document). The names of the above-noted persons are added at the end of the voter list by the ballot box committee. Voters who are pregnant, ill or diabled did not have to wait in line at the polling station.  One by one, the voters registered in the voter list are to prove their identity by official documents shown to the president of the ballot box committee; the list of acceptable identfication documents is  determined by the Supreme Board of Elections prior to the election day. Proxy voting is not permitted. The president finds the name fo the voter in the voter list and gives him/her one ballot paper and envelope, as well as 'yes' or 'preference' stamp, guides him/her to the place for secret voting if there is more than one cabin and tells the voters to go out of the cabin after folding the ballot and inserting it in the envelope. The voter must then go directly to the place for secret voting with the ballot/envelope. Nobody is allowed inside the secret voting area unless the previous voter leaves; voters who remain inside the cabin for more than a reasonable time are to be warned by the president. Voters who do not leave the area despite warning are removed from the cabin. Voters are not allowed inside the secret voting area with phones, cameras, audio or video recorders or any other communication tools. These kind of devices are to be turned off and presented to the president before voting; the devices are returned to voters after voting. The voter casts his/her vote by affixing the stamp inside the circule belonging to the candidate of preference. After folding the ballot paper and placing it in the envelope, the voter leaves the voting cabin and personally inserts the envelope inside the ballot box. The voter returns the stamp back tothe president. Voters with disabilties can be assisted by a relative registered at the polling station or by another voter. The president returns the voter's ID card to the voter and has the voter put his/her signature on the voter list. If the voter cannot sign, the fingerprint of the left thumb is taken or other finger if necessary. After voting, voters must immediately leave the polling station. Voters in line at the time of closing are to be allowed to vote.

campaign_finance.details: Presidential candidates can receive donations from Turkish citizens up to TRY 13,916 for each round and are not entitled to public funding.  Donations by legal entities and from foreign sources, as well as loans, are prohibited. There is no campaign expenditure ceiling. Donations over TRY 2,000 and all expenditures have to be made through a bank account. Candidates must deliver property declarations to the Supreme Board of Elections together with their nomination papers, and within 10 days of the announcement of the final results submit a campaign finance report on incomes and expenditures. Niether the reports nor the property statements are published. The Supreme Board of Elections is mandated by law to audit the reports but in practice it is done by the Court of Accounts.

voting_methods.instructions: Voter shall attend personally the polling station, produce the National Identity Card and, upon receiving ballot paper, the person shall go immediately into one of the compartments at the polling station and, without delay, record the vote in the prescribed manner, fold the ballot paper in such manner as not to reveal the identity of the candidate for whom the vote has been recorded and place the ballot paper in the ballot box

government_functions.details: The president is the head of government, has the executive power, and is also commander in chief of the armed forces. He is indirectly elected by the national assembly for a term of 5 years. The legislative branch has the ability to amend the constitution; to pass, amend, and repeal laws; to debate and approve national plans for economic development, the state budget, credit and financial programs; among other powers. It has 470 members elected by absolute majority vote from slated candidates approved by the government. It has a term of 5 years. The Supreme Court rules on constitutional matters, and reviews final appeals from lower courts, including all criminal, civil, administrative, labor law, and economic cases.

government_functions.details: The President of Poland serves as chief of state while the Prime Minister acts as head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and may serve two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is appointed by the President and confirmed by the Sejm.  Poland has a bicameral Parliament composed of a 100-seat Senate and a 460-seat Sejm. Senators are directly elected by plurality vote in single-seat constituencies and serve 4-year terms. Members of the Sejm are directly elected by party-list proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies and serve 4-year terms. Parties must earn at least 5% of the national vote to gain a seat in the Sejm, and coalitions must earn 8% of the vote with minority parties excepted from this standard.  Poland has two high courts: the Supreme Court and the Constitutional Tribunal. The Supreme Court is composed of 121 judges separated into thematic chambers. Supreme Court judges are nominated by the National Judicial Council and confirmed by the President, and they may serve until age 65. The Constitutional Tribunal is composed of 15 judges appointed by the Sejm to serve a 9-year term.

Kuwait has a unicameral National Assembly (Majlis al-Umma), which has 50 members and 15 ex-officio seats reserved for cabinet ministers. The highest courts in Kuwait are the Constitutional Court and the Supreme Court. All judges are appointed by the Amir on the recommendation of the Supreme Judicial Council.

voting_methods.instructions: Every voter must present, upon casting his/her vote, the electoral ID, and the committee should review it and stamp it with a special stamp, after verifying his/her identity from the reality of the citizenship certificate._____The president of the polling station provides to each voter a ballot paper, and the voter goes to one of the areas designated for vote casting in the polling station. After voting, the ballot paper to be returned to the president who puts it in the ballot box, then the clerk shall indicate in front of the voter’s name that the voter submitted his paper. The voter who is unable to cast his/her vote on the paper himself/herself shall go to one of the areas designated for casting votes in the polling station. The elector may secretly inform the president of the polling station about his vote and the president of the polling station shall cast the requested vote in the ballot paper and put the vote in the ballot box. The voter can only express his/ her vote to the president of the polling station or one of the polling officer

government_functions.details: Executive power is exercised by the supreme authority of the prince, who is the head of state. The government, led by the Minister of State who is assisted by the government council, is directly appointed by the prince and is not accountable to the National Council. A network of advisory bodies mitigates the extensive powers of the prince as compared to the limited powers of the National Council. Legislation can only be initiated by the prince and while the parliament has the responsibility to deliberate and vote on bills, the prince retains a power of veto.  Monaco has a unicameral legislature, the National Council, with 24 seats. All members are directly elected and serve 5-year terms. However, 16 members are elected by plurality vote, and 8 members are elected by proportional representation vote.  Judicial power vests in the Prince who delegates its full exercise to the courts and tribunals. Supreme Court is composed of five full time members and two substitute members.

voting_methods.instructions: In order to cast a ballot, a voter must present a valid identification document and a personal voting card, which is mailed to all registered voters at least two weeks before election day. All voters are required, upon entering the polling room, to establish their identity by presenting their voter card and an identity card or a valid passport. He receives the envelope intended to contain the ballot paper; he is required, to place his ballot paper in the envelope, to go to the part of the voting room arranged to isolate him from view.  On his return, he affirms his vote on the copy of the electoral list and in the margin of his name by his signature. A distinctive sign is affixed to the voter's card by one of the members of the office.

campaign_finance.details:
Firstly all expenditure by a candidate or a list, as well as any income earned, must be recorded in the campaign’s accounts and, secondly, the candidate or list is obliged to appoint a financial agent, who shall be responsible for keeping accounts of income and expenditure. Source: https://en.gouv.mc/Policy-Practice/The-Economy/News/NATIONAL-ELECTIONS-5-FEBRUARY-2023-INFORMATION-FOR-FUTURE-CANDIDATES

The new campaign finance regulations are implemented for the first time in these elections. The law now sets a campaign expenditure limit of EUR 400,000 and requires electoral contestants to submit a campaign finance report to the Audit Committee. However, this report does not include donations received in kind. Source: http://aceproject.org/ero-en/regions/europe/MC/monaco-needs-assessment-mission-report-national/at_download/file

government_functions.details:
The President of Liberia is both the head of state and government. The President is elected  to serve a six-year term and can serve up to two terms.

Liberia has a bicameral legislative system, which consists of the Senate and the House of Representatives. The Senate has 30 members, two from each county, who are elected to serve nine-year terms. The House of Representatives has 73 members, who are elected to serve six-year terms.

The judicial branch is headed by the Supreme Court, which is the highest court in the country. Other courts include circuit courts, magistrate courts, and special courts.

election_commission_historical_context: The appointment for members of the central election commission by the country's president does not effectively ensure the body's independence. In addition, the independence of the lower-level election commissions and their members is not ensured. Overall, the admnistration of elections in Turkmenistan lacks transparency.

government_functions.details: The President of Turkmenistan serves as both the chief of state and head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds. The presidential term is 7 years, and there are no term limits.  The Mejlis is the unicameral legislature of Turkmenistan, and it has 125 seats. All 125 members are elected by absolute majority vote (via up to two rounds of voting) in single-seat constituencies. Members serve 5-year terms.   The Supreme Court is the highest judicial body in Turkmenistan, and it consists of a president and 21 judges split into three chambers. Judges are appointed by the President and serve 5-year terms.

prominent_political_groups.comments: Democratic Party of Turkmenistan [tdp.gov.tm]; Party of Industrialists and Entrepreneurs [tstp.gov.tm]; Agrarian Party of Turkmenistan [tap.gov.tm]

voting_methods.instructions: Voters abroad who are on the voter list of a polling station established at an embassy/consultate can vote there in person.  The law, however, does not determine any procedures for out-of-country voting, and provides that the Central Election Commission is to determine the procedure. The law provides that voting at embassies/consulates may be declared finished at any time if all voters on the voter list have voted.

Early voters vote at the regular polling stations.  At least two members of the polling station commission must be present in order for early voting to take place. The law provides that early voting is to be conducted under the same voting procedures provided in the law for election day voting. The early voted ballots are to be dropped into a ballot box that has been previously sealed.

Each voter must vote in person; no proxy voting is permitted. Upon verification of the voter's identity by presentation of a passport or or other identification document, and based on the voters inclusion on the voter list at the polling station, the ballot paper is issued to the voter by the poll worker. The voter signs the voter list to confirm he/she has received the ballot paper. The voter proceeds alone to the polling booth and marks the ballot paper in the booth. A voter who is unable to independently mark the ballot paper may invite into the booth another person of his/her choice, but excluding members of the election commission, observers, candidate representatives, or members of initiative groups.  The voter puts the surname of the candidate for whom he/she is voting in a designated spot on the ballot paper. The voter then proceeds to drop the completed and folded ballot paper in the ballot box.  A voter may request a new ballot paper in exchange for a spoiled ballot paper. Homebound voting is available for voters who cannot come to the polling station due to ill health or disability.

campaign_finance.details: The law allows political parties to be financed through private and public sources. Parties may be financed by membership fees, donations and economic activities. Donations from state authorities and charitable and religious organizations are forbidden, as are anonymous and foreign donations. The law provides for a maximum annual amount of donations made by individuals to political parties; one person may annually donate up to a tenfold amount of the average monthly salary. State support to political parties includes access to the state media and the provision of state owned premises.  The legislation does not foresee limitations to campaign donations and expenditures, nor any reporting, disclosure, monitoring or oversight mechanisms.The law guarantees equal conditions and public funds to cover campaign costs of candidates and candidates' nominating bodies. Expenses incurred by political parties in connection with their participation in the elections are to be reimbursed.

government_functions.details:
Timor-Leste is a semi-presidential system in which the president and the parliament (which chooses the prime minister) are elected by direct, universal suffrage for five-year terms. The President is the Head of State while the  Prime Minister acts as the Head of government. The prime minister oversees the day-to-day functioning of government and chairs the Council of Ministers. The prime minister is designated by the political party or alliance of political parties with a majority in the national legislature and is formally appointed by the president.

The Legislature is a unicameral Parliament, composed of the National Assembly. Parliamentarians are elected on national party slates with proportional representation. Ministers are also appointed by the president, following the recommendations of the prime minister. 

The judiciary is notionally headed by the Supreme Court: as it has not yet been appointed, the Court of Appeal acts in its place.

election_issues: Corruption; cost of living; fiscal policy; social policy; EU membership; referenda; Soviet memorials
election_commission_historical_context: In the 2023 parliamentary elections, the Central Election Commission (CEC) enjoyed varied levels of confidence among electoral stakehlders, weakened by controversies surrounding some of its decisions. On 20 February, the CEC Deputy Chairperson resigned as a spokesperson in protest of the CEC decision to not include separate reporting lines for the voting results from machine voting and paper ballot. This decision was later overturned by the Sofia Administrtive Court based on an appeal brought by several politcal parties. According to Transparency International Bulgaria, although the members of the CEC are selected on the basis of expert characteristics, the principle of political commitment is the guiding principle in their selection (and in the activities of the CEC) and political biases are manifested in the making of key CEC decisions. In addition, some stakeholders expressed concerns over the limited capacity of the CEC to duly supervise the implementation of all election preparations, while the CEC acknowledged that it does not have the requisite administrative and technical capacities to effectively fullfill some of its legal responsibilities, such as printing of ballots, machine voting, and public procurement.

government_functions.details: The President of Bulgaria serves as the chief of state, while the Prime Minister is the head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority popular vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is indirectly elected by the National Assembly.  Bulgaria has a unicameral National Assembly (Народно събрание / Narodno Sabranie) with 240 seats. Members of the National Assembly are directly elected by proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies and serve 4-year terms. Parties and coalitions must earn at least 4% of the overall vote to receive a seat.   The high courts of Bulgaria consist of the Supreme Court of Cassation (penal, civil, and commercial legal matters), the Supreme Administrative Court (national government matters), and the Constitutional Court. Cassation and administrative judges are elected by the Supreme Judicial Council (SJC) and confirmed by the President. These judges can serve until age 65. The Constitutional Court is independent of the judiciary branch, and its 12 justices are elected by the National Assembly and confirmed by the President and SJC. Constitutional Court justices serve 9-year terms, and one-third of justices are replaced every 3 years.

voting_methods.instructions: The Central Election Commission determines the conditions and procedure for formation of the polling stations abroad, including the conditions, procedure and organization for voting of Bulgarian citizens abroad, not later than 57 days before the election day. Bulgarian citizens who have the right to vote and wish to exercise their right to vote outside the country in the elections for national representatives declare their wish by submitting an application for inclusion in a list for voting outside the country not later than 25 days before the election day by a written application according to a form, signed in person and delivered in person or submitted by post to the diplomatic mission or consular representation in the relevant state, or by electornic application via the website of the Central Election Commission.   Persons who have submitted an application and are included in a list for voting outside the country are automatically deleted from the voter list for these elections at their permanent address in the Republic of Bulgaria, without the need for them to take any action for this. Submitting a written or electronic application for voting outside the country in the elections for national representatives is not mandatory. Citizens who have not submitted an application for voting outside the country by the deadline, may nevertheless vote in a section, in a country and place of their choice. When voting, they submit a declaration that they meet the conditions to vote and that they have not voted and will not vote elsewhere. As inside Bulgaria, polling stations with more than 300 registered voters are to have voting machines available so that voters can choose to vote by machine or paper ballot.

Voters vote in person at their designated polling station. However, polling commission members and security officers are allowed to vote at the polling station of their duty; students are entitled to vote in the  municipality where they study; and persons with disabilitiles may vote in any suitable polling station of their choice without submitting a prior request. Up until 14 days before election day, candidates, higher level election officials, and accredited observers can apply for a certificate to vote at any polling station within the respective constitutency. Up until 14 days before election day, any voter can request inclusion in the voter lists at the place of their current (temporary) registered residence. Secrecy of the vote is guaranteed. On arrival at the polling station, voters show their identity card, or in certain cases, their internal passport. The poll worker checks the voter's particulars against the voter register and enters the identity number and type of document shown into the voter register and admits the voter to voting. Any discrepancy in the name shown in the identification document and the voter register, if the permanent address matches, is recorded in the voter register.  If the voter is not found on the voter register he/she can be added to a supplemental list, with proof of residence in the district, and is allowed to vote upon submitting a declaration (to be attached to the voter register) that he/she has not voted and will not vote elsewhere. In polling stations with at least 300 registered voters, the voters have the option to use either paper ballot voting or direct recording electronic voting machines.  If paper voting, the voter is given a  ballot that is stamped by the poll worker with the commission's seal. The voter proceeds to the voting screen and in private marks the square of the candidate list of his/her choice and if so wishes, also marks the circle of the candidate of his/her choice. The voter folds the ballot to keep the vote secret, leaves the screen and hands the folded ballot to the poll worker who checks whether the number on the ballot matches the number on the book of ballots and if so, restamps the ballot with the seal of the commission and detaches the counterfoil and deposits it in a separate box. The voter then deposits the ballot in the ballot box, signs the voter register, and his/her identification document is given back and he/she leaves the polling site.  If the voter has spoiled the ballot, he/she can return it folded to the poll worker and a replacement ballot will be issued (only once.) In machine voting, the voter is given access to the voting device and votes by means of a magnetic card, with the device displaying a ballot identical to the paper ballot, as well as an option to vote 'against all'. After voting for the candidate list and if he/she chooses, also for a candidate on the list, he/she can change the choice once before confirming to vote. The voter receives a message that the voting is completed and the voted ballot is printed and the voter proceeds to cast the printed ballot in the same way as the paper ballots are cast. The voter then returns the magnetic card, signs the voter register, and is given back his/her identification document and leaves the polling site. The fact that the voter voted by machine is noted in the voter register. If the machine voting becomes inoperable, voting proceeds by paper ballots. Mobile (homebound) voting is available for voters with permanent disabililities, based on an advance request before polling day.  The mobile voting is carried out by not less than four poll workers on election day.

campaign_finance.details: Political parties and coalitions that received, respectively, at least one and four per cent of valid votes nationwide in the previous elections are entitled to annual public funding, which may be used in election campaigns. Parties and coalitions that are not entitled to public funding and have registered candidate lists in all electoral districts and independent candidates receive some monies for covering media advertising costs.  The campaign may be financed by the party's or candidate's own funds and monetary and in-kind donations from private individuals. Donations over one minimum monthly wage must be accompanied by the donor's declaration of the source of donated funds. Donations from non-residents, religious institutions, anonymous and foreign sources, and legal entities are prohibited.  The law does not provide a limit for individual donations. Campaign expenditures are limited to BGN three million for parties and coalitions and BGN 200,000 for independent candidates. During the campaign, contestants are required to report to the National Audit Office all donations wihtin seven days of receipt and information on contracts concluded with media and public relations agencies. Media outlets are required to publish online all contracts with contestants and to submit such information to the National Audit Office within 30 working days after election day. The National Audit Office is mandated with supervising party and campaign financing. Contestants are not required to report expenditures during the campaign but submit a report on campaign income and expenses within 30 working days after the elections, to be published within 15 days and audited by the National Audit Office within six months from the submission. The National Audit Office audits the reported data for prohibited donations or other irregularities but does not have the  mandate to investigate unreported expenses. The law does not address third-party sepnding on behalf of election contestants.

voting_methods.instructions: The Chief Electoral Officer sends eligible postal voters a postal voting package to their address indicated on the electoral roll or to the address the voter indicated in their applicaton for postal voting. The package includes a postal voting paper, an envelope marked "Postal Vote", and an envelope addressed to the Chief Electoral Officer. The outer envelope includes on its face the number of the elector's name on the roll.  Before sending out the postal voting paper, the Chief Electoral Officer must effectively conceal the consecutive number of the voting paper, write his or her initials and the elector's roll number on the counterfoil of the voting paper, place his or her official mark on both the counterfoil and the voting paper, and indicate on a copy of the roll beside the relevant electors' names, the fact that a postal voting paper has been forwarded to the elector, together with the date that it was forwarded.  Upon receipt of the postal voting paper, the elector shall alone and secretly, exercise his or her vote in accordance with the instructions on the voting paper and any additional instructions that the Chief Electoral Officer considers advisable to give to the elector. The elector then encloses the voting paper in the envelope marked "Postal Vote" and then encloses the envelope in the envelope addressed to the Chief Electoral Officer.  Provided the postal vote is received before the close of polls, the Chief Electoral Officer must record on the envelope received, the date of receipt and the name of the person from whom it was received if delivered by hand, draw a line in ink through the number of the elector on a copy of the roll to be called the "Postal Votes Received" and the date of receipt of that postal vote, open the envelope addressed to him or her and take out the envelope marked "Postal Vote" containing the voting paper and place the unopened envelope in the sealed or locked ballot box in his or her office designated for all postal votes. The ballot box shall not be opened until after the close of the poll.  Source: 2004 Electoral Act Articles 65 (1-5), 66 (1-2), 67 (1-2), 68, 69, 70 (1-2)

An elector of any constituency who satisfies a Returning Officer that he or she is unlikely to be in the constituency for which he or she is registered as an elector may vote in advance of polling day, in any polling booth (station) established by the Chief Electoral Office for that purpose. Every applicant must sign and deliver to the Returning Officer a declaration in Form 12. The Returning Officer is to issue the applicant a voting paper and an envelope addressed to the Returning Officer and marked "Vote in advance of poll". Before giving the voting paper to the elector, the Returning Officer must follow the same procedures as for the issuing a voting paper on the ordinary polling day, e.g. concealing the consecutive number of the voting paper, writing his or her initials and the elector's roll number on the counterfoil, place his/her official mark on the counterfoil and voting paper, strike out the elector's name/number on the roll, etc.  The Returning Officer must also enter the date of the advance voting on the counterfoil and at the top right-hand corner of the voting paper, and also beside the name of the applicant on the roll. The applicant then proceeds alone to vote in secret, folds the voting paper, places it in the envelope provided, and delivers the envelope after sealing it to the Returning Officer. The Returning Officer must keep the safe custody of the sealed envelopes with the declarations attached and on polling day is to open all the advance voting envelopes and place the folded voting papers in the ballot box in the respective constituency.   Source: 2004 Electoral Act Articles 62(1-5), 61 (1-2), 64(1-2)

Electors who are ordinarily voting in-person on election day can vote at any place in their constituency that is designated for the taking of the poll. An elector informs the Presiding Officer of his or her name and the constituency in which he or she proposes to vote, and the Presiding Officer, being satisfied that the person is entitled to vote and has not already voted, issues the elector one voting paper.  If so required by any scrutineer, the Presiding Officer may, before issuing any voting paper, put certain questions to the person proposing to vote, for example, whether the person is at least 18 years of age or whether he or she has already voted in the election.  In issuing a voting paper, the Presiding Officer must firmly fix a piece of gummed paper over the consecutive number on the paper in order to conceal it or to otherwise conceal the number, write his or her initials and the elector's roll number on the counter foil of the voting paper, place his or her official mark on both the counterfoil and the voting paper, and draw a line in ink through the number and name of the elector on the roll as evidence that the elector has received a voting paper. The elector is to immediately go into one of the inner compartments of the polling booth/station and while there alone (except for the case of electors in need of assisted voting), secretly vote by marking a cross (or other clear mark) in the square opposite the name of the candidate for whom he or she desires to vote.  If an elector inadvertently spoils a voting paper, he or she can return it to the Presiding Officer who will then supply the elector with a new voting paper. Before leaving the inner comparement, the elector is to fold the voting paper so that the contents cannot be seen and must then deposit it so folded in the ballot box (which is sealed or locked).   At the time of the close of the poll, electors who are present in a polling booth for the purpose of voting can cast their vote. Electors may not remain in the polling booth/station after casting a vote.  Any elector who has registered as an elector of a constitutency but whose name is not found on the roll for that constituency, or has since closing of the rolls become qualified as an elector in a constituency, or is on polling day present in a constituency other than that for which the person is registered as an elector (but has not cast an advance or postal vote) may, upon completing a declaration form, receive an ordinary voting paper and an envelope addressed to the Returning Officer marked "Vote by Declaration". Upon marking the voting paper in secret in an inner compartment, the elector shall place the paper, duly folded, into the envelope, and return the envelope to the Presiding Officer. After the preliminary count of the ordinary votes, the Presiding Officer is to forward the unopened envelopes with declarations to the Returning Officer who shall forward them to the Registrar of the relevant constitutency. The Registrar determines the elector's qualification or non-qualification and returns the envelopes to the Returning Officer who shall allow all qualified voting papers.  Source: 2004 Electoral Act Part 5, Articles 44-59

voting_methods.instructions: Voter can invalidate cancel his/her early vote by casting a ballot on election day. The law provides that pre-election voting can start as soon as possible after the election date has been advertised, but not earlier than eight weeks before election day.

An elector shall vote at the polling station at the location of domicile unless otherwise prescribed. To take a vote, an elector shall receive a ballot by his/her ID card unless otherwise prescribed. After having received the ballot, the electors shall vote by themselves. The electors shall arrive at the polling stations within the specified time limit to vote, and may not enter the polling stations out of time.

government_functions.details: In Mauritania, the President serves as chief of state, while the Prime Minister is head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is appointed by the President and has no term limit.  Mauritania has a unicameral National Assembly (Al Jam'iya Al Wataniya) with 176 seats. 88 members are elected via absolute majority vote (up to two rounds) in a single, nationwide constituency. The remaining 88 members are elected via closed-list proportional representation vote in multi-member constituencies, including 4 overseas constituencies. All members are directly elected and serve 5-year terms. Out of the 88 nationwide constituency seats, 20 seats are reserved for women, and 11 are reserved for youth (aged 25 to 30).   The Mauritanian judiciary is composed of the Supreme Court (21 judges), the Constitutional Council (9 judges), and the High Court of Justice (9 judges). Judges within these institutions are all appointed by either the President, the Prime Minister, or members of the National Assembly.

voting_methods.instructions:
A Postal Voter shall, before marking the Postal Ballot Paper, show the unmarked ballot paper, the IDC, and the Envelope B before a competent witness. He/she shall first fill the IDC in the presence of the competent witness who shall, if satisfied, counter-sign it. The Postal Voter shall mark the Postal Ballot Paper to cast his/her vote. He/she shall, immediately upon marking the Postal Ballot Paper in total secrecy, place the same in Envelope B and ensure that the envelope is properly sealed. The sealed Envelope B together with the IDC shall be placed in Envelope A. The Postal Voter shall then dispatch Envelope A by post without delay, or hand it over to the Returning Officer who must issue a receipt for it. He/she must also use the provided seal or pen on the Ballot Paper to cast his/her vote in the designated Facilitation Booth.

Votes may be casted by post by any of the following: (a) Diplomats and persons working in the Embassies of Bhutan abroad; (b) Any person on special government duty who is for the time being residing outside Bhutan for the performance of the duty; (c) Members of the Armed Forces of Bhutan; (d) Any person on election duty; (e) Civil servants; (f) Students and trainees; (g) The spouse or dependent of a person referred to in sub-section (a) to (e), if the spouse or dependent is ordinarily residing with him/her; and (h) Any other group of voters as specified by the Election Commission in consultation with the Government.

The Polling Officer 1 shall verify the identity of the voter from the Voters’ List using his/her Voter Photo Identity Card (VPIC). A voter whose identity is established shall proceed to Polling Officer 2 who will obtain his/her signature or thumb impression in the Registry of Voters and issue a White Voter’s Slip for male voters and Yellow Voter’s Slip for female voters. The voter will then proceed to Polling Officer 3 and hand over the Voter’s Slip, proceed to the Voting Compartment to vote secretly unless he/she requires assistance as permitted under the Election Act. The casting of the vote by a voter shall be confirmed by a single beep that will be heard after a vote is casted.

campaign_finance.details: Under the Election Act of the Kingdom of Bhutan 2008, the Election Commission shall, from time to time, fix the maximum limits of election expenses that may be incurred or authorized by registered political parties and candidates taking part in elections to Parliament and Local Governments, including the funds received from the Election Commission. Every candidate and registered political party shall also maintain the day-to-day accounts in a prescribed form of all contributions received and all expenses incurred or authorized concerning the election from the date the election is announced by the Election Commission and until the date of declaration of the result of the election.

election_commission_name: National Electoral Commission (CNE) and Technical Secretariat for Election Administration (STAE)

government_functions.details:
Timor-Leste is a semi-presidential system in which the president and the parliament (which chooses the prime minister) are elected by direct, universal suffrage for five-year terms. The President is the Head of State while the  Prime Minister acts as the Head of government. The prime minister oversees the day-to-day functioning of government and chairs the Council of Ministers. The prime minister is designated by the political party or alliance of political parties with a majority in the national legislature and is formally appointed by the president.

The Legislature is a unicameral Parliament, composed of the National Assembly. Parliamentarians are elected on national party slates with proportional representation. Ministers are also appointed by the president, following the recommendations of the prime minister. 

The judiciary is notionally headed by the Supreme Court: as it has not yet been appointed, the Court of Appeal acts in its place.

voting_methods.instructions:
Timorese citizens who reside abroad may exercise their right to vote as long as they are registered in the voter register and display their voter’s card. Out of country voting will be available at Timor-Leste diplomatic missions or consular offices in Lisbon and Porto, Portugal;  Dungannon, Oxford and Peterborough, United Kingdom ; Seoul, South Korea; and Darwin, Sydney and Melbourne, Australia. Voters must be on the voter register compiled for the areas covered by these missions or offices and vote in person on Election Day. However, Timorese voters in Indonesia will not be able to vote.

Presentation of an updated voter’s card shall constitute a necessary condition for the exercise of the right to vote. If a voter does not have his/her voter’s card on election day, he or she may exercise his/her right to vote by presenting his/her Timorese ID card or passport, as long as his/her data appear on the voters list for that geographic unit.

The voter shall indicate his or her choice by placing a mark or by punching in the blank square in the corresponding line for the list for which he or she wishes to vote. The voter then folds the ballot paper with the printed part on the inside, and places it in the ballot box.

campaign_finance.details:
Candidates must provide campaign accounts  covering all transactions between date of publication of election date and two days after election day to CNE within 30 days after election day. CNE has 30 days to verify accounts and then publishes them, along with its opinion on them, in the Jornal da Republica within 45 days of their receipt.

The law also defines legitimate and illegitimate sources of funds, requires separate campaign accounts, describes how income and expenditure is to be categorized, and bans cash contributions of over $100.

institution.name: Thai House of Representatives
institution.term_details: There is no term limit for members of the House of Representatives in general, but there is an 8-year limit for the role of Prime Minister.

voting_methods.instructions: Voters can register to exercise the right to vote in another country. The Commission or the person entrusted by the Commission in that country, however, shall arrange for vote casting.

Voter wanting to vote early must submit to the election committee of the constituency a request for registration within a period of time prescribed by the Commission or the Commission may require registration to be made by an electronic means in accordance with the rules and procedures prescribed by the Commission.

If ordered to perform duties out of the constituency where he is entitled to vote, or a person entitled to vote, staying out of the constituency in respect of which his name is listed in the household register, who intends to exercise his right to vote prior to the election date in the constituency or out of the constituency.

In casting a vote, a cross shall be affixed in the box provided for a candidate’s personal number on  a ballot card and, in the case where a person entitled to vote decides not to vote for any candidate, a cross shall be affixed in to Vote for Anyone”.

campaign_finance.details: The government provides state funding for the development of political parties through the Political Party Development Fund. Thailand has adopted a ‘matching-funds’ regime in which 40 per cent of the subsidies are granted to parties on the basis of their electoral support, another 40 per cent in accordance with their subscription fees and the rest (20 per cent) depending on the number of branches they have. At the same time, it requires all political parties and candidates to report on their campaign finances.

voting_methods.instructions: Paper ballot to be placed in an envelope; transparent ballot box.

Voters marks a cross on their ballot paper in the delimited space provided against the name of such number of candidates as correspond to the number of the person to be elected, and shall then place the ballot paper so marked in the ballot box.  Voters may if they wish mark crosses against a lesser number of candidates than those to be elected.

Voter wishing to vote shall present himself at the polling station where he is assigned; convince the presiding officer that he is the voter he claims to be and that he has not voted at such polling station or elsewhere; receive a ballot paper from polling officer; record his vote by putting a mark against the name of the candidate for whom he wishes to vote and by that mark recording no more than one vote; and put the folded ballot paper into the ballot box.

Those who want to vote shall: - Provide an ID to the identification officer. - Receive a stamped ballot paper from the officer - Cast his/her vote. - Ink the index finger of the right hand and put the ballot paper in the ballot box.  - [ ] The Following documents are considered a valid ID: - Family book, if it has his/her picture. - Passport. - National ID - Official Identification document.

voting_methods.instructions: Early voting or pre-election voting is held at District commissioners' offices, in main offices and branch offices although District commissioners may decide that pre-election voting at the official address of the commission shall take place at a special location outside the main office, and also that voting shall take place at other locations in their administrative areas. Voters who are members of the crew or passengers on board an Icelandic vessel on sailing routes abroad or on remote fishing grounds may cast their votes on board the vessel. Early voters abroad cast their votes in the offices of Icelandic embassies or permanent missions to international organisations, in consular offices or in the offices of honorary consulates, or any locations abroad, as determined in further detail by the Ministry for Foreign Affairs. Voters have to prove his identity, receive the prescribed electoral materials and vote using it by stamping or writing the letter of the alphabet of the list he or she wishes to vote for on the ballot paper. The voter has the right to indicate a preference regarding the order of the candidates on the list. Vote must be without assistance or without anyone seeing his vote; thereafter, he/she writes the address on the covering letter and signs it in the presence of the election official, who witnesses the casting of the vote. Voters who are unable to attend polling sessions on election day can cast their vote early (Article 56 of Act No. 24/2000). It is the voter himself who decides this. Since this is in fact interpreted broadly voters do not need an excuse to vote early. Note that the start of the early voting is eight weeks before election day and will end before the election day.

Voters cast their votes by marking a cross in the check box with a pencil on the ballot paper in front of the letter of the alphabet of the list for which they wish to vote. If a voter wishes to change the ranking of candidates in the list for which he or she votes, he or she may do so by putting the number 1 in front of the name he or she wishes to place at the top, the number 2 in front of the name he or she wishes to have in second place, the number 3 in front of the name he or she wishes to have in third place, etc., as far as he or she wishes to change anything.

voting_methods.instructions: Voting shall be conducted without interruptions from seven to nineteen hundred hours. At the seats of diplomatic missions and consular posts, voting shall be conducted over a period of two days, where it shall end on the same day as the closing of voting in the Republic of Croatia. With Article 39 of the Act on Amendments to the Act on the Elections of Representatives to the Croatian Parliament (Official Gazette 19/15), which entered into force on 25 February 2015, paragraph 2 was amended. Polling stations shall be closed at nineteen hundred hours, but voters found at polling stations at the moment of closing shall be allowed to vote.

voting_methods.instructions: Voters eligible to vote at their place of residence (mobile voting) submit an advance written application to the precinct election commission, not later than 3 days before election day. Each polling station will have up to three mobile ballot boxes. Mobile voting is conducted by at least two members of the precinct election commission (drawn by lots) together with the operator who received the required number of ballot papers, and together with the sealed mobile ballot boxes. Parties, candidates, observers and media can observe the mobile voting process. A special list of mobile voters is posted outside the polling station two days earlier. The home-bound voter must identify him/herself to the poll workers on the basis of biometric and personal data. Upon identification, the ballot is issued to the voter (no check issued) and the poll worker registers the voter in the paper voter list by putting the series and number of the voter's ID and signs it. The voter signs the voter list upon verification of the entries.  The voter marks the ballot in a special place that allows secrecy of the vote, as well as observation by poll workers and observers. A voter who is unable to fill out the ballot on his/her own due to disability or health condition can request assistance of another voter (but not poll worker, partisan representatives or observers.) In the voter list is noted that the voter voted outside the voting premises.

Only citizens on the voter list have a right to vote on election day. Proxy voting is not permitted.  A voter's identity is checked at the polling station based on his/her biometric and personal data using identification equipment at the polling station. Voter consent is not required. The voter's information is shown on a monitor, visible to partisan representatives and observers. After identification, a check is printed out which the voter hands to the poll worker in exchange for a ballot. If the equipment fails to identify the voter, the voter is not allowed to vote. An official act is to be drawn up with a copy to the voter and another copy to be provided to the relevant state bodies after the official announcement of the election results for taking measures. A ballot is issued to the voter upon presentation of an identity document. When a ballot is issued to a voter, the poll worker registers the voter in the paper voter list, by entering the series and number of the voter's ID and signing the voter list. The voter signs the voter list upon checking the accuracy of the entries. The voter marks the ballot in secret in the voting booth or other specially equipped place. The voter marks the ballot in the square or in the position "Against all" in favour of the candidate or party of choice. If a voter spoils the ballot, a new ballot can be issued; next to the voter's name on the voter list, the poll worker notes that a replacement ballot was provided. Upon verbal notification to the polling commission, voters not able to independently vote can request assistance from another voter who is not a poll worker, candidate, partisan representative, or observer. The voter puts the marked ballot in the automated ballot box. If the automated ballot box breaks down on election day, a spare automated box is to be used and an official act drawn up. If the spare automated ballot box is damaged, voting is to be carried out using a stationary ballot box, and an official act drawn up. If the automated ballot box is repaired it cannot, in any case, be used.

Each voter is issued with 5 different ballot papers(for five different contests) and is instructed to: check they have 5 different ballot papers; complete each ballot paper by placing numbers one to five in the boxes, ask for a replacement paper if they make a mistake, in the order of their choice; place the completed ballot papers into the correct ballot boxes after voting.

Code électoral de 2019:   Article 43  Le vote des nomades a lieu sur deux (2) jours. Le premier jour est celui qui précède le jour du scrutin national dans les conditions fixées à l'alinéa 1 du présent article.   Les tchadiens de l'Étranger votent sur deux (2) jours selon les conditions déterminées par la CENI, qui doivent tenir compte du contexte, de l'environnement et des réalités objectives des représentations diplomatiques et consulaires du Tchad.      Les membres des Forces de défense et de sécurité sont consignés dans leurs casernes le jour du scrutin. Ils votent un jour avant les autres citoyens et en dehors des casernes dans des bureaux définis à l'article 38, et supervisés par la CENI.

Code électoral de 2019:   Article 43 : Le scrutin ne dure qu’un seul jour sur l’étendue du territoire national. Il est ouvert à six (06) heures et clos le même jour à dix-sept (17) heures.      Article 48 : L'électeur, après avoir fait constater et confirmer son identité par la présentation de sa carte biométrique, prend le bulletin unique de vote, se rend à l'isoloir, coche le candidat ou la liste de son choix ou appose son empreinte digitale devant le candidat ou la liste de son choix, plie le bulletin, sort de l'isoloir et introduit le bulletin dans l'urne placée devant le Président du bureau de vote.   En cas d’élections couplées, l’électeur fait les mêmes gestes prévus à l’alinéa précédent mais en ramassant à la fois autant de bulletins qu’il y a d’élections.   Article 49 : Le vote de chaque électeur est constaté par l'apposition de sa signature sur la liste d'émargement. S'il ne peut signer, il y appose son empreinte digitale.   Tout électeur doit, après avoir introduit le bulletin dans l'urne, tremper son doigt dans l'encre indélébile avant de quitter le bureau de vote.   Article 50 : Tout électeur, atteint d'infirmité le mettant dans l'incapacité de voter, est autorisé à se faire assister par un électeur de son choix inscrit sur la même liste électorale que lui.   Article 51 : Les membres du bureau de vote régulièrement inscrits sur la liste électorale sont autorisés à voter dans les bureaux où ils siègent sur simple présentation de leur carte d'électeur.

government_functions.details: The President of Argentina serves as both chief of state and head of government. The President is directly elected by qualified plurality vote in up to two rounds. To be elected, a candidate must receive either 45% of the overall vote or 40% of the vote and a 10-point lead over the closest opponent. The President may serve up to two 4-year terms.  Argentina has a bicameral National Congress with a 72-seat Senate and a 257-seat Chamber of Deputies. In the Senate, all 72 members are directly elected from multi-seat constituencies. Each constituency (province) awards 2 seats to the party highest-polling party and 1 seat to the second-place party. All members serve 6-year terms, and one-third of seats are up for election every 2 years. In the Chamber of Deputies, all 257 members are directly elected by party-list proportional representation vote from multi-seat constituencies. Members serve 4-year terms, and half the seats are up for election every 2 years.   The Supreme Court is the highest court in the Argentinian judiciary. It is composed of four judges who are nominated by the President and approved by a two-thirds vote of the Senate. Judges may serve until age 75.

voting_methods.instructions: Art. 195.- A las siete horas, la Presidencia de la Junta Receptora de Votos, deberá llamar a sus miembros y vigilantes para que emitan su voto, y retendrá su respectivo Documento Único de Identidad, el cual les devolverá al cierre de la votación; posteriormente anunciará en voz alta que dará comienzo la votación, permitiéndose el acceso de los ciudadanos, de uno en uno, y guardando la debida compostura, al lugar destinado al efecto.Las jefaturas de Centro de Votación y supervisores o supervisoras de los partidos políticos o coaliciones a que se refiere el artículo 125 de este Código, votarán en la misma forma indicada en el inciso anterior, pero lo harán en la primera Junta Receptora de Votos del Centro de Votación donde estuvieren acreditados cuando el Centro de Votación tenga menos de veinte Juntas Receptoras de Votos.Cuando tenga más de veinte Juntas Receptoras de Votos, los supervisores o supervisoras votarán en la segunda Junta Receptora de Votos; en todo caso, también se les retendrá su Documento Único de Identidad, devolviéndoseles al cierre de la votación.El delegado o delegada del Fiscal electoral acreditado ante la Junta Electoral Municipal respectiva, los ciudadanos miembros de la Policía Nacional Civil, los alumnos de la Academia Nacional de Seguridad Pública y miembros de la Fuerza Armada, podrán ejercer su derecho al sufragio en los Centros de Votación donde se encuentren destacados, y lo harán en la última Junta Receptora de Votos mostrando su carné policial, de la Academia Nacional de Seguridad Pública o de la Fuerza Armada, y además, su respectivo Documento Único de Identidad vigente, siendo este último retenido hasta el cierre de la votación. En el padrón de votantes de la última Junta Receptora de Votos de cada Centro de Votación, se consignará el nombre y número de Documento Único de Identidad del delegado o delegada Fiscal, de los ciudadanos miembros de la Policía Nacional Civil, de la Academia Nacional de Seguridad Pública y de la Fuerza Armada que voten de la manera que este artículo establece.Los ciudadanos a que se refieren los incisos anteriores podrán votar en elecciones Presidenciales y de Diputaciones al Parlamento Centroamericano, independientemente del domicilio que aparezca en su Documento Único de Identidad; para elecciones Legislativas si su domicilio corresponde a la circunscripción Departamental y, para      CÓDIGO ELECTORAL183Concejos Municipales si su domicilio corresponde a la circunscripción Municipal en que desempeña sus funciones, todo lo anterior de conformidad a los principios Constitucionales de soberanía popular, democracia y representación política.Quienes hagan uso de la prerrogativa establecida en el presente artículo, solo podrán votar en la forma indicada, cuando lo hagan inmediatamente después de instalada la Junta Receptora de Votos y antes de que comience la votación de ciudadanos; una vez iniciada esta, deberán votar en la urna que les corresponda de acuerdo a los padrones electorales (10) Procedimiento de la votación Art. 196.- La Junta Receptora de Votos deberá exigir a todo ciudadano y ciudadana que se presente a votar, se identifique ante dicha Junta y ante los representantes de los partidos políticos o coaliciones contendientes que lo exijan, mediante su respectivo Documento Único de Identidad vigente. El Presidente o Presidenta de la Junta deberá constatar que el ciudadano o ciudadana aparezca en el padrón electoral de búsqueda y que no posea marcas que evidencien que haya votado; verificado esto, se sellará el nombre del votante en dicho padrón, sin que tal sello abarque otro u otros números y nombres. Cumplidos los anteriores requisitos, el secretario o secretaria deberá firmar y sellar la papeleta de votación. Efectuado esto, mostrará el reverso a los demás miembros de la Junta, a los vigilantes de los partidos políticos o coaliciones y al ciudadano o ciudadana a quien le será entregada, con el fin de verificar que ha sido debidamente firmada y sellada; luego procederá a retirar la esquina desprendible y entregar la papeleta al ciudadano o ciudadana, de todo lo cual deberán cerciorarse los demás miembros y vigilantes que asistan. Mientras no se cumplan con las formalidades establecidas en este inciso, no será procedente el ejercicio del voto. La Junta velará que el ciudadano y ciudadana emita el voto de forma secreta en el lugar designado para tal efecto.

government_functions.details: The President of Togo serves as chief of state while the Prime Minister acts as head of government. The President is directly elected by plurality vote and may serve an unlimited number of 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is appointed by the President.  Togo has a unicameral National Assembly with 91 seats. All members are directly elected via list proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies and serve 5-year terms.  Togo has three high courts with distinct purposes. The Supreme Court is composed of a civil/penal chamber and an administrative chamber. The Constitutional Court is composed of 9 judges. Constitutional Court judges may serve up to two 6-year terms and are appointed by the President (2 judges), the National Assembly (2), the Senate (2), and several national legal organizations or communities (3). The High Court of Justice handles treason and other criminal cases against current and former presidents. It is composed of the president and chamber presidents of the Supreme Court and 4 additional judges selected by the National Assembly.

voting_methods.instructions: The voting process is as follows: Upon entering the polling station, the voter hands over his/her National ID to the polling station officer; - the officer announces aloud the full name and the voter's ordinal number; - The president of the polling station orders to verify the presence and identity of the voter on the voter list; - The voter takes one ballot paper himself from a table prepared for this purpose, The President shall make sure that this requirement is respected. The voter enters the voting both with his ballot paper in hand and places a mark, according to his choice, in the place designated for the list or for the candidate at the district level, and his vote mark in the place designated for the list or for the candidate At the national constituency level, then fold the voting paper before leaving the both. - The voter personally deposits his folded ballot paper into the ballot box; - The president places on the voter's hand a sign with an ink that cannot be quickly erased. The polling officer shall cross the name of the voter from the Voters' List before returning the National ID to the Voter. - The voter shall leave the Polling station at once.

voting_methods.instructions: Voting is personal and confidential. When entering the hall, the voter proves his identity to the members of the voting office. The voter takes an envelope and a copy of the ballot paper or ballot papers and goes directly to the polling station where he puts his paper in the envelope without leaving the hall. After that, the head of the voting office certifies that he carries only one envelope, and then the president authorizes him to insert the envelope into the box. Each voter with a disability that prevents him from inserting his paper in the envelope and putting it in the box is authorized to seek the assistance of a person of his choice. The voter's vote shall be proven by placing the thumbprint of the left index finger, in indelible ink, on the signature list, opposite their name and surname, in front of the members of the voting office. The voter's card shall be stamped with a wet seal bearing the phrase “Vote (T)” and the date of the election is affixed to it.        Note: When it is impossible to present a voter card, any voter can exercise his right to vote if he is registered on the list.  He must present his national identification card or any other official document proving his identity

voting_methods.instructions: Art. 116 Para el acto de votación se procederá así:   1)Cada elector acudirá personalmente ante la Junta Receptora de Votos presentando su Cédula de Identidad Ciudadana o su Documento Supletorio de Votación;   2)La Junta Receptora de Votos verificará la validez de la Cédula de Identidad o del Documento Supletorio de votación y si esta corresponde a su portador, se comprobará si el elector se encuentra registrado en la lista del Padrón Electoral para entregarle las boletas electorales correspondientes;   3)El Presidente de la Junta Receptora de Votos le explicará al elector la forma de emitir el voto;   4)El votante marcará en cada boleta electoral con una “X” o cualquier otro signo en el circulo de su preferencia y la introducirá debidamente doblada en la urna electoral correspondiente;   5)Si la “X” o cualquier otro signo hubiese sido marcada en la boleta fuera del circulo, pero se pueda entender la intención del votante, el voto se consignará válido; y   6)Previo al ejercicio del derecho al voto, en el caso que el elector portare el Documento Supletorio de Votación, este quedará retenido en la Junta Receptora de Votos, salvo en la elección presidencial en cuyo caso será devuelto debidamente marcado a fin de ejercer el derecho al voto en la segunda convocatoria si la hubiere.   Art.117 Los miembros de las Juntas Receptoras de Votos, los fiscales acreditados ante ellas y su personal auxiliar, ubicados en las Juntas Receptoras de Votos diferentes de aquellas en la cual se encuentran registrados, podrán votar en ellas previa presentación de su Cédula de Identidad Ciudadana o Documento Supletorio de Votación y credencial. Esto se hará constar en acta.

voting_methods.instructions: Artículo 169. Desarrollo de la votación. A las siete horas (7:00 a.m.), el o la Presidente (a) de la Mesa Electoral Receptora, anunciará “empieza la votación”. Seguidamente, se procederá de acuerdo a la secuencia siguiente:1) El o la Presidente(a) requerirá a cada elector la presentación de su Tarjeta de Identidad;2) El o la Presidente (a) mostrará dicha tarjeta a los demás miembros de la mesa para su cotejo con la fotografía que aparece en el cuaderno electoral y la verificación de autenticidad. Seguidamente, la entregará a1 Secretario(a);3) El o la Secretario(a) comprobará que el ciudadano aparece inscrito en el padrón electoral de dicha mesa;4) Una vez comprobado por el Secretario(a) que aparece inscrito en el padrón electoral, los demás miembros de la Mesa Electoral Receptora observarán la mano del elector para comprobar que en sus dedos no existen manchas de tinta indeleble que indique que pudo haber votado en otra Mesa; si las hubiere el Secretario(a) de la Mesa Electoral Receptora retendrá su Tarjeta de Identidad y le ordenará salir del local registrándolo en la hoja de incidencias;5) Si el elector no tuviere impedimento, el o la Presidente(a) firmará junto con el o la Secretario(a) de la Mesa Electoral Receptora en el reverso de las papeletas y las entregará al elector; 6) El o la Secretario(a) retendrá la Tarjeta de Identidad y cualquier aparato digital fotográfico por el tiempo que utilice el elector para votar;7) Seguidamente el elector pasará al lugar privado para marcar las papeletas;8) Enseguida el elector, las doblará de manera que quede oculto el contenido y así las mostrará a los miembros de la Mesa para que éstos verifiquen que contienen las firmas del Presidente(a) y Secretario(a); de tenerlas, se estampará el sello de “ratificado”;9) Efectuado esto el elector depositará cada papeleta en la urna respectiva;10) Seguidamente, uno de los miembros de las Mesa Electoral Receptora examinará el dedo meñique de la mano derecha del votante, o el que corresponda, para ver si tiene residuos grasos o impermeables, procurando eliminarlos si los tuviere y le pondrá tinta indeleble en el mismo;11) El o la Secretario(a) de la mesa hará la anotación respectiva de que el elector votó, consignándolo en el correspondiente Padrón Electoral; y12) Finalmente el Secretario(a) hará entrega al elector de su Tarjeta de Identidad y aparato digital en su caso que le haya retenido quien se retirará de inmediato del local  Artículo 172. Cierre de la Votación. La votación se desarrollará sin interrupción hasta las dieciséis horas (4:00 p.m.);

voting_methods.instructions: Opens at 12.00am on Monday and ends at 4pm on Thursday  Can apply for early vote between October 10 2020 (after the closing of the rolls) and 5pm on 26 March 2021 [s61(2) Electoral Act 2019].  Eligibility for applying for early vote is set out in s61 of Electoral Act 2019         (1)  A person qualifies to pre-poll if the person:         (a)  travels outside Samoa during the    designated period under section 60(2);         (b)  is 65 years old or above;         (c)  is a person living with disabilities;         (d)  is nominated (in a method approved by    the Commissioner) by a person qualified under paragraphs (b) or (c) to be his or her carer;         (e)  is confirmed (in a method approved by the Commissioner) to be employed in an Office providing a service listed under section 5 of the Public Holidays Act 2008;

Polls open at 8am and close at 3pm [s66 of Electoral Act 2019]  Method of voting set out in s71 of Electoral Act 2019         (1)  The voter, having received a ballot paper, must immediately go into one of the inner compartments provided for marking his or her vote, and must there alone and secretly indicate on the ballot paper the candidate he or she desires to vote for by marking a tick (√) in a square set opposite to the name that candidate.      (2)  A ballot paper is not void on the ground that the marking in the square set opposite the name of the candidate is not marked as a tick but is marked in a manner that clearly indicates the candidate that the voter voted for.      (3)  A voter must before leaving the inner compartment, fold the ballot paper so that the contents cannot be seen, and must deposit the ballot paper so folded, in the ballot box made available.

voting_methods.instructions: Special Electors, including police officer, or election officers, or persons who are in hospital (among others) can apply as special electoral within a specific deadline. They will cast their ballot ealry in special polling stations.  Sections 59- 70 Election Rules, ROP Act.  See Sections 62-75 Election Rules, ROP Act for the full categories of special voters.     See notification of the Elections and Boundaries Commission: https://www.ebctt.com/wp-content/uploads/Application-to-vote-as-a-Special-Elector.pdf;

Manual - Casting of paper ballot in ballot box. The method of voting in the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago is manual voting as there is no provision in the legislation, the Representation of the People Act, Chapter 2:01 for any other method (of voting).
