voting_methods.instructions: The deadline for submitting an application for a postal vote is currently 5pm on 20 April 2021.  But note that the Electoral Commission advises that because of legislative changes the deadline will move to 6 April.  The Commission advises that this will be confirmed at the end of January 2021. Rule 7, schedule 4 of the Scottish Parliament (Elections etc) Order 2010 provides that postal votes must not be issued before 5pm on the 11th day before the poll.  From Electoral Commission website: http://www.electoralcommission.org.uk/postalvote  You need to download, print and fill in the postal vote application form.     Once you have completed the form and made sure you have signed it, you need to send it to the Electoral Registration Office for your area.    After the deadline to become a candidate has passed (approximately three weeks before polling day), ballot papers are produced and printed. Yours will then be sent to you, in your postal voting pack.     Complete the ballot paper in line with the instructions. Make sure you do it alone and in secret.   Once you've completed your ballot paper, put it in the smaller envelope and seal it up. Next, complete and sign the postal voting statement, and put everything inside the big envelope and seal it all up.  When you're ready to return your postal vote, take it to the postbox yourself.  If you can't post it yourself, you can either ask someone you know and trust to post it for you, or you can contact your local authority to ask if they can collect it from you.  Avoid asking a candidate or party worker to post it for you.  Your postal vote needs to be with your local authority by 10pm on polling day to be counted.  If you can't post your postal vote pack in time, you can take it your polling station or to your local authority on polling day.

Voters are given two ballot papers.  The voting procedure and form of the ballot papers are provided for in the Scottish Parliament (Elections etc) Order 2010.  The form of the ballot paper for constituency candidates is prescribed by rule 27, schedule 2 and Form J and contains the instruction: Vote once only in the box opposite the candidate of your choice using an X.    The form of the ballot paper for regional candidates is prescribed by rule 28, schedule 2 and Form K and contains the instruction: Vote once only in the box opposite the party or candidate of your choice using an X.    The voting procedure is set out in rule 46, schedule 2.

voting_methods.instructions: Out-of-country voters without residence in Hungary can apply with the national election authority to be able to vote by-mail.  The application must be submitted no later than 25 days before the election day, and must include the necessary identification information and the voter's postal address to send the voting package or an indication of which embassy/consultate or election office they will pick up the package. The postal voting package is sent to the voter at the indicated address or delivered to the respective embassy/consulate/office. The postal voting package contains a postal ballot paper, a voter identification declaration form, the ballot envelope, a prepaid and pre-addressed reply envelope for mailing, and information on the voting method.  After filling in the postal ballot paper(s), the voter places the ballot(s) in the inner envelope and seals it, completes and signs the voter identification declaration, and inserts the sealed ballot envelope and the declaration form in the outer envelope or in any other envelope. The by-mail ballot can be returned by post to the national election office or embassy/consulate or delivered in-person (or by proxy) to the embassy/consultate or a constitutency election commission.

Voters generally vote at the polling stations at which they are registered to vote, that is in the place of their domocile. Absentee voting is allowed, whereby a voter can vote in a polling station in their area of temporary residence (including outside their election constituency, where they can vote for a candidate from their place of domocile), usually in a dedicated absentee polling station, based on an application submitted to the election authorites at least nine days prior to election day. Also, voters with disability can request to be transferred to an accessible polling station in their same settlement and constituency, if their regular polling station is not accessible. At a polling station, voters show an official identification card, which allows them to vote for a party list (or minority list) and show documentary proof of their address or their personal identification number, which allows them to vote for a constituency candidate.  Upon producing their identification documents and determination that the voter is on the voter list at that polling station and has not voted, the voter receives a ballot paper(s) (normally two ballots - a party/minority list ballot and a constituency ballot), to be stamped in front of the voter, and a ballot envelope, and the voter must sign the voter register (or if unable, two polling officials can sign). Voters registered as a minority voter can vote for a minority list (not a party list), and for constituency candidate. Absentee voters, even if voting outside their constituency, will be provided a ballot from the constituency of their domicile. When necessary, the polling official explains the voting process to the voter. The polling commission must advise voters to use the polling booth but cannot oblige them to do so. The voter then proceeds (to the polling booth) to mark their ballot(s).  Votes can only be cast by drawing two intersecting lines in the circle beside the name of the candidate, or above the name of the list, using a pen. The voter inserts the marked ballot(s) into the ballot envelope and inserts the envelope into the sealed ballot box. If the voter spoils the ballot paper, he or she can receive a new ballot from a polling official provided the spoiled ballot is returned before inserting it in the ballot box. Only one replacement per type of ballot can be provided. Voters with disability or who are illiterate can request a person of their choice (or two polling commission members) to assist them to fill in the ballot paper. Mobile voting can be requested by persons with limited mobility due to the health condition or disability or who are in detention, which is carried out by two members of the polling station commission. The same voting procedures apply for mobile voing; except instead of a polling booth, the voter must be provided circumstances to vote in secret.

voting_methods.instructions: Lebanese Electoral Law 44/2017 Article 88: Early voting The Ministry shall organize early voting for polling officers in all constituencies, on the Thursday preceding Election Day. Once the number of ballots contained in every ballot box has been counted, all ballot boxes used in the polling officers’ polling stations shall be sealed and immediately sent- while sealedwith security forces escort, to the Banque du Liban or any of its branches. At the end of the voting process on Sunday, these ballot boxes shall be sent to the competent registration committee who shall sort them and combine their results with those of the other ballot boxes. This process shall be subject to the regulations provided for in Chapter Eleven of the present Law.

The voting process 1.When the voter enters the polling station, the head officer shall verify their identity by checking their identity card or valid ordinary Lebanese passport. If a material difference is noticed between the identity card or passport data and the checklist data, the identity card number of passport number shall be the basis for verification. 2.After the polling station officers have verified that the name of the voter is included in the polling station checklist, the head officer shall hand to the voter a ballot paper signed on its back side by the head officer and clerk, and an envelope officially signed and stamped by the head officer, and request the voter to mandatorily go behind the booth and freely exercise their right to vote, under penalty of being prevented from voting. 3.The voter shall mark the list or candidate name of his choice in accordance with Article 98 of the present law. The voter shall return toward the polling station officers and show the head officer that they hold one sealed and folded ballot paper only. The head officer of the polling station shall verify that without touching the paper before allowing the voter to personally cast the ballot in the ballot box. 4.The head officer of the polling station shall make sure that the voters use the voting booth under penalty of preventing them from voting. The voters may not disclose their ballot after exiting the voting booth. 5.A voter’s vote is validated by the voter’s signature on the checklist and by having their thumb marked with a 24-hour indelible ink supplied by the Ministry to all polling stations. Voters who already have their thumb marked shall thus be prevented from voting again. 6.The head officer of the polling station shall be responsible for preventing any voter from casting their vote should they act in breach of the provisions of paragraph (4) of this Article. 7.The voter may not delegate any other person to vote on their behalf.

voting_methods.instructions: Citizens seeking to (advance) vote abroad must submit an application for enrolment as an overseas (or special) voter in person at any embassy, high commission or foreign mission or apply in writing to the Parliamentary Commissioner. Applications can be submitted in person, by fax, or electronically, to reach the Parliamentary Commission within 7 days of the issue of the writ of election. A person who meets the criteria and is enrolled as an overseas voter cannot vote in the the Bahamas on polling day. Overseas voting is held in-person at certain designated polling locations (High Commissions, Consulates, and other foreign missions of the Bahamas) on the appointed advance polling date. Persons who wish to vote in the Bahamas as a special voter on the advance polling day must apply in writing to the Parliamentary Commissioner for a special voter certificate within 14 days of the issue of the writ of election.  The Parliamentary Commissioner designates the places for advance polling for special voters in the Bahamas, paying due regard to the facilities of such institutions as he or she may designate. Institutions that house certain categories of special voters, such as hospitals and nursing homes, can apply to be designated as an advance polling place for special voters.  Advance polling for eligible members of the police and defence forces is to be held at places designated by the Parliamentary Commission.  Not less than 14 days prior to the designated advance polling day, the police commissioner and defence force commodore must submit to the Parliamentary Commissioner a list of the members of the police and defence forces, respectively, which lists shall be made available for inspection by the Parliamentary Commissioner not later than 7 days before the advance polling day.  The election law provides that advance polling for all of the categories of advance voters is to be conducted in the same manner as the polling on the regular polling day in accordance with the law. At any advanced poll, a separate ballot box is provided, and at the close of such advanced poll the ballot papers in each box shall, without examination, be placed in separate packets and sealed by the presiding officer, each packet designating the number of ballot papers it contains and the relevant constituency. The sealed packets are to be immediately returned to the Parliamentary Commissioner (from both inside and outside the Bahamas) to be kept in his or her office or other safe place until delivery on the day appointed for the regular polling day to one of the presiding officers for the same constitutency to which such packet relates. Immediately before the commencement of the regular polling day, the presiding officer is to open such advance polling packets and without examining the ballot papers shall place them in the ballot box at his or her poll before he or she locks the box up and places the seal on it.

A voter must vote in person at the polling division to which he or she is designated in the voter register (except for those persons scheduled to vote in the advance polls.) The voter is to show his or her voter's card or other sufficient means of identification. Then, if the presiding officer is satisfied that the person has not already voted and that his or her name is on the voter register for that polling division, the voter is allowed to vote.  If a voter uses an identification other than a voter's card, the presiding officer must record the voter's name and type of ID on a list. If the presiding officer is not satified with the identification of the voter or his or her right to vote because of a defective voter's card, incorrect entry in the voter register, or missing entry on the voter register for the relevant constituency or polling division, the voter is allowed to cast a "protest vote" using a coloured ballot paper (regular ballot papers are white).  The presiding officer gives a voter one ballot paper after the officer signs his or her own name on the back of the ballot paper, calls out the number, full name and description of the peron as stated in the register and marks the said number on the counterfoil, puts a mark against the name of that person in the register to indicate that the person has voted in that polling division,  marks the thumb of the person by dipping the thumb of his or her right hand in indelible ink or by such other officially designated mark (or otherwise left thumb, other finger, or other way to indicate the person has been issued a ballot paper), and stamps that person's voter card to indicate that the person voted in that election in that polling division. After inspecting the person's thumb or fingers with the proper equipment, the presiding officer should refuse to give a ballot paper unless satisifed that there does not appear any such mark of indelible ink. If the proper equipment is not working properly or not available, each voter must take an oath that he or she has not previously voted in that election.  A refusal to give a voter a ballot paper must be recorded with a reason by the presiding officer. Before issuing a ballot paper, the presiding officer may, and, if required so to do by a candidate or election agent, must, require any person to to take and subscribe to an oath  to confirm his or her identify and residence qualification, and that he or she has not already voted in that election. If the voter refuses to do so, the ballot cannot be issued.  Before giving the voter the ballot paper, the presiding officer must immerse the voter's thumb (finger) in the indelible ink. Upon receiving a ballot paper, the voter is to immediately go into one of the compartments to secretly vote, using the indelible pencil provided, marking one cross opposite the name of the candidate for whom he or she votes. The voter is to fold the ballot paper to conceal the vote, show the back of the paper to the presiding officer to show the officer's signature, and then drop the folded ballot paper into the ballot box. The voter must then immediately leave the polling station. A voter who inadvertently spoils a ballot paper can return it to the presiding officer and be issued a new one.  Source: 1992 Parliamentary Elections Act 56, 57(1-3), 58(1-2), 59(1-9), 60(1-5), 61, 62(1-3), 63(1-4), 64(1-3)

voting_methods.instructions:
Residents abroad can vote by-mail or in person, and citizens who happen to be in a foreign country can vote in advance of election day in-person.

Vote by mail is free for all citizens residing abroad. The State is obliged to pay the costs. The Ministry of Internal Affairs sends the paper ballots to the citizens registered in the census elaborated by the census comissions abroad, that opted for voting by mail. The shipping is made in the fastest way possible, under registration, in the shortest term possible, after the draw which is referred to in paragraph 1 of article 31, to the addresses indicated in the census registration. Each paper ballot is accompanied by two envelopes: a) One green envelope, which is meant to receive the paper ballot and does not contain any instructions; b) The other envelope, a white and larger one, which is meant to contain the envelope for the paper ballot. The voter cross marks, in the respective square, the candidacy in which they want to vote and folds the paper ballot in four, introducing it in the green envelope, which is then closed. The green envelope, sealed, is introduced in the white envelope, with a copy of th identification card, that the voter sends, sealed, before the election. 

Source: 1979 Electoral Law of the Assembly of the Republic Articles 79-F(1-3), 79-G(1-6)

Voters can register ahead of time for early voting at the municipality in which they want to vote, at the election administration of the General Secretariat of the Ministry of Internal Affairs. Inpatients and prisoners can register to vote in advance at the hospital or prison where they are. Seven days before the election, the voter goes to the polling station where they chose to vote (there is at least one per constituency), shows a civil identification document and indicates the parish where they are registered. The voter is given a ballot paper and a white envelope. The voter marks their choice on the ballot in secret, folds it in four, puts it in the white envelope and seals it. This envelope is placed in another blue envelope where the voter's name and civil identification number, county, and the parish and registration office, if any, in which they are registered will be written. This envelope is closed and protected with a sticker whose duplicate will be delivered and serves as a receipt.    Source: 1979  Law governing Elections to the Assembly of the Republic Articles 40b(1-3), 79b(1-2), 79c(1-3)

The vote is exercised directly and in person by the voter at the polling station corresponding to the place where the voter is registered. The voters vote by order of arrival at the polling station. Voters are to show a civil identification document or any other official document that contains an updated photograph. If the voter does not have such an ID, he/she can vote as long as their identity is unanimously recognized by the board or by two duly identified voters. Proxy voting is not allowed.  The voter's name and ID number is read aloud and if the voter appears in the register they are given one ballot. The voter must mark the ballot in secrecy in the voting booth. The voter must make a cross within a box on the ballot paper corresponding to the candidate they wish to vote for. The voter folds the ballot in four and returns it to the polling president who puts it in the ballot box. The polling staff initial beside the name of the voter on the register. If a voter inadvertently spoils the ballot they can ask the chairman for another ballot and return the spoiled one.  Source: 1979 Law governing Elections to the Assembly of the Republic Articles 79(1-3), 82(1-2), 84, 88(1-8)

voting_methods.instructions: The Supervisor of Elections provides each Special Presiding Officer (assigned for the early voting) with a list of the election officers, their national ID numbers, and the constitutencies in which they are registered to vote. Each Special Presiding Officer is to be provided with a sufficient number of ballot papers and envelopes for the number of election officers on the list. The early voting by election officers is to be carried out according to the same procedures that apply to voting on polling day, with the exception that early voters are to place their marked ballot in the ballot paper envelope provided by the Special Presiding Officer (which indicates on the outside the number of the polling district) and seal the envelope, then place that envelope in the covering envelope provided (that is addressed to the relevant returning officer) and seal the envelope, and then insert the envelope in the sealed ballot box. Each ballot box is to be marked "special ballot box" and have the number of the constituency written on it. The Supervisor of Elections is to ensure the safe keeping of all the special ballot boxes.  Source: 1991 Representation of the People Act 34(1-9)

Voters must vote in-person at the specified polling station where they are regisered. At the polling station, eligible voters must present their national ID card and are given a single paper ballot by the presiding officer if their name appears on the voter register. If the person is on the register but does not have an ID, they must still be given a ballot provided that he or she satisfies the presiding officer that they have not been issued an ID card or that it has been lost or destroyed. At the time any person applies for a ballot paper, the presiding officer may, and if required by a candidate or his or her agent, must put to that person certain questions, such as relating to identity and whether the person has already voted in that election.   Immediately before giving a person a ballot paper, the presiding officer must mark the ballot with the offiical mark, call out the name, description and roll number of the elector, mark the elector's roll number on the counterfoil, and place a mark next to the elector's roll number in the register to indicate that a ballot paper has been received. Upon receiving a ballot, the elector must proceed into one of the compartments (polling booth) and, in secret, mark the ballot by placing a cross next to their chosen candidate. The voter then folds the ballot to conceal his or her vote and must then shows the presiding officer the back of the paper so as to disclose the official mark. In the presence of the presiding officer, the voter then puts the folded ballot into a sealed ballot box.   If a voters spoils their ballot, he or she can notify the presiding officer who will issue a new ballot paper upon return of the spoiled ballot.  Upon voting, the elector must immediately leave the polling station. Where another person has voted as the elector and after satisfactorily answering the questions permitted by the law to be asked at the poll, the presiding officer is to issue the elector a "tendered" ballot paper. The voter does not put it in the ballot box, but gives it to the presiding officer who keeps all tendered ballots in a separate package, along with a list of electors who voted by tendered ballot.   Source: 1991 Representation of the People Act 39; Second Schedule 27(1-4), 28 (1-2), 29(1-3), 32(1-3), 33

voting_methods.instructions: A variety of deadlines and timeframes appear to apply depending upon the category and location of voter. Art 49 Public Offices Election Law 2016.  New provisions allow persons isolating because of Covid-19 to vote by mail. Also available for overseas voters. Art 49 Public Offices Election Law 2016. Act on Special Exceptions to the Voting Method for Specific Patients Using Mail, June 18 2021.

Voters can vote at polling places from the day following the day on which the notification of election day is made from 8.30am to 8.00pm on the day before election day but must establish some reason , such as incapcity or absence (work, travel, leisure, ceremonial occasions etc) why can't attend at polling place on election day. Article 48 -2(1) Public Offices Election Law 2016.  For constituency elections voters must write the one person they want to vote for on the ballot paper and put it in the ballot box.  For the PR election they must write the name or abbreviation of the political party or other organisation they want to vote for or  a single candidate on their ballot paper and put it in the ballot box. Art 46 Public Offices Election Law 2016.

For constituency elections voters must write the one person they want to vote for on the ballot paper and put it in the ballot box.  For the PR election they must write the name or abbreviation of the political party or other organisation they want to vote for or a single candidate  on their ballot paper and put it in the ballot box.

government_functions.details:
Timor-Leste is a semi-presidential system in which the president and the parliament (which chooses the prime minister) are elected by direct, universal suffrage for five-year terms. The President is the Head of State while the  Prime Minister acts as the Head of government. The prime minister oversees the day-to-day functioning of government and chairs the Council of Ministers. The prime minister is designated by the political party or alliance of political parties with a majority in the national legislature and is formally appointed by the president.

The Legislature is a unicameral Parliament, composed of the National Assembly. Parliamentarians are elected on national party slates with proportional representation. Ministers are also appointed by the president, following the recommendations of the prime minister. 

The judiciary is notionally headed by the Supreme Court: as it has not yet been appointed, the Court of Appeal acts in its place.

voting_methods.instructions: Before casting votes, voters must first show their voter registration card to the electoral officers and their hands to the identification officer to confirm that they have not voted yet. Upon completing the said steps, voters will receive a ballot paper stamped and signed on the back by the ballot paper controller. The voters must then go alone into the polling booth and vote, sign, or perforate the square corresponding to the preferred candidate in the ballot box. After voting, voters must fold the ballot paper twice then drop it in the ballot box. The ballot box controller will then mark their index finger with indelible ink before leaving the polling station. (Article 32, sec. (1)(5)(6)(8)(9)(10) of Regulation on the Polling and result Tabulation Procedures for the Election of the President of the Republic)  The voting is done by marking or by perforating the square in the ballot paper corresponding to the preferred candidate. (Article 34 of Regulation on the Polling and result Tabulation Procedures for the Election of the President of the Republic)

voting_methods.instructions: The law provides for voting in diplomatic posts and consular missions abroad.  Voting procedures are the same as those of in-country, in-person voting.

The following may vote in advance:
a) Military personnel who, on the day of the election, are prevented from going to the polling station due to an urgent need to carry out their duties;
b) Agents of forces and services who carry out functions of internal security under the terms of the law and are in a similar situation to that foreseen in the previous subparagraph.
c) Long-distance maritime and aeronautical workers who, by virtue of their professional activity, are presumably on board or displaced on the day of the election.

Qualified voters imay go to the President of the CRE of the area in which he is registered, 72 hours before election day, expressing his will to exercise his right to vote in advance. After verification, ballot is given to the voter. The voter fills in the ballot secretly, folds it in four, inserting it in the white subscript, which closes properly. Then the white subscript is inserted into the blue subscript together with the  supporting document, the blue subscript being closed, sealed and legibly signed on the back by the President of the CRE and by the voter

The voter presents himself to the polling station, which proceeds with his identification, upon examination of the voter card. The Chairman of the Board gives the voter a ballot paper indicating the polling booth. After voting, voter must dip a finger in indelible ink.

campaign_finance.details:
The financing of the candidates' electoral campaign can be done by: a) Contribution from similar parties; b) Voluntary contribution from voters; c) Contribution of the candidates themselves and the parties Politicians; d) Proceeds from the activity of the electoral campaign. Direct funding of election campaigns by foreign governments and foreign government organizations is prohibited.

 

The law also requires submission to the CNE of  the origin of the financing obtained and the expenses incurred during the electoral campaign within a maximum period of 30 days after the official proclamation of the election results. The CNE assesses within  60 days the regularity of funding and expenses and publish its assessment in the Official Gazette. If it  finds any irregularity, it must notify the respective entity to, within 15 days, correct it.

election_issues: Inflation; corruption; democracy; refugee crisis; treatment of ethnic minorities
election_commission_historical_context: During the 2018 general elections, the technical aspects of the election administration were carried out in an efficient manner. However, the Supreme Board of Elections did not exercise oversight over the lower election boards and failed to produce manuals or voting education materials. Overall transparency in the election administration was also lacking, including the election board's failure to publish all its decisions as required by law.  Upon governors' requests based on security considerations, the election board relocated and merged a number of polling stations affecting some 120,000 voters in 16 provinces.The election board did not publish the numbers and locations of the polling stations moved, the number of voters affected, or the justification for these decisions. Some of these changes were done after the legal deadline. The measures resulted in some voters having to travel several kilometres to vote, and voters were not informed in a systematic manner of their new places for voting.  Various stakeholers noted that the affected communities opposed these measures and expressed concerns that the measures were aimed at lowering the voter turnout in areas considered to be HDP strongholds. Complaints were lodged against the decisions.

government_functions.details: Turkey is a presidential republic. The President serves as both the chief of state and head of government. The president is directly elected for a 5-year term and is eligible to serve two terms.   Turkey has a unicameral Grand National Assembly (Buyuk Millet Meclisi) which has 600 members. Members are directly elected in multi-seat constituencies to serve 5-year terms.   The highest courts are the Constitutional Court (Anayasa Mahkemesi), Court of Cassation, and the Council of State.

voting_methods.instructions:
Only voters registered on the Overseas Electoral Register can vote overseas. The Overseas Electoral Register includes the records of Turkish citizens residing abroad taken from the address registration system of the General Directorate of Population and Citizenship Affairs by the General Directorate of Electoral Register.

Overseas voting is implemented by several methods: in-person at foreign representations (or other designated locations), at customs gates, and by-mail. Electronic voting for overseas voters can also be implemented by decision of the Supreme Board of Elections, in which case voters are to be provided with passwords and similar safety measures are to be taken to prevent multiple voting. If electronic voting is used, it is to begin 30 days before election day and end 17:00 on election day. The Supreme Board of Elections, based on the opinion of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, determines separately or individually, the voting methods either using electronic or paper ballots, considering the type of elections and conditions of the country. The foreign representations (and other designated places) where voting will take place in-person are determined by the Supreme Board of Elections, based on the opinion Ministry of Foreign Affairs.  Overseas voters may vote in the presidential election and the proportional part of the parliamentary election (not majoritarian elections.) For by-mail overseas voting, specially manufactured ballot papers and coloured voting envelopes are used, which are sent to the addresses of the overseas voters five days before the election.  One small envelope carries the seal of the foreign district election board in which the ballot is included. This envelope is to be put in another medium envelope in which the words "foreign district election board Ankara/Turkiye" is written and this envelope is put in a third larger envelope on which the the voters' foreign address is written. After marking the ballot paper with an 'X' beside the column of the preferred political party or presidential candidate, the voter puts the ballot paper in the small envelope and closes it. This envelope is put in the  medium envelope which is then sealed and the voter sends it in a way to arrive at the foreign district election board at the latest at 17:00 on election day. For in-person voting at polling stations located at  foreign representations (and other designated places), secrecy of the vote must be respected.  The ballots and envelopes for overseas voting in-person are specially  manufactured in special colours. When the voters comes to vote, the president of the ballot box committee checks the voters identification document and whether the voter has already voted, over a computer supported central electoral roll system. If the voter has not yet voted, he/she is given a stamped ballot paper and the 'yes' or 'preference' stamp. After voting, the voter signs on the electoral roll next to his/her name.  The sealed envelopes with the ballots are put in a bag along with the other voting materials, and sent to the overseas district election board for counting. For voting at customs gates, the period of voting begins 45 days before election day and ends 17:00 on election day; voting hours are 8:00 to 17:00. Specially manufactured ballot papers and envelopes in special colours are used for customs gate voting. The designated customs gates are determined by the Supreme Board of Elections. Secrecy of the vote must be guaranteed.  When a voter comes to a customs gate to vote, the president of the ballot box committee checks his/her identity document and that he/she has not already voted, as indicated on the computer supported central electoral roll. The voter is given a stamped ballot paper and a 'yes' or 'preference' stamp, and enters the secret voting area and completes the voting process. The voter then signs the electoral roll.  Ballots are counted at the customs gates.

Voters must vote at the polling station at which they are appear on the voter list (absentee voting is not permitted), unless the voter has a decision of the district election board to be presented to the ballot box committee. Poll workers and law enforcement officers are provided documentation from the distriction election board to vote at the polling station to which they are assigned (MPs and candidates can vote at any polling station by presenting their voter document). The names of the above-noted persons are added at the end of the voter list by the ballot box committee. Voters who are pregnant, ill or diabled did not have to wait in line at the polling station.  One by one, the voters registered in the voter list are to prove their identity by official documents shown to the president of the ballot box committee; the list of acceptable identfication documents is  determined by the Supreme Board of Elections prior to the election day. Proxy voting is not permitted. The president finds the name fo the voter in the voter list and gives him/her one ballot paper and envelope, as well as 'yes' stamp, guides him/her to the place for secret voting if there is more than one cabin and tells the voters to go out of the cabin after folding the ballot and inserting it in the envelope. The voter must then go directly to the place for secret voting with the ballot/envelope. Nobody is allowed inside the secret voting area unless the previous voter leaves; voters who remain inside the cabin for more than a reasonable time are to be warned by the president. Voters who do not leave the area despite warning are removed from the cabin. Voters are not allowed inside the secret voting area with phones, cameras, audio or video recorders or any other communication tools. These kind of devices are to be turned off and presented to the president before voting; the devices are returned to voters after voting. The voter casts his/her vote by affixing the stamp inside the circle belonging to the political party or candidate of preference. After folding the ballot paper and placing it in the envelope and sealing it, the voter leaves the voting cabin and personally inserts the envelope inside the ballot box. The voter returns the stamp back tothe president. Voters with disabilties can be assisted by a relative registered at the polling station or by another voter. The president returns the voter's ID card to the voter and has the voter put his/her signature on the voter list. If the voter cannot sign, the fingerprint of the left thumb is taken or other finger if necessary. After voting, voters must immediately leave the polling station. Voters in line at the time of closing are to be allowed to vote.

campaign_finance.details: Political parties that received at least three per cent of votes in the last parliamentary elections are entitled to annual public funding on a proportional basis, as well as campaign funding but only for regular elections, In addition, parties are financed from membership fees and private donations. Donations from public legal entities, state and public organizations and foreign sources are prohibited.  An individual may donate up to TRY 44,000 annually to a party. There is no ceiling for annual party and campaign-related expenditure. Parties declare their funds soley through annual financial reports; these reports do not include incomes and expenditures incurred by candidates nor by third parties. The Constitutional Court audits the reports but only publishes the auditing results years later. Independent candidates declare their campaign funds through personal tax declarations. Possible sanctions for breaches include warnings, imprisonment from three months to three years, monetary fines and dissolution of the party.

election_commission_historical_context:
Election management is divided into three levels in Montenegro; the State Election Commission (SEC) at the national level, Municipal Election Commissions (MECs) at the sub-national level, and Polling Boards (PBs) at the polling station level. The SEC and MECs are permanent bodies that serve four-year terms, and MECs manage the appointment of the PBs for each election. Article 18 of the Law on Election Counselors and Members of Parliament determines that election management bodies should operate in both permanent composition (standard appointed members) and extended composition. The Parliament appoints the permanent composition of the SEC, consisting of 10 members and a president. The SEC includes four members from the parliamentary majority, four from the parliamentary opposition, one from the minority entity that received the most votes in the previous election, and one from civil society or academia. The SEC’s main responsibilities include coordinating MECs, overseeing election materials, reviewing and publishing official candidate lists, and ascertaining and publishing election results.

Municipal assemblies appoint the permanent composition of MECs, consisting of a president and four permanent members. In extended composition, the same nominating entity that submits a candidate for the presidency also nominates an individual’s membership in the extended composition. MECs determine the number and location of polling stations across the country in addition to determining the number of ballots needed for each polling station. The presidential election is administered by the SEC, 25 MECs, and approximately 1,200 PBs.

government_functions.details:
Montenegro is a parliamentary republic. The Prime Minister is nominated by the president and approved by the Assembly. The President is directly elected in a two rounds of voting if necessarily. Voters in Montenegro must have resided in the country for a minimum of 10 of the past 15 years. 

The unicameral Skupstina or Assembly has 81 seats with all members directly elected in a single nationwide constituency. Members serve for four years unless snap elections are called by the President of Montenegro, the government, or a minimum of 25 members of parliament. 

The judiciary is comprised of the Supreme Court (Vrhovni Sud), which has 17 members including a court president and deputy president, as well as the Constitutional Court (Ustavni Sud).

In Greece, the President serves as chief of state, while the Prime Minister acts as head of government. The President is indirectly elected by Parliament and may serve up to two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister, customarily the leader of the parliamentary majority party, is appointed by the President.   Greece has a unicameral Hellenic Parliament with 300 seats. 285 members are elected in multi-seat constituencies, while the remaining 15 are elected from a single, nationwide constituency. All members are directly elected via open party-list proportional representation vote and serve 4-year terms.  There are three high courts: the Supreme Civil and Criminal Court, the Council of State (for cases involving the national government), and the Court of Audit. The 56 judges of the Supreme Court and the president of the Court of Audit are nominated by an expert panel called the Supreme Judicial Council and appointed by the President. The president of the Council of State is appointed by the executive cabinet. All other Council of State and Court of Audit judges are hired via a competitive process.

voting_methods.instructions:
Registered voters wishing to exercise their right to vote abroad have to submit an online application through a dedicated government portal.  If accepted, the voter is placed on the foreign voters list for a period of eight years. Overseas voters will have the right to elect only candidates who are on the parties' nationwide candidate lists and not the parliamentarians that represent a particular regional constituency.  Overseas voting will takeplace in person at polling stations which will be set up in embassies, consulates and suitable venues of Greek disaspora organizations. For an out-of-country polling station to be constituted, a minimum of 40 registered voters is required. On the day appointed for voting, voters come to the polling station of the relevant electoral division and present themselves to the electoral commitee, which determines their identity based on their Greeck police ID or Greek passport, and verifies their registration in the foreign voter list. To each voter, the electoral committee delivers an envelope initialed by the representative of the judicial authority and sealed with a stamp of the committee, a complete set of ballot forms and a blank ballot. Then the voter proceeds to the special separate area, in such a way that he/she cannot be seen, and there the voter secretly inserts the ballot paper of his choosing in the envelope given to him/her by the election committee. After securely sealing the envelope, the voter returns to the election committee and shows the envelope to the members and other attendees, to show that he/she is holding only one envelope, and then inserts the envelope into the ballot box. The election committee draws up minutes during the voting for every matter related to its conduct.

The 2023 elections will be the first time that certain out-of-country Greek citizens will be able to vote abroad.  According to legislation adopted in December 2019, after the 2019 parliamentary elections,  registered voters who are temporarily or permanently abroad must fulfil two main requirements in order to vote abroad. They must have had a two-year stay in Greece in the last 35 years and for those over 30 years old they  must have filed  a tax return in Greece in the year of the election or the preceding year.

Voters must vote in person in the electoral constituency where they are registered. Citizens residing outside their constituency can apply to vote at specially designated absentee polling stations in the  municipalities of their temporary residence. Voters go to the polling station and present themselves to the returning board which will examine their identification and verify whether they are registered in the electoral rolls. Voters will enter the polling station one by one or in groups of small numbers in the order they arrive or in the manner laid down by each returning board. In order to be identified when proceeding to exercise their right to vote, voters have to present their ID card or their passport. The returning board provides each voter with a specially marked envelope initialled by the court representative and stamped by the board as well as a full set of ballot papers for all party-lists and independent candidates. The voter is to proceed to the polling booth and must vote in secret, in such a way that he/she cannot be seen. The voter must place the chosen and marked ballot papers within the specially marked envelope and seal it, then proceed to show the sealed and stamped envelope to the chairperson of the returning board and others present, and then the voter places the envelope in the ballot box. Voters physically incapable of performing such tasks can request the court representative or a member of the returning board for obligatory assistance.  For the constituency voting, voters may select the candidate or candidates of their choice by marking the candidate's name on the party ballot.  Upon request, voters will be provided with a certificate signed by the chairperson of the returning board and bearing its stamp that he/she voted. The returning board keeps a protocol in which the electors who vote are written.

election_commission_historical_context: The Centre gabonais des élections (CGE) succeded the prior CENI. Since February 2023, a new face took the helm of the Centre Gabonais des Elections. Michel Stéphane Bonda has been elected to replace Moise Bibalou Koumba. A former deputy minister, he also advised the Bongo fathers and sons. 3 elections this year: presidential, legislative and local.  The CGE supervises, but the Interior Ministry manages elections.

government_functions.details: The President of Gabon serves as the chief of state, while the Prime Minister acts as head of government. The President is directly elected by plurality vote and serves 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is appointed by the President.  Gabon has a bicameral parliament including a 67-seat Senate and a 143-seat National Assembly. Within the Senate, 15 members are appointed by the President, and 52 members are indirectly elected by municipal and departmental legislative bodies. Senators serve 6-year terms. Within the National Assembly, all members are directly elected by plurality vote in single-seat constituencies and serve 5-year terms.  Gabon has 6 high courts, each of which operates indepedently and addresses a different legal area: the Court of Cassation (civil, social, and criminal cases), the Council of State (administrative cases), the Accounting Court (public finance cases), the Constitutional Court (constitutional cases), the High Court of Justice (temporary institution for presidential treason cases), and the Court of Justice of the Republic (temporary institution for criminal cases against national government officials). These judges are appointed by Parliament, the President, the High Council of Magistrates, or other courts.

institution.term_details: Article 35 (Law n°046/2020 of January 11, 2021) The legislative power is represented by a Parliament composed of two (2) chambers: the National Assembly and the Senate. Members of the National Assembly bear the title of deputy. They are elected by direct universal suffrage for a renewable term of five (5) years.

institution.name: Gabonese Presidency
institution.term_details: Article 11 (Law n°001/2018 of January 12, 2018) The term of office of the President of the Republic begins on the day of his swearing-in and ends on the expiry of the seventh year following his swearing-in. The election of the President of the Republic takes place at least one (1) month and at most two (2) months before the expiry of the term of office of the incumbent President. The latter may not shorten his term of office in any way whatsoever in order to seek another. If the incumbent President of the Republic becomes a candidate, the National Assembly may not be dissolved. Moreover, from the official announcement of his candidacy until the election, he may not exercise his power to legislate by ordinance. If necessary, Parliament is convened in extraordinary session. If the President of the Republic is re-elected, he may take the oath of office as soon as the results of the election have been announced by the Constitutional Court.

government_functions.details: In Mauritania, the President serves as chief of state, while the Prime Minister is head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is appointed by the President and has no term limit.  Mauritania has a unicameral National Assembly (Al Jam'iya Al Wataniya) with 176 seats. 88 members are elected via absolute majority vote (up to two rounds) in a single, nationwide constituency. The remaining 88 members are elected via closed-list proportional representation vote in multi-member constituencies, including 4 overseas constituencies. All members are directly elected and serve 5-year terms. Out of the 88 nationwide constituency seats, 20 seats are reserved for women, and 11 are reserved for youth (aged 25 to 30).   The Mauritanian judiciary is composed of the Supreme Court (21 judges), the Constitutional Council (9 judges), and the High Court of Justice (9 judges). Judges within these institutions are all appointed by either the President, the Prime Minister, or members of the National Assembly.

voting_methods.instructions: Voters living abroad can vote in-person at Mauritanian embassies and consulates.
Members of the Armed and security forces vote the day preceding the polling day.

Voters vote in person at the polling station where they are registered to vote. The voter is admitted to vote upon presentation of his/her Voter's Card and National ID Card. Indelible ink on the voter's finger is checked and applied, as a safeguard against multiple voting. Once the voter's identity and presence on the voter list is determined, and after he/she is determined not to have an inked finger, the polling official gives the voter the (four) ballot(s).  Upon receiving the ballot(s), voters proceed to the polling booth to manually mark the ballot(s) in secret. Voters with certain affirmities can be assisted by a person or voter of their choice. After marking the ballot(s), the voterproceeds to insert each ballot into the respective  ballot box.

campaign_finance.details: Legally constituted political parties or coalitions are allocated public financial assistance which is included in the State Budget.  The public funding is based on the results of the previous elections. Political parties are allowed to receive private donations.

government_functions.details: The President of Ecuador serves as both head of government and head of state.  The president is directly elected by plurality of at least 40% and a 10% differential to the runner-up vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two consecutive 4-year terms.  The National Assembly shall be comprised of Fifteen (15) Assembly persons elected as representatives of the nation as a whole (national district). Two (2) Assembly persons elected for each province, plus one (1) additional Assembly person for every two hundred thousand (200,000) inhabitants or fraction thereof over one hundred fifty thousand (150,000), on the basis of the last national population census.  The jurisdictional bodies, without detriment to the other bodies with equal powers recognized in the Constitution, are those in charge of administering justice and they shall be as follows: The National Court of Justice. The provincial courts of justice. The courts and tribunals provided for by law. The justices of the peace.

institution.name: Ecuadorian Presidency
institution.term_details: There is a two-term limit; the president can be reelected only once, consecutively or not.

voting_methods.instructions: Ecuadorian citizens living abroad can register via their national ID or passport to vote. They then vote online on election day.
On 17 August, pre-trial detainees vote.  On 18 August, qualified pre-registered voters vote early from home.
Voters must present a valid national ID card.

campaign_finance.details: Article 12. Control over electoral and campaign spending For this process, Article 10 of the Organic Law on Control over Electoral and Campaign Spending is applicable, using the following values for the corresponding calculation: Election of the President and Vice-President of the Republic: zero point fifteen dollars (US$0.15); Election of members of the Andean Parliament: zero point zero five dollars (US$0.05); Election of national and provincial Assembly persons and prefects: zero point fifteen dollars (US$0.15); Election of Assembly persons representing nationals living abroad: zero point thirty dollars (US$0.30); Election of mayors: zero point fifteen dollars (US$0.15); Election of council persons: the maximum amount shall be sixty percent (60%) of the amount set for the respective mayor; Election of members of parish boards: zero point thirty dollars (US$0.30.

Two (2) Assembly persons elected for each province, plus one (1) additional Assembly person for every two hundred thousand (200,000) inhabitants or fraction thereof over one hundred fifty thousand (150,000), on the basis of the last national population census.  The jurisdictional bodies, without detriment to the other bodies with equal powers recognized in the Constitution, are those in charge of administering justice and they shall be as follows: The National Court of Justice. The provincial courts of justice. The courts and tribunals provided for by law. The justices of the peace.

The President of Brazil serves as both head of government and head of state.  The president is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two consecutive 4-year terms.    The National Congress is composed of a Senate with 81 seats and a Chamber of Deputies with 513 seats.  Senators are directly elected in multi-seat constituencies by plurality vote and serve 8-year terms.  Deputies are directly elected via an open-list proportional representation system and serve 4-year terms.    The Brazilian judiciary is headed by the Federal Supreme Court (STF), a body of 11 justices.  Justices are nominated by the President and confirmed in the Senate by absolute majority vote.

voting_methods.instructions: https://www.tse.jus.br/eleicoes/eleicoes-2022/normas-e-documentacoes/arquivos/3-resolucao-atos-gerais-eleicoes-2022-inteiro-teor-acordao/rybena_pdf?file=https://www.tse.jus.br/eleicoes/eleicoes-2022/normas-e-documentacoes/arquivos/3-resolucao-atos-gerais-eleicoes-2022-inteiro-teor-acordao/at_download/file  Voting is obligatory also for out-of-country voters.

election_commission_historical_context: The Central Electoral Board is the highest body of the Electoral Administration. It is permanent and has its headquarters in the Congress of Deputies in Madrid.  It is composed of eight Magistrates of the Supreme Court, appointed by means of insaculation by the General Council of the Judiciary; and five active professors of Law or Political Science and Sociology, appointed at the joint proposal of the parties, federations, coalitions or groups of voters with representation in the Congress of Deputies.  These appointments must be made within ninety days following the constitutive session of the Congress of Deputies. The Members are appointed by Royal Decree and continue in office until the new Central Electoral Board takes office at the beginning of the following Legislature. These elect, from among the Members of judicial origin, the President and the Vice President of the Board in the constitutive session.  The Secretary of the Central Electoral Board is the Secretary General of the Congress of Deputies. The Director of the Electoral Census Office is a non-voting member of the Central Electoral Board.  Source: http://www.juntaelectoralcentral.es/cs/jec/admelectoral/jecentral

government_functions.details: The King, a hereditary monarch, is the Spanish chief of state, while the President is the head of government. The President, typically the leader of the largest congressional party or coalition, is nominated by the King and elected by the Congress of Deputies.  The legislature (Cortes Generales) is composed of a Senate with 265 seats and a Congress of Deputies with 348 seats. Senators serve 4-year terms and are directly elected by plurality vote in multi-seat constituencies (208 seats) or indirectly elected by autonomous community legislatures (57 seats). Deputies serve 4-year terms and are directly elected via closed-list proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies (348 seats) or directly elected by plurality vote (2 seats in Ceuta and Melilla).  The Spanish judiciary is headed by the Supreme Court (president and 79 judges organized into thematic chambers) and the Constitutional Court (12 judges). Supreme Court judges are nominated by the General Council of the Judiciary Power (CGPJ) and appointed by the King. These judges may serve until they are 70 years old. Constitutional Court judges are nominated by the legislature, president, and CGPJ and appointed by the King to serve 9-year terms.

institution.name: Spanish Congress of Deputies
institution.term_details: Section 68 Constitution 4. The Congress is elected for four years. The term of office of Members thereof ends four years after their election or on the day on which the Congress is dissolved.

voting_methods.instructions: Article 75. Exercise of the vote by persons living abroad 1. In elections for Deputies, Senators, members of the Legislative Assemblies of the Autonomous Communities, members of the Assemblies of the Autonomous Cities of Ceuta and Melilla and Deputies to the European Parliament, when in the latter case the election is chosen in Spain, the Provincial Delegations of the Electoral Census Office shall send, ex officio, to the address of registration of each person of Spanish nationality registered in the census of resident-absent voters living abroad, the following documentation:  (a) The voting envelope or, as the case may be, the voting envelopes for each process called, with adequate security systems.  b) Two identical certificates of being registered in the census of absentee resident voters living abroad, except in the case of concurrent elections with scrutiny in different electoral boards, in which case the corresponding ones shall be sent according to said electoral concurrence.  c) The envelope or envelopes in which the address of the competent Electoral Board and the envelope in which the address of the Consular Post or Consular Section of the Diplomatic Mission in which he/she is registered shall appear,  d) An information sheet on how to exercise the right to vote and the address of the official website where the final candidacies shall be displayed, and where downloadable sets of ballots shall be available, with all the competing candidacies, as well as any other information on the electoral processes in progress, and  e) The list of centers authorized for the deposit of votes in ballot boxes in the area of their consular demarcation.  2. The ballot or ballots of the voters registered in the census of absent residents living abroad for each process called shall correspond to the official ballot, as well as to a downloadable model ballot approved by the Electoral Board. The information sheet that shall accompany the documentation referred to in the previous section shall contain the instructions for obtaining a set of ballots telematically in an accessible manner, with all the competing candidacies, as well as the means by which the voters shall be able to know the proclaimed candidacies.  In order to guarantee the secrecy of the vote, only the complete set of ballots may be downloaded telematically.  The Public Administrations shall guarantee the material and technical means to provide the voters with access to the information on the electoral process and to the downloadable ballots.  3. The electoral documentation referred to in the first paragraph shall be sent by registered mail as from the eighteenth day and before the twenty-fifth day following the call for elections.  The Provincial Delegations of the Electoral Census Office shall also send the official ballots to the address of registration of absentee voters living abroad, as of the twenty-ninth day and no later than the thirty-third day following the call, in those provinces where the proclamation of candidates has not been challenged, and in the remaining provinces, no later than the thirty-ninth day.  The downloadable ballots shall be available after the resolution of the appeals filed against the proclamation of candidacies and no later than the fifth day after the proclamation of candidacies.  The Public Administrations shall provide the necessary means in each case so that the mailings provided for in paragraphs 1, 3 and 8 of this Article are carried out in the quickest, safest and most efficient manner, including the diplomatic pouch and forwarding by internal mail of the corresponding country, to the extent that the Electoral Roll Office and the consular administration deem it necessary and possible.

Only OCV voters can vote by mail. 7. Voters who choose to exercise their right to vote by mail shall include in the envelope addressed to the corresponding Electoral Board, in addition to the voting envelope or envelopes, one of the certificates of being registered in the census, on the back of which shall be the signature and passport or National Identity Card number of the voter, a photocopy of the passport or National Identity Card issued by the Spanish authorities or a certificate of nationality or, failing this, a certificate of registration in the Consular Register issued by the Consular Office or the Consular Section of the Diplomatic Mission of Spain in the country of residence. All of the above shall be placed in the envelope addressed to the Consular Post or Consular Section of the Diplomatic Mission to which each voter is attached, and the other certificate of being registered in the census shall be included in this envelope. The documentation thus ordered shall be sent personally by the voter by postal mail, certified when possible, to the Consular Post or Consular Section of the Diplomatic Mission to which each voter is attached, no later than the fifth day prior to the day of the election.  Envelopes received by mail at the Consular Post or Consular Section of the Diplomatic Mission before the final proclamation of candidatures shall not be valid. Those arriving after the second day prior to the day of the election shall not be valid either. This deadline shall not be extended in order to ensure that the votes arrive in time to be counted by the Electoral Boards.

Article 32 LOREG 1. Registration in the electoral roll is compulsory. In addition to the name and surname, the only data necessary for the identification of the voter in the act of voting, without prejudice to the provisions of Article 85, the number of the National Identity Card shall be included among the remaining census data.  2. The Municipal Councils shall process the registration of the residents in their municipal district ex officio.  3. The Consular Posts and Consular Sections of the Diplomatic Missions shall ex officio process the registration of Spaniards residing in their demarcation in the manner established by regulation.

election_commission_historical_context: Stakeholders in civil society and the media have voiced concerns over the independence and impartiality of the election administration, particularly on the local and regional level. These concerns are based on perceived influence on its decision-making and previous reported instances of malpractices during elections, in particular on the most recent referendum and election days.

government_functions.details: In Uzbekistan, the President serves as chief of state, while the Prime Minister serves as head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two 7-year terms. The Prime Minister is nominated by the majority party in the Supreme Assembly and appointed by the President.   Uzbekistan has a bicameral Supreme Assembly consisting of a 100-seat Senate and a 150-seat Legislative Chamber. Members of the Senate are indirectly elected by regional councils (84 members) or appointed by the president (16 members). All members serve 5-year terms. All 150 members of the Legislative Chamber are directly elected by absolute majority vote in single-seat constituencies and serve 5-year terms.  The Supreme Court and Constitutional Court are the highest judicial bodies of Uzbekistan. The Supreme Court has 67 judges, while the Constitutional Court has only 7. Judges for both institutions are nominated by the President and confirmed by the Senate. Judges may serve one term of 10 years.

institution.name: Uzbekistani Presidency
institution.term_details: In 2023, the two-term limit for the incumbent president was reset, allowing him to run in the 2023 presidential election. The presidential term was also increased from 5 to 7 years.

voting_methods.instructions: Voters staying in densely populated areas of citizens of Uzbekistan abroad can vote in embassies and consular offices. Voter lists at polling stations formed at embassies and consular offices are compiled on the basis of data provided by the heads of those institutions. The precinct election commissions formed at embassies and consular offices inform citizens in foreign countries about the method, place and time of familiarlization with the voter lists. Citizens in foreign countries can apply in writing to precinct election commissions in the embassies and consular offices, or electronically through the official website of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, to be included in the voter list for fifteen days before the election. The precinct election commissions submit to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs information on citizens included on the voter lists and the Ministry submits information about such citizens to the State Center for Personalization under the Cabinet of Ministers to make appropriate changes to the Single Electronic Voter Register. The method for out-of-country voting is the same as for voting in-country. Out-of-country voting includes the possibility of early and mobile voting. In polling stations at embassies and consular offices, the precinct election commission may at any time report the voting completed if all citizens included in the list have voted.

A voter who is unable to vote at his/her place of residence on election day has the right to vote early, upon application indicating the reasons for absence (vacation, business trip, travel abroad, etc.). The voter receives the ballot paper from the relevant precinct election commission and signs the voter list in the presence of at least two members of the commission. The ballot is marked by the voter in a specially equipped booth or room for secret voting.  The voter then places the marked ballot in a sealed envelope, two members of the precinct election commission sign on the seal which is then officially sealed with the commission seal. The early ballot envelopes are stored in a safe at the relevant precinct election commission until mixed with all other ballots on election day.

Voters can vote at a specified polling station in the location where they are registered to vote.  Upon arrival at the polling station, the voter presents his/her identity document and signs the voter list. Then he/she is given a ballot. If a voter is not on the voter list, he/she can register to vote on election day at the polling station, provided that the person is on the Single Electronic Voter Register. The voter fills out the ballot paper in the voting booth or room for secret voting.  A voter who is unable to mark the ballot on their own can invite another person to the booth at his/her discretion, with the exception of poll workers, observers and media representatives. The voter puts a valid mark on the empty square situated on the right side, opposite the surname of the candidate for whom he/she is voting. The voter then puts the ballot in to the ballot box. To ensure secrecy of the vote, the polling station must be set up so that the voter must pass through a secret voting booth/room in order to cast the ballot in the ballot box. If a voter spoils a ballot, the ballot may be replaced with a new one by the poll worker. A voter who cannot come to the polling station due to health or other reasons can request the polling commission to come to the voter's house to allow him/her to vote.  The homebound voting must respect the secrecy of the vote. Special polling stations are established in places where voters temporarily reside such as penitentiary institutions, military units, hospitals and other health institutions.

campaign_finance.details: Political parties with a faction in the legislative chamber of the parliament are entitled to annual public funding distributed proportionally to the number of seats gained in the last parliamentary elections. Additionally, parties receive funds from the state budget for campaign purposes in an amount determined by the Central Election Commission. Unused campaign funds must be returned to the state budget after the election. Other sources of funding, including private and party and candidate funding and donations, are prohibited for use in election campaigns. Political parties must submit to the Central Election Commission an interim campaign finance report five days before election day and a final report within twenty days after the announcement of the election results. Both reports must contain information about expenditure of funds for campaign purposes. Political parties are required to publish the reports on their websites and in the print media within a month following the announcement of the election results. Parties must also submit annual financial reports to the legislative chamber of the parliament, the Ministry of Finance and the Tax Committee. The Chamber of Accounts, directly subordinate to the President, conducts an ex post financial audit due in the beginning of the  next calendar year and the results of the audit are required to be published. The legal framework does not establish clear and effective sanctions for campaign finance violations, including for the failure to submit campaign finance reports or use of prohibited funding sources.

election_commission_historical_context:
Sierra Leone has always had an election management body called Electoral Commission. Even during periods of military rule, when electoral activities were suspended, the technical and support staff were maintained, thus making it possible to build a reservoir of experience in election administration within the institution. The President appoints all members of the Commission, after consultation with all registered Political Parties and subject to the approval of parliament.

The tenure of office of the Commissioners is five years, and their terms and conditions of service are prescribed by parliament. The Commission was renamed National Electoral Commission (NEC), following the passing of the NEC Act 2002. The Act empowers the Commission to appoint its own staff. The Commission is currently undergoing a restructuring process, which began in 2005. Before this time, Civil Servants recruited by the Public Service Commission (PSC) staffed the Commission. At the start of the current restructuring process, the Commission returned all its then Civil Servants to the Establishment Secretary’s Office. This was followed by the recruitment of new staff in a transparent and competitive manner, and trained into a professional staff.

government_functions.details:
Sierra Leone is a presidential republic. The President is the chief of state, head of government, and the minister of defense. The President is directly elected by an absolute majority popular vote in two rounds if necessary. Presidents must, per the Constitution, be nominated by a political party. 

Sierra Leone has a unicameral parliament with 146 seats total. 132 members are directly elected. 14 seats are filled in seperate elections by non-partisan members called "paramount chiefs". Paramount chiefs are regional leaders. 

The highest court is the Superior Court of Judicature, which consists of the Supreme Court, the Court of Appeal, and the High Court of Justice. The Supreme Court is the highest-ranking court out of these three. There are also a variety of subordinate courts, including District Appeals Court, magistrates' courts, and local courts.

institution.name: Sierra Leonean Presidency
institution.term_details: Article 46 Constitution 46. Tenure of office of President, etc 1. No person shall hold office as President for more than two terms of five years each whether or not the terms are consecutive. 2. Any person who is elected President while he is, or has been elected a Member of Parliament shall, on assuming office as President, cease to be an elected Member of Parliament and his seat shall be declared vacant. 3. The President shall not, while he continues in office as President, hold any other office of profit or emolument in the service of Sierra Leone or occupy any other position carrying the right to remuneration for rendering services. 4. Upon his assumption of office, the President shall take and subscribe the oath for the due execution of his office as set out in the Second Schedule to this Constitution. 5. The oath aforesaid shall be administered by the Chief Justice of Sierra Leone or the perso

voting_methods.instructions: https://ec.gov.sl/voting-procedure/

The voter exercises his/her right to vote in presidential elections at any polling station in the country.  Citizens can vote upon presentation of an identification card. In practice, there is no voter list at the polling station against which to authenticate the voter. The head of the polling station committee hands the voter an envelope signed by him/her and stamped with the committe's seal. The voter proceeds to a polling booth that ensures secrecy to mark the ballot. The voter puts the completed ballot paper in the sealed envelope - a ballot paper can be printed or written, prepared in advance or written in the polling booth, indicating the candidate of choice. Blind voters and voters with other disabilities can request a trusted person to write a ballot paper for them or can verbally tell a poll worker how they wish to vote and to have the poll worker complete the ballot paper. In both cases, the fact of the assistance must be recorded by the head of the polling committee. In front of the members of the polling station committee, agents and observers, the voter puts the sealed envelope in the ballot box. The voter's name is then recorded in the electoral record of the polling station.
