voting_methods.instructions: Ballot papers and voting materials are automatically mailed out to all voters in the country along with their personal voting cards. Voters abroad can receive postal voting materials upon written request no later than three weeks before election day. Postal ballots can be cast from anywhere in the country or from abroad (no postage required in Liechtenstein or Switzerland) or can be handed over to the municipality personally or by a representative. The marked ballot is placed in the secrecy voting envelope and together with the signed voting card must be sealed by the voter in the officially preprinted delivery envelope. Upon receipt of a postal ballot, the voting is noted in the voter register. Postal ballots received after the deadline are to be destroyed without opening.

At the polling station, a voter must present a personal voting card, which is delivered to all voters at least two weeks before the election day and contain the voter's address, place of registration, identification number and a barcode. At the polling station, the barcode is scanned and the "voter check-in" system in place at every polling station helps identify the voter and indicates if the voter has voted already. Voters can be included on the voter list on election day by the polling commission only if "his or her ommission from the list is an obvious mistake". The members of the election committee vote first and then the voters vote in the order they arrive. After check-in, the voter places the official ballot in the secret voting envelope and enters it in the ballot box. Voting booths are set up on the polling station that allow the voter to fill out the ballot in secret. Voters with disabilites can be assisted by a person of trust. At the polling station, the voter can vote the ballot that was mailed out to them, but official ballot papers are also available in the voting booth; secrecy envelopes can be obtained from the election committee. Only those candidates on the valid candidate lists can be voted for. A voter is allowed to make deletions and amendments to his/her official ballot paper, subject to provisions on invalid ballots. The vote is to be noted in the voter register.

Voters must register ahead of time for early voting at the municipality in which they want to vote, at the election administration of the General Secretariat of the Ministry of Internal Affairs. Inpatients and prisoners can register to vote in advance at the hospital or prison where they are.  Seven days before the election, the voter goes to the polling station where they chose to vote (there is one per municipality), shows a civil identification document and indicates the parish where they are registered.The voter is given a ballot paper and a white envelope. The voter marks their choice on the ballot in secret, folds it in four, puts it in the white envelope and seals it. This envelope is placed in another blue envelope where the voter's name and civil identification number and the parish and registration office, if any, in which they are registered will be written. This envelope is closed and protected with a sticker whose duplicate will be delivered and serves as a receipt.  In November 2020, temporary measures were introduced for mobile early voting with advance application to facilitate participation of voters who are in compulsory confinement in relation to the Covid-19 pandemic. Between the tenth and seventh day before election day, voters who, due to the COVID -19 disease pandemic, are in mandatory confinement, at their home or in a place other than a hospital, must express their intention by electronic means or at the Junta de Freguesia where they are registered through a third party who presents a declaration signed by you and a copy of the voter's ID. On the fifth and fourth day before election day, the Mayor or his/her representative goes to the voter's address indicated to allow him/her to vote.

The vote is exercised directly and in person by the voter at the polling station corresponding to the place where the voter is registered. The voters voter by order of arrival at the polling station. Voters are to show a civil identification document or any other official document that contains an updated photograph. If the voter does not have such an ID, he/she can vote as long as their identity is unanimously recognized by the board or by two duly identified voters. Proxy voting is not allowed.  The voter's name and ID number is read aloud and if the voter appears in the register they are given one ballot. The voter must mark the ballot in secrecy in the voting booth. The voter must make a cross within a box on the ballot paper corresponding to the candidate they wish to vote for. The voter folds the ballot in four and returns it to the polling president who puts it in the ballot box. The polling staff initial beside the name of the voter on the register. If a voter spoils the ballot they can ask the chairman for another ballot and return the spoiled one.

voting_methods.instructions: A May 2020 amendment to the election laws provides for the possiblity of the Central Election Commission establishing the option, with procedures, of voting by mail or internet voting. However, it is not known whether postal or internet voting will be used in the 2021 elections.

A May 2020 amendment to the election laws provides for the possiblity of the Central Election Commission establishing the option, with procedures, of voting by mail or internet voting. However, it is not known whether postal or internet voting will be used in the 2021 elections.

The election laws provide for the possibility for constituency election commissions to allow early voting (not earlier than 20 days before election day) for voters registered at one or several polling stations formed in hard-to-reach or remote areas, on ships that will be at sea on the voting day, and at polar stations, or for voters in settlements or areas without polling stations to vote, up to 15 days early. The dates of early voting are established by a decision of the relevant precinct election commission. However, it is not known whether, and to which extent, early voting will be available in the 2021 elections.       If early voting is conducted in the remote areas and settlements, it is done by sealed portable ballot boxes, accompanied by at least two members of the precinct election commission.  The secrecy of the vote is guaranteed. On the front side of each ballot paper issued to an early voter, in the upper right corner, the signatures of two voting members of the precinct election commission shall be put, certified by the seal of the precinct election commission.  The voter list with those eligible to vote early accompanies the portable ballot box. The voting is done according to the same procedure for voting on election day at polling stations. Upon receiving the ballot, the voter signs the voter list and the poll worker marks in the list that the voter voted early.  If an extract of the voter list is used, after the early voting is completed, the notations on early voting are transfered to the regular voter list at the polling station.

Voters vote at a designated polling station in their locality of residence. Permission for absentee voting (to allow a voter to vote at a polling station outside their area of residence) can be obtained by advance application by voters who will be away from their residential polling precinct on election day. Secrecy of the vote is guaranteed. Proxy voting is prohibited. Ballot papers are issued to voters included in the voter list upon presentation of a passport or document that replaces a citizens passport. Before issuing the ballot paper(s) to a voter, the precinct election commission is obliged to check that the voter has not already voted early (e.g. by portable ballot box in remote areas) or by mobile (homebound) voting. Each voter has a right to receive two ballot papers, one for voting in the federal electoral district and one for voting in the corresponding single-mandate electoral district (except absentee voters voting outside the territory of their single-mandate electoral district receive only the ballot for the federal electoral district.) A voter who is not on the voter list for any reason can be registered on election day, upon showing a passport or other proof of residence at the polling station. Upon receipt of the ballot, the identification document number of the voter is to be entered in the voter list. The voter checks the accuracy of the entry made and both the voter and the poll worker sign the voter list in the column next to the voter's name. The voter should enter the polling booth (or other specially equipped place for secret voting) to mark the ballot. Voters should vote alone, except a voter who is unable to independently mark the ballot can request assistance of another person who is not a poll worker, partisan representative, or observer. The voter using assistance must notify the precinct election commission and the personal details of the helper are to be entered in the voter list in the column next to the voter's name. Using any mark, the voter marks the ballot for voting in the federal electoral district - in the square referring to the chosen list of candidates, and on the ballot for voting in the single mandate electoral district - in the square referring to the chosen candidate.  A voter who spoils a ballot can receive a replacement one from the poll worker, who records the issuance of a replacement ballot in the voter list next to the voter's name and signs the entry along with the secretary of the precinct election commission. The voters puts the marked ballots into the sealed ballot box. If the Central Election Commission makes a decision to use ballot envelopes, the voter is to place the marked ballots into the envelope given to him/her by the poll worker after leaving the polling booth, and places the envelope in the ballot box. Electronic voting and counting machines may be used at polling stations.   Mobile (homebound) voting is available, upon advance application, for voters who, due to health reasons, disability, caring for a person in need, or other reasons, cannot go to the polling station.

Once voting card is verified by assistant presiding officer and finger is inked, marble/token is handed to voter who enters the voting compartment and drops the marble/token in his/her chosen ballot drum and leaves compartment afterwards.

election_name.en_US: Presidency of the Czech Republic, Second Round

government_functions.details:
The Czech Republic or Czechia is a parliamentary republic. The President is directly elected and serves a five-year term. The President appoints the Prime Minister. 

Czech parliament consists of the 81-seat Senate and the 200-seat Chamber of Deputies. Both houses are directly elected. 

The judiciary is comprised of the Supreme Court, the Supreme Administrative Court, and the Constitutional Court. Supreme Court judges are proposed by the lower house of parliament and are appointed for life.

The President of Turkmenistan serves as both the chief of state and head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds. The presidential term is 7 years, and there are no term limits.  The Mejlis is the unicameral legislature of Turkmenistan, and it has 125 seats. All 125 members are elected by absolute majority vote (via up to two rounds of voting) in single-seat constituencies. Members serve 5-year terms.   The Supreme Court is the highest judicial body in Turkmenistan, and it consists of a president and 21 judges split into three chambers. Judges are appointed by the President and serve 5-year terms.

voting_methods.instructions: Voters could vote at any point during the 10 days prior to election day. Voters do not need to justify their need to vote in advance, and early voting is intended to enable those who will be traveling or are unable to vote on election day for any other reason (OSCE 2017 Report)

election_issues: Russia-Ukraine war; Finland-EU relations; economy; migration; climate change

government_functions.details: In Finland, the President serves as chief of state, and the Prime Minister is head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two 6-year terms. The Prime Minister is indirectly elected by Parliament and formally appointed by the President.  Finland has a unicameral Parliament (Eduskunta) with 200 seats. 199 members are directly elected in single and multi-seat constituencies via proportional representation vote. The remaining member, who represents the autonomous region of Åland, is directly elected by plurality vote. All members serve 4-year terms.   The Finnish judiciary has two high courts: the Supreme Court (civil and criminal cases) and Supreme Administrative Court (government cases). The Supreme Court consists of 19 judges, while the Supreme Administrative Court has 21 judges. All high court judges are appointed by the President and may serve until age 68.

voting_methods.instructions: The Finnish diplomatic missions and their offices at which out-of-country voters can vote are determined by a government decree.  The ballot, ballot envelope, covering letter form, and envelope for the covering letter form provided by the Ministry of Justice are used for out-of-country voting. A voter who wishes to vote in at a diplomatic mission shall report to the election official at the location.  The voter is obliged to present a proof of his or her identity to the election official. Thereafter, he or she is given a ballot, a ballot envelope and a covering envelope and, if needed, a covering letter form.  The voter shall be provided with the opportunity to familiarise himself or herself with the master list of candidates for his or her electoral district. A voter in parliamentary elections has the right to vote for a candidate in the master list of candidates for the electoral district in which the voter is registered.  The voter shall mark the number of the candidate he or she is voting for in the ballot in such a manner that there can be no uncertainty as to whom he or she has voted for. The marking shall be made in the voting booth or somewhere else in a manner that maintains the election secrecy.  A person whose ability to mark the ballot is essentially weakened may request assistance from an election official, or can use the help of an assistant he or she has chosen. A candidate or his or her family member cannot assist voters. The assistant must strictly comply with the directions of the voter and keep secret the choice of the voter. The covering letter,which includes the name and identifying number of the voter, shall be addressed to the central electoral committee of that municipality and entered in the voter register next to the voter.  The voter shall sign a declaration on the covering letter stating that he or she himself or herself has, maintaining the election secrecy, filled in the ballot and enclosed it stamped in the ballot envelope. The voter shall give the folded ballot to the election official to be stamped and, immediately after the ballot is stamped, enclose it in the ballot envelope in front of the election authority. The closed ballot envelope and the signed covering letter are to be given to the election official. When a voter register is used in the advance polling station, the election official  shall check in the register that the voter has the right to vote, make an entry in the register indicating that the voter has used his or her right to vote, and make a marking on the covering letter indicating that an entry has been made in the voter register. When the voter register is not used at the polling location, a list of voters shall be kept.  The election offiical of a Finnish ship must deliver without delay the covering envelopes to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs or to a Finnish diplomatic mission in the country where the ship is or where it first arrives. The election official in a Finnish diplomatic mission, or, if the mission does not serve as an advance polling station, the Head of Mission, shall ensure that the covering envelopoes that have been given there or that have arrived there are delivered to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in a manner determined by it. The Ministry shall ensure that the covering envelopes are delivered without delay to the central electoral commitee of the municipality in question.

For the 2023 parliamentary elections, postal voting documents can be ordered starting 2 January 2023.  The first possible date for postal voting is 2 March 2023, when the candidates and their candidate numbers will be confirmed. 

Postal voting can be used only by persons living or staying abroad for the duration of the entire advance voting period and on election day. An eligible voter wishing to vote by post shall order the postal voting documents online from the Ministry of Justice to be sent to an address abroad. The postal voting documents can be ordered three months before the election day at the earliest. An assistant may be used for placing the order. The voter's name and personal identity code and the postal address abroad to which the documents will be sent must be given with the order. The postal voting package includes a ballot, a postal ballot envelope in which the ballot is inserted, a postal vote covering letter, which the voter must fill in, a postal vote covering envelope, in which the ballot envelope and the covering letter are inserted, and postal voting instructions, drawn up by the Ministry of Justice. The eligible voter himself or herself must find out the number of the candidate that he or she wants to vote for (which are published about one month before the election day). The instructions to vote are as follows: First, the voter marks the number of the candidate he or she wants to vote for on the ballot, inserts the ballot in the postal ballot envelope, and seals the envelope. Next, the voter fills in the postal vote covering letter and signs it. Postal voters are obliged to mark the ballot and put it into the ballot envelope personally and in secret and maintaining electoral freedom. The voter must sign an attestation concerning this on the covering letter. Two witnesses must be present when the postal voting takes place. The witnesses must also sign the attestation on the covering letter stating that election secrecy has been preserved and electoral freedom respected while voting. The witnesses must have reached the age of 18. The spouse, child, or parent of the voter or an election candidate or his or her family member cannot be a witness. The witnesses need not be Finnish citizens. At the end of the postal voting, the voter puts the ballot envelope and the covering letter into the covering envelope and seals it. The name and address of the central municipal election board to which the vote will be sent must be visible in the window of the covering envelope. The voter must send the covering envelope, containing the ballot sealed in the ballot envelope and the covering letter, to Finland to the central municipal election board of the municipality in which the voter has the right to vote according to the voter register. The voter is responsible to find out which municipality this is by calling the relevant authorities or if the voter received a polling card, by using the address indicated on it. The voter must put enough postage on the covering envelope (the mailing is not pre-paid). Finally, the voter posts the covering envelope to Finland through the postal service of a foreign country in the same manner as any other postal item.  The voter may also choose to post the envelope as a registered letter or to use an international courier service.

General advance voting in Finland takes place starting the 11th day before the election day and ends on the 5th day before the election day. At a general advance polling station in Finland, the voting takes place at the times determined by a decision of the local executive, which may not be before 8:00 or after 20:00 on weekdays or before 10:00 or after 18:00 on Saturdays and Sundays. A voter who arrives at the advance polling station within the time frame specified but has not been able to cast a vote during that time may vote after the said time.

Every eligible voter may vote in advance at the general advance polling stations in Finland.

There must be at least one general advance polling station located in each municipality in Finland.  In addition, advance voting  is held n hospitals, full-time care facilities, and prisons for one or two days as determined by the electoral commission. Homebound voting also takes place during the advance polling days. The ballot, ballot envelope, covering letter form, and envelope for the covering letter form provided by the Ministry of Justice are used in advance voting.  A voter who wishes to vote in advance shall report to the election official or the electoral commission at the advance polling station. Where necessary, advance voting conducted in an institution is to be organized in different units and patients rooms. The voter is obliged to present a proof of his or her identity to the election official or the electoral commission. Thereafter, he or she is given a ballot, a ballot envelope and a covering envelope and, if needed, a covering letter form.  The voter shall be provided with the opportunity to familiarise himself or herself with the master list of candidates for his or her electoral district. A voter in parliamentary elections has the right to vote for a candidate in the master list of candidates for the electoral district in which the voter is registered.  The voter shall mark the number of the candidate he or she is voting for in the ballot in such a manner that there can be no uncertainty as to whom he or she has voted for. The marking shall be made in the voting booth or somewhere else in a manner that maintains the election secrecy.  A person whose ability to mark the ballot is essentially weakened may request assistance from an election official or member of an electoral commission, or can use the help of an assistant he or she has chosen. A candidate or his or her family member cannot assist voters. The assistant must strictly comply with the directions of the voter and keep secret the choice of the voter. The covering letter,which includes the name and identifying number of the voter, shall be addressed to the central electoral committee of that municipality and is entered in the voting register next to the voter.  The voter shall sign a declaration on the covering letter stating that he or she himself or herself has, maintaining the election secrecy, filled in the ballot and enclosed it stamped in the ballot envelope. The voter shall give the folded ballot to the election official or, in an institution, to the electoral commission to be stamped and, immediately after the ballot is stamped, enclose it in the ballot envelope in front of the election authority. The closed ballot envelope and the signed covering letter are to be given to the election official or the electoral commission. When a voter register is used in the advance polling station, the election official or the chairperson of the electoral commission shall check in the register that the voter has the right to vote, make an entry in the register indicating that the voter has used his or her right to vote, and make a marking on the covering letter indicating that an entry has been made in the voter register. When the voter register is not used at the advance polling station, a list of voters shall be kept. The election official and the electoral commission of a general advance polling station in Finland shall ensure that the covering envelopes addressed to the municipality's own central electoral committee are without delay delivered to the central electoral committee in the manner determined by it.

Proxy voting is not allowed. The voter reports to the election board in the polling station of his or voting district. The voter is obliged to present proof of his or her identity to the electon board, which then must determine that the voter has the right to vote by checking the voter register. The voter receives the ballot and proceeds to the polling booth or, if that is not possible without causing undue difficulty to the voter, somewhere else in a manner that maintains the election secrecy.  A voter in parliamentary elections has the right to vote for a candidate in the master list of candidates for the electoral district in which the voter is registered. The voter marks the number of the candidate he or she is voting for in the ballot in such a manner that there can be no uncertainty as to whom he or she has voted for. A person whose ability to mark the ballot is essentially weakened may request assistance from an eletion official or member of an electoral commission, or can use the help of an assistant he or she has chosen. A candidate or his or her family member cannot assist voters. The assistant must strictly comply with the directions of the voter and keep secret the choice of the voter.The voter then presents the folded ballot paper to the election board in order to be stamped. The stamp is placed in the middle of the reverse side of the folded ballot. The voter then puts the ballot in the ballot box. The electoral board makes a marking in the list of voters, as well as the voter register, indicating that the voter has used his or her right to vote.

campaign_finance.details: All parliamentary parties are eligible for public funding in proportion to the number of seats held. In addition to the funding provided by the parties, election camapign activities can be funded from candidates' own resources, as well as loans and contributions received from individuals and legal entities. For in-kind donations, contestants are obliged to give a voluntary estimate of the donations they include in the financial reports. All contributions received from the same donor should not exceed EUR 6,000 for a candidate and EUR 30,000 for a political party. In addition, each individual campaign contribution and its donor must be disclosed separately, if the value of such a contribution exceeds EUR 1,500. Consent for disclosure is required for donations below EUR 1,500. The legislation does not envisage limits on campaign spending. The National Audit Office (NAO) is tasked with oversight of political party and campaign financing. All political parties and candidates elected to parliament are obliged to submit detailed financial reports to the NAO two months after the electons and annually on their regular financial activities. There are no mandatory requirements for reporting on campaign finances prior to the election day. The NAO is vested with sanctioning powers in situations where required documents or information are not submitted, corrected or completed. The NAO publishes all financial reports online and reports to the parliament on the audits of the campaign finance reports within eight months and on the reports for the regular financial activities of the parties annually.

election_issues: EU cooperation; social/fiscal policy; institutional reform; economy; housing costs

government_functions.details: In Andorra, a parliamentary leader (Cap de Govern) serves as head of government, while two foreign co-princes traditionally share the role of chief of state. The president of France and Bishop of Seu d’Urgell, Spain automatically become co-princes of Andorra upon assuming their primary offices. Each co-prince appoints a local representative. There are no defined terms of office; co-princes reign as long as they maintain their primary offices. The Cap de Govern is indirectly elected by the General Council and confirmed by the co-princes. The Cap de Govern serves 4-year terms.  Andorra's legislature, the unicameral General Council, has 28 members. Half of those members are elected by proportional representation vote in a single, nationwide constituency while the other half are elected by plurality vote in multi-seat constituencies (2 seats for each of 7 parishes). All members serve 4-year terms.  The Andorran judiciary is headed by the Supreme Court of Justice (9 judges) and the Constitutional Court (4 judges). Supreme Court judges are selected by a panel called the Supreme Council of Justice and serve 6-year terms. Constitutional judges are selected by the General Council and the co-princes, and they may serve up to two 8-year terms.

voting_methods.instructions:
Voters who are permanently or temporarily residing abroad may apply  to vote by postal voting. Voters must either be living abroad and appear as such on the final voter list or, despite not being registered in the voter list as residing abroad, can vote from abroad if they prove by documentation that they are studying abroad or doing temporary or professional activity abroad.

Out-of-country postal voting, like in-country in-person early voting is administered by judges. Overseas postal voters must apply by post or online by the established deadline to receive their postal ballots.  The law provides that the government will regulate the form, terms and means to be used to deliver the documents to the postal voters. The government sends to the voters voting packs by registered mail, comprising ballot papers, envelopes, and electoral information, and a pre-addressed return envelope. The postal voter inserts each of the two chosen ballots into each of the two ballot envelopes and closes the envelopes.  These envelopes are then put into the pre-addressed return envelope, sent to the court of first instance in Andorra. The postal voters is to include in the main envelope their certificate of registration on the final voter list and a photocopy of their passport. The envelope is to be closed and the voter is to put their name, address and signature on the back of the envelope. The voter is to return the package in the manner set out in the instructions. The receiving court records the receipt of postal voting packages. At the start of the election day, the judges are responsible to take the voted ballots to the respective polling stations and place them in the ballot boxes. The postal voters are then marked off the voters list at the polling station to prevent multiple voting.

Early voting is adminstered by judges, also called "judicial voting".  Early voters can collect the ballots and envelopes at the respective common house during office hours and deposit the chosen ballots in-person at the courts of first instance. These voters can alter their vote before the election day, with all previous ballots invalidated. At the start of the election day, the judges are responsible to take the marked ballots to the respective polling stations and place them in the ballot boxes. At that time, those who voted in advance are marked as such in the voter lists at the polling stations to prevent multiple voting.

In addition, during the period for early voting, homebound, detained and hospitalized voters may also request to vote at their place of stay. A judge of the court of first instance, accompanied by a court secretary, travels to the requested locations with the necessary materials. A medical certificate is needed for homebound voting.  The above-noted process is not included in the legislation itself but is described in the OSCE/ODIHR Needs Assessment Mission Report, 7 April 2019 Parliamentary Elections, Principality of Andorra.

All voters are entitled to have a paid absence from their workplace for two hours in order to vote. At the parish polling station, which may be divided into more than polling station, the voter must present his/her identification.  The poll worker verifies that the person is registered to vote in that electoral district. Voters can be registered to vote in their parish of residence or parish or origin. Once the identity and registration is verified, the voter receives two envelopes: one for the parish seats and the other for the proportional contest. The voter is to go into one of the ballot booths alone to vote in secret (except persons with disabilities can be accompanied by a person of their choice or the presiding officer to assist in casting the ballot). The voting booth includes an illuminated table or desk on which there will be ballots for each candidate list for both the parish and national elections. In the booth, the voter puts inside each of the two envelopes one chosen ballot paper.  The voter then proceeds to insert the two envelopes inside each of the two ballot boxes. A poll worker counts the number of voters who exercise the right to vote. All voters waiting to vote at the time of closing are allowed to vote.

campaign_finance.details: Parliamentary political parties and groups are entitled to public funding based on the number of votes received and mandates won during the last parliamentary and local elections. After parliamentary elections, the government partially reimburses campaign expenses of each winning candidate list, providing EUR 5 for every vote received and EUR 150 for each MP elected. In addition, each party or group receives an annual representation subsidy of EUR 5,000 if elected on national list, and EUR 1,400 if elected on parish list. Contestants can finance their campaigns from party membership fees and budget allocations, as well as donations made by citizens and residents of Andorra. Private donations, including monetary and in-kind, are limited to EUR 6,000 per person per year. Anonymous and foreign donations, as well as those from legal and public entities and parliamentary groups are prohibited. Campaign spending for a national list cannot exceed EUR 200,0000 plus EUR 0.3 for each voter registered for the elections. Campaign spending for a parish list is limited to EUR 30,000 plus EUR 0.3 for each voter registered in the corresponding parish. All lists are required to open an account through which all donations and expenditures must pass. Each candidate list is required to report on donations, within eight days of their receipt, to the Court of Auditors, the body in charge of finance oversight, which publishes this information within  one month. All contestants have to submit a campaign finance report between 60 and 80 days after the election day. Banks that issued loans for the campaign and entities that provided any campaign services exceeding EUR 10,000 have to report on these to the Court of Auditors. The Electoral Board has access to the campaign bank accounts and is obliged to report within two months after elections on whether contestants complied with the rules. The Court of Auditors publishes an audit report, sends it to the parliament within six months after the elections and validates the right of contestants to receive public funding andr reimbursement for campaign expenses.

election_name.en_US: Antigua and Barbados House of Representatives 2023

election_issues: Food production; health services; high cost of living; inflation; infrastructure; public sector reform; tax system

government_functions.details: Antigua and Barbuda is a member of the British Commonwealth and thus the monarch is hereditary. The monarch appoints a Governor-General. The Prime Minister is appointed by the Governor-General. Per the Constitution, the Prime Minister must be a member of the House of Representatives who has the support of the majority of members of the House and is typically the leader of the ruling coalition or party.   There is a bicameral parliament with a 17-seat Senate that is appointed by the Governor-General and a 17-seat House of Representatives that is directly elected in single-seat constituencies by simple majority vote to serve 5-year terms. There are two ex-officio seats reserved for the attorney general and the speaker of the House, respectively.   The highest court is the Eastern Caribbean Supreme Court (ECSC), which rules over Anguilla, Dominica, Grenada, Saint Vincent, Saint Kitts & Nevis, and Saint Lucia as well. The chief justice of the ECSC is appointed by the British monarchy.

institution.name: Antiguan and Barbudan House of Representatives

voting_methods.instructions: In order to vote, a voter must be registered in the register of electors in that constituency. Employers must provide four hours paid leave for voters to go to their polling station to vote. At their designated polling station, voters are required to present a voter identification card (issued by the Electoral Commission) to a polling official who checks off the name of the voter against the voter register and issues the voter with a ballot paper. Before handing the ballot to the voter, the voter is checked that he or she does not have the black electoral ink on the right index finger. If the voter is refused a ballot due to having such ink on his or her finger, the presiding officer must make an entry in the poll book setting out the facts of the refusal.  The polling official then puts the official stamp on the ballot paper, calls out the number, name and description of the voter as stated in the voter register, and instructs the voter how to fold the ballot. A presiding officer may, and if required by a candidate or polling agent must, put to a voter at the time of applying for a ballot paper specific questions regarding the identity of the voter and whether he or she has already voted. Only if the voter satisfactorily answers the questions, if asked, can he or she be  given a ballot paper. The voter then proceeds to the polling booth to vote in secret. Electors vote by putting a cross on the ballot paper against the name of the candidate they want to represent them (any other mark or comment on the paper renders it invalid), folds the ballot so as to conceal the vote, shows the back of the folded ballot paper to the presiding officer, so as to disclose the official stamp, and then inserts the ballot paper in a sealed box in the presence of the presiding officer. Prior to inserting the ballot in the box, the presiding officer must cause the voter to immerse his or her right index finger in the black electoral ink. If the voter refuses to do so, the presiding officer takes possession of and destroys the ballot paper. A voter who spoils his or her ballot paper can return it to the presiding officer who will issue a new ballot paper if satisified that it was mistakenly spoiled.   Blind voters and those with physical disabilities may be assisted to cast their vote through a regulated procedure. A voter must vote without undue delay and leave the polling station as soon as he or she has inserted the ballot in the box. The law allows proxy voting for those unable or likely to be unable to vote in person at the polling station for reason of providing law enforcement or defence service on election day or working as an election official or polling agent on election day.  Such person wishing to vote by proxy must submit an application not later than three days before election day to be treated as an "absent voter" and provide the name and address of a person within the country whom he or she wishes to act as proxy to him or her. A letter 'p' will be marked beside the voter's name in the voter register and a list of proxies is made for each polling station. At the polling station, a proxy must appear on the list of proxies and show that his or her left index finger does not have red electoral ink on it (different than the black in on the right index finger for regular voters). Upon a proxy receiving the ballot paper, a mark is to be placed by his or her name in the list of proxies. Prior to placing the ballot in the ballot box, a proxy is to immerse his or her left index finger in the indelible red ink. Election officials and polling agents may, in the alternative, apply in advance to be "transferred" to vote at the polling station to which they are assigned, in which case they are issued a transfer certificate. If a person who appears on the voter register or on a proxy list applies for a ballot paper after another person has voted in person either as the elector or proxy, the applicant is entitled to vote a "tendered ballot" provided he or she satisfactorily answers questions regarding his or her identity and whether he or she has already voted. Any marked tendered ballot is separately packaged and the name and electoral number of the voter recorded.

campaign_finance.details: Political parties do not receive public funding. Parties must keep records of all monetary and in-kind donations received during an election and the name and address of any entity or person whose donation exceeds $25,000.  Donations above that amount are prohibited unless the party can identify the source to the Electoral Commission. Every political party that had a candidate elected must, within six weeks after the announcement of the election results, file a report of the donations it received to the Electoral Commission. The Electoral Commission has authority to access and examine the records and audited accounts of the political parties in connection with campaign finances and to receive any requested information about the campaign donations received. Within six months of an election, every political party must have its accounts audited.The Electoral Commission shall impose a $2,000  penalty per day on any party or organization who fails to comply with these requirements The legislation does not include limits on the total amount that a party or candidate is permitted to spend in an electoral campaign and there is no requirement to publicly disclose the sources of funding for campaigns.

government_functions.details: The President of Bulgaria serves as the chief of state, while the Prime Minister is the head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority popular vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is indirectly elected by the National Assembly.  Bulgaria has a unicameral National Assembly (Народно събрание / Narodno Sabranie) with 240 seats. Members of the National Assembly are directly elected by proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies and serve 4-year terms. Parties and coalitions must earn at least 4% of the overall vote to receive a seat.   The high courts of Bulgaria consist of the Supreme Court of Cassation (penal, civil, and commercial legal matters), the Supreme Administrative Court (national government matters), and the Constitutional Court. Cassation and administrative judges are elected by the Supreme Judicial Council (SJC) and confirmed by the President. These judges can serve until age 65. The Constitutional Court is independent of the judiciary branch, and its 12 justices are elected by the National Assembly and confirmed by the President and SJC. Constitutional Court justices serve 9-year terms, and one-third of justices are replaced every 3 years.

voting_methods.instructions: Voting is compulsory but there is no sanction for not voting.  Voters vote in person at their designated polling station (though candidates, higher level election officials, and observers can apply for a certificate to vote at any polling station within the respective constitutency). Secrecy of the vote is guaranteed. On arrival at the polling station, voters show their identity card, or in certain cases, their internal passport. The poll worker checks the voter's particulars against the voter register and enters the identity number and type of document shown into the voter register and admits the voter to voting. Any discrepancy in the name shown in the identification document and the voter register, if the permanent address matches, is recorded in the voter register.  If the voter is not found on the voter register he/she can be added to a supplemental list, with proof of residence in the district, and is allowed to vote upon submitting a declaration (to be attached to the voter register) that he/she has not voted and will not vote elsewhere. The law provides for the use of both paper ballot voting and direct recording electronic voting machines, at the voter's option. In past elections, such machines were used on  a limited basis as it was not mandatory and due to limited resources and technical expertise, but a 2020 amendment to the election law now mandates that voters have the option of either paper or machine-based voting. If paper voting, the voter is given a  ballot that is stamped by the poll worker with the commission's seal. The voter proceeds to the voting booth and in private marks the square of the candidate list of his/her choice and if so wishes, also marks the circle of the candidate of his/her choice. The voter folds the ballot to keep the vote secret, exits the booth and hands the folded ballot to the poll worker who checks whether the number on the ballot matches the number on the book of ballots and if so, restamps the ballot with the seal of the commission and detaches the counterfoil and deposits it in a separate box. The voter then deposits the ballot in the ballot box, signs the voter register, and his/her identification document is given back and he/she leaves the polling site.  If the voter has spoiled the ballot, he/she can return it folded to the poll worker and a replacement ballot will be issued (only once.) In machine voting, the voter is given access to the voting device and votes by means of a magnetic card, with the device displaying a ballot identical to the paper ballot, as well as an option to vote 'against all'. After voting for the candidate list and if he/she chooses, also for a candidate on the list, he/she can change the choice once before confirming to vote. The voter receives a message that the voting is completed and a control receipt is printed which is to be deposited in a special machine voting box.The voter then returns the magnetic card, signs the voter register, and is given back his/her identification document and leaves the polling site. The fact that the voter voted by machine is noted in the voter register. If the machine voting becomes inoperable, voting proceeds by paper ballots. Mobile (homebound) voting is available for voters with permanent disabililities, based on an advance request before polling day.  The mobile voting is carried out by not less than four poll workers on election day.

government_functions.details: The President of the Maldives serves as both chief of state and head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and serves up to two 5-year terms.   The Maldives has a unicameral legislature: the People's Assembly. All 87 members are directly elected by plurality vote in single-seat constituencies and serve 5-year terms.  The Supreme Court is the highest court of the Maldivian judiciary. The Supreme Court is composed of 7 justices who are nominated by the President and confirmed by the People's Assembly. Justices may serve until age 70.

election_issues: Unemployment; COVID-19 pandemic; Government's foreign worker policy and free trade agreements; goods and services tax (GST); Inflation; Violence against women

institution.name: Singaporean Presidency
institution.term_details: Part 5, Section 20(1) of the Constitution of the Republic of Singapore

voting_methods.instructions: Any poll (including an advance poll) at an overseas polling station must be conducted in the same manner as that in which voting at a polling station within Singapore on polling day is conducted.  The hours of any poll at an overseas polling station for any contested election must be not less than 4 hours and may start in advance of the poll on polling day in Singapore, except that every such poll at an overseas polling station must close not later than the close of the poll on polling day in Singapore.

Voting by post or at an overseas polling station are meant for Singaporeans residing overseas only and does not include local Singaporeans who happen to be overseas on Polling Day, such as those on overseas vacation. An overseas voter may vote by post by registering via Elections Department's online Voter Services using Singpass and must upload his/her wet-ink signature during registration. He/she may download and print a postal ballot paper and return envelope the day after Nomination Day.  Voting by post is done by marking, folding, and inserting the postal ballot paper in the return envelope. Thereafter, the voter must seal and sign on the return envelope and post the same to Returning Officer in Singapore. Note that return envelopes containing the postal ballot papers must be postmarked before Polling Day and reach the custody of the Returning Officer in Singapore within 10 days after Polling Day in Singapore to be accepted for counting.

The voter, on receiving the ballot paper, shall immediately proceed to such place in the station as may be indicated by the presiding officer shall secretly mark the paper; voter’s mark on the ballot paper must be made in the area demarcated on the ballot paper for that purpose, and not elsewhere;  fold the paper so as to conceal his vote, and shall put the paper so folded up into the ballot box.

campaign_finance.details: Any candidate at any election or any of his or her election agents, who will have expenses in excess of the maximum amount of $600,000 or an amount equal to 30 cents for each elector on the registers, whichever is the greater, whether before, during, or after an election, on account of or in respect of the conduct or management of the election, shall be guilty of an illegal practice.

election_commission_historical_context: Post Independence – 1980-2004  After independence in 1980, the new government of Zimbabwe introduced a democratic, non-racist electoral system based upon universal adult suffrage. A new electoral management structure was established consisting of the Delimitation Commission, responsible for the delimitation of electoral districts, and the Electoral Supervisory Commission (ESC), charged with supervising the conduct of elections. The management of elections was done at this stage by the Registrar-General of Elections under the supervision of the ESC. The Registrar-General registered voters and compiled voter registers, conducted the voting process and the counting and collation of votes, and announced the results of the election. The Election Directorate provided logistical support to the Registrar-General in the management of the electoral process.  2004 Restructuring  In 2004 the electoral management system was re-structured. This re-structuring was based on recommendations by the Electoral Supervisory Commission, by the political parties and by civil society organisations. The reforms also took account of the Principles and Guidelines Governing Democratic Elections adopted by the SADC Heads of State and Governments in Mauritius in 2004. The Zimbabwe Electoral Commission (ZEC) was then established as an independent body in line with the recommendation in the SADC Principles and Guidelines Governing Democratic Elections that elections should be run by an independent management body and not by a government department like that of the Registrar-General.  The Electoral Supervisory Commission was then abolished in 2005 by Constitutional Amendment No. 17. ZEC became the body responsible for running elections and this function was no longer performed by the Registrar-General. To reflect the new system, the title of the Registrar-General of Elections was changed to that of the Registrar-General of Voters. The function of the Registrar-General of Voters in relation to elections was now only to register voters under the supervision of ZEC. ZEC was responsible for compiling voters rolls and providing copies of these rolls to those requesting them.  The Present ZEC  ZEC was constituted in terms of Chapter 12 Section 238 of the Constitution of Zimbabwe. There are nine Commissioners, who hold office for a term of six years. There is a Chairperson and a Deputy-Chairperson both of whom are appointed on a full time basis. Four of the eight Commissioners other than the Chairperson must be women.  The Chairperson is appointed by the President after consultation with the Judicial Service Commission and the Parliamentary Committee on Standing Rules and Orders. The Chairperson must be a judge or former judge of the Supreme Court or the High Court, or a person qualified for appointment as such the other eight members are appointed by the President from a list of not fewer than twelve nominees submitted by the Parliamentary Committee on Standing Rules and Orders.  In respect of the eight Commissioners appointed under this new system, the Parliamentary Committee on Standing Rules and Orders first invites applications for these posts. It then shortlists applicants. The shortlisted applicants are subjected to a vigorous public interview process by a panel of Parliamentarians. The Constitution provisions requires that Commissioners be chosen “for their integrity and their experience and competence in the conduct of affairs in the public or private sector.”

government_functions.details: The head of state and government is the president, who is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds. The president can serve no more than two 5-year terms. The president is assisted by two vice presidents.  The parliament consists of the National Assembly and the Senate. The National Assembly normally has 210 members, all of whom are directly elected. For the first two parliaments elected after the promulgation of the 2013 constitution, however, the National Assembly has 270 seats, with the 60 additional seats reserved for women—6 from each of the 8 provinces and the 2 cities with provincial status—elected through a system of proportional representation. The Senate comprises 80 members: 60 (6 from each of the 8 provinces and the 2 cities with provincial status) elected by a party-list system of proportional representation, with men and women being listed alternately on every list; 16 traditional chiefs elected by the provincial assemblies of chiefs in the 8 provinces; 2 seats for the president and deputy president of the National Council of Chiefs (the administrative body of traditional chiefs); and 2 representatives of people with disabilities. All parliament members serve five-year terms.  The highest courts of the Zimbabwean judiciary are the Supreme Court (5 judges) and Constitutional Court (7 judges). Supreme Court judges may serve until age 70, while Constitutional Court judges serve a single 15-year term.  Judges from both courts are appointed by the President.

institution.term_details: Art 91 Constitution 2. A person is disqualified for election as President or Vice-President if he or she has already held office as President under this Constitution for two terms, whether continuous or not, and for the purpose of this subsection three or more years' service is deemed to be a full term.

voting_methods.instructions: PART XIV  POSTAL VOTING  [Part XIV (sections 71 – 80) substituted by Act 3 of 2012]  71 Interpretation in Part XIV  The reference in section 73(2)(b)(ii) to a “letter” includes a reference to a letter sent by way of elec- tronic mail, under the following conditions—      (a)  thesender(thatis,thepersonreferredtoin73(2)(b)(ii)(A)or(B)andrecipient(thatis,theappli- cant for a postal vote) must both use official electronic mail addresses; and      (b)  theelectronicmailsentbysendermustbeauthenticatedbytheelectronicsignatureofthesender; and      (c)  theelectronicmailmustbeembodiedinahardcopyprintedbytherecipient,whichcopyshallbe the “letter” referred to in 73(2)(b)(ii).     72 Personswhomayvotebypost  Where an election is to be held in a constituency, a person who is registered as a voter on the roll for that constituency shall be entitled to vote by post in terms of this Part if, on all polling days in the election, he or she will be—      (a)  on duty as a member of a disciplined force or as an electoral officer; or      (b)  on duty in the service of the Government outside Zimbabwe; or      (c)  outside Zimbabwe as the spouse of a person referred to in paragraph (b);     and so unable to vote at a polling station in the constituency.  For cut offs, see articles 73-79 Electoral Act

57 Mannerofvoting  The voting at an election shall be by ballot which shall be conducted in substance and as nearly as pos- sible in the following manner—      (a)  every ballot paper shall be in the form prescribed and there shall be printed on every ballot pa- per—         (i)  in type of equal size, the names of all the duly nominated candidates at the election in alphabetical order of surnames; and         (ii)  the symbols, if any, specified by the duly nominated candidates at the election in terms of paragraph (b) of subsection (1) of section forty-six, each printed to a size that permits the vertical extremities or the horizontal extremities or both such extremities to touch oppo- site sides of the appropriate square on the ballot paper; and         (iii)  in capital letters of equal size, the abbreviation of every political party for which a duly nominated candidate at the election is standing or which is sponsoring such a candidate, where the candidate concerned specified the abbreviation in his or her nomination paper in terms of paragraph (c) of subsection (1) of section forty-six; and         (iv)  a passport-sized photograph of the candidate; and [Subparagraph amended by Act 17 of 2007]         (v)  such other particulars as may be prescribed;           (b)  beforetheballotpaperishandedtotheapplicant,thepresidingofficershallmarktheballotpaper   with the official mark;      (c)  when the person claiming the vote has received the ballot paper he or she shall—         (i)  take the paper to the compartment provided for the purpose; and         (ii)  then signify the candidate for whom he or she desires to vote by secretly placing a cross    in the rectangle opposite the name of that candidate or, if there is more than one such rec-    tangle, in the rectangle nearest to the right-hand side of the ballot paper; and         (iii)  then fold the ballot paper so that the official mark is visible and the names of the candi- dates and the cross made by him or her are not visible and drop the ballot paper in the bal-    lot box placed in front of the presiding officer:   Provided that, if he or she has spoilt the ballot paper, he or she may return it to the    presiding officer in terms of section fifty-eight and shall deal with the second ballot paper given to him or her in accordance with this paragraph.

government_functions.details:
Slovakia is a parliamentary republic. The President is the chief of state and is directly elected by an absolute majority popular vote in two rounds if necessary. The President must be nominated by no less than 15 member of the National Council, per the Constitution. The President selects the Prime Minister (typically, the leader of the winning party or coalition). The Prime Minster must win a vote of confidence in the National Council prior to being officially confirmed. 

Parliament consists of the unicameral National Council. The Council has 150 seats, all of which are directly elected to serve four-year terms. 

The judiciary is comprised of the Supreme Court of the Slovak Republic and the Constitutional Court of the Slovak Republic.

voting_methods.instructions: A special voter register of voters who do not have permanent residence in Slovakia is maintained by the Ministry of Interior. Out of country voters must submit an application, in writing or electronically, to the Ministry of Interior (for non-permanent residents) or to the municipality of permanent residence (for permanent residents) no later than 50 days before the polling day to receive a by-mail ballot. The Ministry or municipality must mail the ballot to the voter at least 35 days before the polling day. A secrecy envelope is provided with the ballot and guidance on how to vote.  All mail-in ballots must be received by the Ministry or municipality at the latest by the last working day before the polling day. By-mail voters temporarily out of country are marked on the voter register as having voted by postal vote.

No proxy voting allowed, identity card or other card proving identity required, ballot paper with envelope given to voter, voter signs voter list before voting, must vote in the polling booth, votes for a political party and may vote for up to four candidates on the party list, replacement of spoilt ballot papers allowed, ballot (envelope) placed by voter in ballot box, physically disabled voter or voter who cannot read or write can be assisted by another voter (not by commission members) , mobile (home) voting for health reasons is available, secrecy of vote guaranteed. Voters can apply before election day for a  certificate that allows them to be registered and to vote in any polling district if they are not able to vote in the polling district where they are registered (upon issuing the voter certificate the voter is deleted from their own voter register).

voting_methods.instructions: (1) Each voter shall, subject to the provisions of section 82, receive from the presiding officer a ballot paper on which such officer has previously put his or her initials so placed as indicated in the form set out as Form No. 11 in the Second Schedule that when the ballot paper is folded the said initials can be seen without opening it, and on the counterfoil of which he or she has placed a number corresponding to the consecutive number on the official list of voters and entered in the poll book opposite the name of such voter. [Amended by Act 11/1971] (2) The presiding officer shall instruct the voter how to make his or her mark, and shall properly fold the voter’s ballot paper, directing him or her to return it, when marked, folded as shown, but without inquiring or seeing for whom the voter intends to vote, except when the voter is unable to vote in the manner prescribed by this Act on account of illiteracy, blindness or other physical incapacity. (3) The voter, on receiving the ballot paper, shall forthwith enter one of the polling compartments in the polling station and there mark his ballot paper by marking with a black lead pencil and not otherwise a cross within the space opposite the name and symbol of the candidate for whom he or she intends to vote, and he or she shall then fold the ballot paper as directed so that the initials and the numbers on the counterfoil can be seen without opening it, and hand the paper to the presiding officer who shall, without unfolding it, ascertain by examination of the initials and the number appearing thereon that it is the same paper as that delivered to the voter and, if the same, he or she shall, subject to section 83, in full view of the voter and of all others present remove the counterfoil and deposit the ballot in the ballot box. [Amended by Act 11/1971] (4) A voter who has inadvertently so dealt with the ballot paper delivered to him or her that it cannot conveniently be used shall restore it to the presiding officer who shall cancel it by writing the word “Spoiled” across the face of the same, and the presiding officer shall then deliver another ballot paper to the voter. (5) Every voter shall vote without undue delay and shall leave the polling station as soon as his or her ballot paper has been put into the ballot box. (6) If at the closing of the poll there are any voters inside the polling station who are qualified to vote and have not been able to do so since their arrival at the polling station, the poll shall be kept open a sufficient time to enable them to vote, but no one not actually present within the polling station at the hour of closing shall be allowed to vote. [Previously section 70] 79. National identification cards and questions to be put to a voter. (1) The presiding officer at the time any person applies for a ballot paper, but not afterwards, (a) shall request that person to produce his or her national identification card; and (b) may, and if requested by a candidate or his or her agent, put to the voter the following questions: (i) are you the same person whose name appears as “A.B.” in the register of voters now in force for this polling division?; (ii) have you already voted at this election either here or elsewhere. (2) Subject to subsection (3), a ballot paper shall not be issued to any person who (a) does not produce his or her national identification card when required to do so under subsection (1)(a); and (b) does not satisfactorily answer the questions asked of him or her under subsection (1)(b). (3) A ballot paper shall be issued to any person whose name appears in the register of voters and who is unable to produce his or her national identification card, if he or she satisfies the presiding officer that (a) a national identification card has not been delivered to him or her; (b) the national identification card delivered to him or her is lost or destroyed; or (c) he or she has been duly registered to vote and his or her particulars appear on Form 3A; and that he or she is the same person whose name appears in the register of voters by producing a valid passport or other Government issued photo identification card.

voting_methods.instructions: Out-of-country voting at diplomatic missions and consular posts is available to citizens who do not reside in Lithuania but are entitled to vote in the elections; they are entered in electoral rolls for the constituency in the territory where the parliament is situated and can vote for a designated period not less than 10 days, and ending on polling day Lithuania time. Voters who are aboard a ship and will not be able to return to Lithuania to vote, are entered on the electoral roll of the polling district on whose electoral roll the ship's crew is entered, and can vote on the ship.

There is no general postal voting; the term postal voting is used to describe special mobile "post offices" which are available to voters who are in healthcare institutions, social care or guardianship institutions because of their health condition or age, voters who perform mandatory military service or who perform active military service, civil service or work under contract in international military operatons abroad, or voters who are in detention facilities. Postal voting is possible at these mobile post offices on the last Wednesday, Thursday or Friday before an election day.  Posting voting envelopes are also used for advance voters (those unable to be go to vote on election day) and home voters; the election committee is to hand the sealed envelopes from advance and home voting to the postal worker. who seals it with a special lable and gives the voter a receipt.

The head of an appropriate post office is responsible for organizing voting by post. The chairman of the electoral committee of the polling district on the territory where a post office is situated is responsible for organizing the supervision over the post office work related to postal voting. The responsible chairpersons are to organize the members of the polling district electoral committees to work during voting in special post officers. The head of the post office with the consent of the constituency electoral committee appoints postal workers for the issue and collection during postal voting of ballot papers and postal voting envelopes. Commanders of military units deployed abroad are responsible for organizing postal voting in those military units. Postal voting for voters in military units deployed abroad is to be conducted in accordance with the procedure laid down by the central election commission, on the recommendation of the Minister of National Defence. Expenses related to postal voting are covered by the state budget. The institutions where postal voting takes place must have a place where voters can, without interference and in secret, mark the ballots and place them into a voting envelope. The postal worker issues the election documents to a voter in accordance with a procedure established by the central election commission. A covering envelope for voting by post is to be addressed by the postal worker to the polling district electoral committee which is indicated on the person's poll card.  An entry on the poll card concerning the issuance of the ballot paper should be made and the card returns to the voter.  After marking the ballot in secret, the voter is to insert the ballot paper into a sealed envelope and then insert the sealed envelope and the polling card into the covering envelope for voting by post which is then sealed and handed to the postal worker who should seal the envelope with a special label and give the voter a receipt.

Generally voters are to vote in the polling district where their name is on the voter list; must show a passport or other identification document or otherwise two citizens on the voter list of the polling district must bear witness in writing to the voter's identity;  proxy voting is prohibited; if entered on voter list voter is given an arrival card; if an electronic voter register is used the arrival of the voter will be entered on it; upon giving arrival card to ballot issuer, voter and ballot issuer sign voter roll; voter is handed two ballot papers; voter must vote in polling booth and personally put ballots in ballot box; a spoilt ballot paper can be replaced on request by voter; assisted voting for disabled voters is allowed by another voter (not poll workers, observers, or partisan representatives) and home (mobile) voting is available on request for persons with disabilities. Secrecy of the vote is guaranteed.

For early voting, a constituency electoral committee organizes the voting on the designated advance voting days in the premises arranged beforehand and suitable for voting in the building housing the workplace of the mayor of the municipality in the territory of which the constituency is located. If a constituency comprises the territories of several municipalities, early voting is to be organized in all those municipalities. For handing out and accepting ballot papers and envelopes in advance voting, the chairman of the constituency electoral committee appoints not less than two members of a constituency electoral committee or district electoral committee who may not be proposed by the same political party. Advance voting is supervised by the chairman of a constituency electoral committee, or upon his instruction, a member of the committee. When voting in advance, an entry is to be made on the poll card concerning the issue of the ballot papers and the poll card shall be returned to the voter; a voter shall vote in person and in secret, mark the ballot papers; put the marked ballot papers into the ballot paper envelope; seal the ballot paper envelope; place the ballot paper envelope together with the poll card into the covering envelope for voting by post, and seal the covering envelope for voting by post.  The sealed envelope should be given to the election committee/postal worker which should seal the envelope with a special label and give the voter a receipt.

government_functions.details: The President of Ecuador serves as both head of government and head of state.  The president is directly elected by plurality of at least 40% and a 10% differential to the runner-up vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two consecutive 4-year terms.  The National Assembly shall be comprised of Fifteen (15) Assembly persons elected as representatives of the nation as a whole (national district). Two (2) Assembly persons elected for each province, plus one (1) additional Assembly person for every two hundred thousand (200,000) inhabitants or fraction thereof over one hundred fifty thousand (150,000), on the basis of the last national population census.  The jurisdictional bodies, without detriment to the other bodies with equal powers recognized in the Constitution, are those in charge of administering justice and they shall be as follows: The National Court of Justice. The provincial courts of justice. The courts and tribunals provided for by law. The justices of the peace.

voting_methods.instructions: A home voter shall choose one candidate (referring to one political party in cases of an election of proportional representative National Assembly members or an election of proportional representative local council members), put a mark in the corresponding column of the balloting paper received from the competent Gu/Si/Gun election commission, put the ballot paper into the envelope for return, seal the envelope, and then dispatch the envelope by registered mail.

An elector shall go, in person, to an advance polling station, and shall present his/her resident registration card in the presence of voting witnesses, and shall, after the identification is confirmed, affix his/her signature or seal or thumbmark to the electoral register, and then shall receive a ballot paper. After receiving the ballot paper, shall enter a balloting booth, select one candidate (referring to one political party in the election of the proportional representative National Assembly members and the election of the proportional representative local council members), from among those entered in the ballot paper, make a mark in the corresponding column of the ballot paper, fold the ballot paper on the spot so that other persons can not see the contents, and then put it in the ballot box in the presence of the voting witnesses.

An elector shall go, in person, to a polling station, and shall present his/her resident registration card in the presence of voting witnesses, and shall, after the identification is confirmed, affix his/her signature or seal or thumbmark to the electoral register, and then shall receive a ballot paper. After receiving the ballot paper, shall enter a balloting booth, select one candidate (referring to one political party in the election of the proportional representative National Assembly members and the election of the proportional representative local council members), from among those entered in the ballot paper, make a mark in the corresponding column of the ballot paper, fold the ballot paper on the spot so that other persons can not see the contents, and then put it in the ballot box in the presence of the voting witnesses.

voting_methods.instructions: Here are the steps for casting your ballot: 1. Show your Electoral Card/National ID card to the Polling Clerk. 2. The Polling Clerk checks that there is no stamp for this election on your Electoral Card. 3. The Polling Clerk looks for your name on the Electoral Roll and checks your name on both new (VES list) and old electoral roll (GVRS list). 4. When the Polling Clerk has found your name and has checked your identity, he or she will place a tick next to your name and number – make sure you are included successfully in the new Electoral Roll based on National ID registration, as this roll will be the only one to be used in future elections! 5. The Polling Clerk will give you an envelope and a booklet containing a ballot paper for each candidate. 6. Go to the Voting booth. – People with disabilities who cannot get to the polling booth or cast their ballot on their own can appoint a person to help them. This person must be a registered voter. 7. Look through the candidate booklet carefully and find the ballot paper of the person you want to vote for. You can find it easily by looking for their photo or their symbol. 8. Put the ballot paper of the candidate you want to vote for into the envelope and come out of the Voting booth. 9. Show the Polling Clerk that you have one envelope only. Throw away the left-over ballot papers in the closed bin outside the voting booths, or where the Polling Clerk tells you. 10. Put your envelope into the ballot box. 11. The polling Clerk stamps your Electoral Card with the official government stamp in the place that says “Date of Voting”. They add the date and sign. 12. Give the Polling Clerk your left thumb and get it inked. 13. Take your Electoral Card back. 14. Leave the Polling station

voting_methods.instructions: After voter registration, the ballot will be stamped with the elections stamp and the Supervisory Board stamp by the official responsible for registration and the Supervisory Board monitor, respectively. After separating [the ballot from the registration paper], the ballot will be returned to the voter. After obtaining the ballot, the voter will write on the ballot the first and last name and other specifics of his or her preferred candidate or candidates. In case the first and last names of the candidates have already been printed on the ballot, the voter will place a mark in front of the names of his/her preferred candidates, and after dropping the ballot in the ballot box, will leave through the exit door of the voting station. Needless to say, the election registration papers and the special supervisory section [of the ballot] will be kept after being stamped under the joint observation of the voting station staff and supervisors of the Guardian Council.

voting_methods.instructions: Election Law 1982, 15. Ballot papers: (1) The ballot of every voter shall consist of a ballot paper and the names of the persons shown in the statement of persons validly nominated as candidates, and no other person shall be entitled to have his name inserted in the ballot paper. (2) A ballot paper shall be in Form 7 in the Appendix and shall be printed in accordance with the directions therein and shall - (a)contain the names alphabetically arranged according to surnames and numbered accordingly and other particulars of the candidates as shown in the statement ofthe persons nominated. Opposite to the name of each candidate there shall be printed one of the symbols as are specified in Form 8 in the Appendix which shall be allotted by the Supervisor of Elections; (b) be capable of being folded; (c)have a space provided on the face of the ballot for the initials of the presiding officer; (d)have attached a counterfoil and a stub, and a line or perforations between the ballot and the counterfoil and between the counterfoil and the stub, the whole as in Form 7 in the Appendix. 16. Official mark: (1) Every ballot paper shall be marked with an official mark, which shall be either stamped or perforated. (2) The official mark shall be kept secret and an interval of not less than seven years shall intervene between the use of the same official mark at elections in the same polling division. 17. Prohibition of disclosure of vote: No person who has voted at the election shall, in any legal proceedings to question the election or return, be required to state for whom he voted.
