voting_methods.instructions: Art. 63 : Le scrutin est ouvert à huit (8) heures et clos le même jour à dix-neuf (19) heures.      Toutefois, la CENI peut, pour faciliter aux électeurs l’exercice de leur droit de vote, avancer l’heure d’ouverture ou retarder l’heure de la clôture dans certaines circonscriptions électorales.   Dans tous les cas, les opérations du vote doivent se dérouler dans un intervalle de temps de onze (11) heures précises.   Les électeurs présents devant le bureau de vote doivent voter. A cet effet, à l’heure officielle de clôture, le Président du bureau de vote fait ramasser les cartes des électeurs en commençant par le dernier de la file en attente, et seuls ceux-ci sont autorisés à voter, mention en est faite au procès-verbal.   Un arrêté du Président de la CENI précise les modalités d’application de ces dispositions.   Art. 64 (Loi n° 2019-38 du 18 juillet 2019) : Nul ne peut être admis à voter s’il ne justifie de son identité.   La carte d’électeur biométrique est l’unique document de vérification de l’identité de l’électeur.   Le vote par témoignage est interdit.   Art. 65 (Loi n° 2019-38 du 18 juillet 2019) : Les électeurs inscrits sur la liste d’une même circonscription électorale, lorsqu’ils changent de résidence à l’intérieur de cette dernière, sont autorisés à voter dans le bureau de vote de leur nouvelle résidence, sur présentation de leur carte d’électeur biométrique.         Leurs noms sont ajoutés sur la liste des électeurs votants.   Dans le cas d’espèce, l’électeur doit justifier par un récépissé de changement de résidence délivré et authentifié par la CENI locale ou la Commission administrative de son ressort.   Art. 66 : Pour les élections législatives, les candidats déclarés éligibles par la Cour constitutionnelle sont autorisés à voter dans l’un des bureaux de vote du ressort de la circonscription électorale dans laquelle ils se portent candidats sur présentation de leur carte d’électeur biométrique.   Art. 67 : Les membres du bureau de vote régulièrement inscrits sur une liste électorale peuvent voter dans le bureau de vote où ils ont été nommés quelle que soit l’élection.   Les délégués détenteurs d’un mandat votent dans le bureau où ils ont été désignés pour leur mission.   Les personnes chargées d’assurer la sécurité des bureaux de votes sont autorisées à voter dans lesdits bureaux sur présentation de leur carte d’électeur biométrique.   Les agents des forces de défense et de sécurité, les membres et le personnel de la CENI et de ses démembrements, les membres et les délégués de la Cour constitutionnelle, les observateurs nationaux et les délégués des partis politiques sont autorisés à voter dans l’un des bureaux de vote de la circonscription électorale dans laquelle ils sont en mission, sur présentation de leur carte d’électeur biométrique, de leur mandat ou de leur Ordre de mission.      Le président du bureau de vote est tenu de leur faciliter le vote.   Dans tous les cas, mention du vote doit être faite au procès-verbal avec l’ensemble des caractéristiques de la carte d’électeur.   Art. 68 : Le vote est personnel et secret.   Le choix de l’électeur est libre.   Nul ne doit être influencé dans son choix par la contrainte, la menace ou la violence.   Le vote a lieu dans les bureaux désignés par la CENI.   Art. 69 : Le vote se fait au moyen d’un bulletin unique, à mettre dans l’urne par l’électeur.   Tout électeur atteint d’infirmité ou de handicap physique le mettant dans l’impossibilité d’introduire son bulletin dans l’urne est autorisé à se faire assister par un électeur de son choix ou par un membre du bureau de vote.      Art. 75 (Loi n° 2019-38 du 18 juillet 2019) : A son entrée dans le bureau de vote, l’électeur porteur de sa carte d’électeur biométrique ou de la preuve de son droit de voter par la production d’une décision du Président du Tribunal d’Instance, après avoir fait constater qu’aucune de ses mains ne porte d’empreinte et de trace d’encre indélébile, prend lui- même un bulletin unique mis à sa disposition. Le président ou un membre du bureau de vote lit à haute et intelligible voix les noms et prénoms de l’électeur qui s’apprête à voter. Celui-ci, sans quitter le bureau de vote exprime son choix. Cette opération doit se faire dans l’isoloir.   Il fait ensuite constater au président qu’il n’est porteur que d’un seul bulletin unique qu’il introduit lui-même dans l’urne.   Art. 76 : Le vote par procuration est exceptionnel ; il n’est admis qu’en cas d’incapacité physique ou d’empêchement majeur.   Sont déclarées valables les seules procurations établies par les présidents des commissions électorales locales conformément au modèle défini par la CENI.   Tout électeur mandaté pour voter par procuration doit être muni de la carte d’électeur et de la pièce d’identification de la personne qui l’a mandaté.         Le mandataire doit être inscrit dans le même bureau de vote que le mandant. Il ne peut être détenteur que d’une seule procuration.   La procuration doit être établie en deux (2) exemplaires dont l’un sera remis au mandant et l’autre classé dans les archives de la Commission locale des élections.   Elle doit être numérotée et enregistrée dans un registre spécial.   Toute procuration ne respectant pas les prescriptions du présent article est nulle.   A l’issue du dépouillement, les procurations sont jointes aux bulletins nuls, tels que prévus à l’article 88 ci-dessous et transmis à la juridiction compétente.   Art. 77 : Le vote de chaque électeur est constaté par son identification tel que prévue par l’article 75 ci-dessus, puis par sa signature ou son empreinte digitale apposée sur la liste d’émargement en face de son nom.   De plus, le vote de l’électeur est constaté par l’imprégnation de son pouce gauche à l’encre indélébile.   Tout électeur détenteur d’une procuration dûment mandatée doit procéder aux deux (2) opérations avant de passer son pouce à l’encre indélébile.       L’électeur atteint d’une infirmité le privant de son index ou de son pouce peut apposer l’empreinte de tout autre doigt sur la liste d’émargement. S’il ne dispose d’aucun doigt, la personne qui l’assiste est autorisée par le président de bureau de vote à apposer l’empreinte de son index.      Art. 78 : Dès la clôture du scrutin, la liste d’émargement est signée par tous les membres du bureau de vote.   Cette liste d’émargement est tenue à la disposition de tout électeur qui désire la consulter à la Circonscription électorale, pendant un délai de huit (8) jours à partir de la proclamation des résultats provisoires.

https://aceproject.org/ero-en/regions/africa/CG/congo-brazzaville-electoral-law-amendments-2016/view  Article 93 nouveau : Après son entrée dans le bu- reau de vote et après avoir prouvé son identité et fait constater son inscription sur la liste électo- rale, l’électeur prend le bulletin unique de vote et se rend dans l’isoloir pour y faire,à l’abri du public, le choix de son candidat.      Après avoir coché dans la case réservée à côté du nom du candidat de son choix ou après y avoir apposé son index droit trempé dans de l’encre indélébile au cas où il ne sait ni lire ni écrire, l’électeur s’approche du président du bureau de vote, lui fait constater qu’il n’est porteur que d’un seul bulletin qu’il introduit lui- même dans l’urne.      Article 93-1 nouveau : Après avoir voté, l’électeur fait constater son vote par la signature ou l’apposition de son index droit sur la liste d’émargement en face de ses nom et prénom.   Il trempe ensuite son index droit dans l’encre indé- lébile jusqu’à hauteur de l’ongle. Cette formalité est accomplie devant les membres du bureau de vote.

Sous-section 2 : Des modalités de vote   Art. 63 : Le scrutin est ouvert à huit (8) heures et clos le même jour à dix-neuf (19) heures.         Toutefois, la CENI peut, pour faciliter aux électeurs l’exercice de leur droit de vote, avancer l’heure d’ouverture ou retarder l’heure de la clôture dans certaines circonscriptions électorales.   Dans tous les cas, les opérations du vote doivent se dérouler dans un intervalle de temps de onze (11) heures précises.   Les électeurs présents devant le bureau de vote doivent voter. A cet effet, à l’heure officielle de clôture, le Président du bureau de vote fait ramasser les cartes des électeurs en commençant par le dernier de la file en attente, et seuls ceux-ci sont autorisés à voter, mention en est faite au procès-verbal.   Un arrêté du Président de la CENI précise les modalités d’application de ces dispositions.   Art. 64 (Loi n° 2019-38 du 18 juillet 2019) : Nul ne peut être admis à voter s’il ne justifie de son identité.   La carte d’électeur biométrique est l’unique document de vérification de l’identité de l’électeur.   Le vote par témoignage est interdit.   Art. 65 (Loi n° 2019-38 du 18 juillet 2019) : Les électeurs inscrits sur la liste d’une même circonscription électorale, lorsqu’ils changent de résidence à l’intérieur de cette dernière, sont autorisés à voter dans le bureau de vote de leur nouvelle résidence, sur présentation de leur carte d’électeur biométrique.         Leurs noms sont ajoutés sur la liste des électeurs votants.   Dans le cas d’espèce, l’électeur doit justifier par un récépissé de changement de résidence délivré et authentifié par la CENI locale ou la Commission administrative de son ressort.   Art. 66 : Pour les élections législatives, les candidats déclarés éligibles par la Cour constitutionnelle sont autorisés à voter dans l’un des bureaux de vote du ressort de la circonscription électorale dans laquelle ils se portent candidats sur présentation de leur carte d’électeur biométrique.   Art. 67 : Les membres du bureau de vote régulièrement inscrits sur une liste électorale peuvent voter dans le bureau de vote où ils ont été nommés quelle que soit l’élection.   Les délégués détenteurs d’un mandat votent dans le bureau où ils ont été désignés pour leur mission.   Les personnes chargées d’assurer la sécurité des bureaux de votes sont autorisées à voter dans lesdits bureaux sur présentation de leur carte d’électeur biométrique.   Les agents des forces de défense et de sécurité, les membres et le personnel de la CENI et de ses démembrements, les membres et les délégués de la Cour constitutionnelle, les observateurs nationaux et les délégués des partis politiques sont autorisés à voter dans l’un des bureaux de vote de la circonscription électorale dans laquelle ils sont en mission, sur présentation de leur carte d’électeur biométrique, de leur mandat ou de leur Ordre de mission.         Le président du bureau de vote est tenu de leur faciliter le vote.   Dans tous les cas, mention du vote doit être faite au procès-verbal avec l’ensemble des caractéristiques de la carte d’électeur.   Art. 68 : Le vote est personnel et secret.   Le choix de l’électeur est libre.   Nul ne doit être influencé dans son choix par la contrainte, la menace ou la violence.   Le vote a lieu dans les bureaux désignés par la CENI.   Art. 69 : Le vote se fait au moyen d’un bulletin unique, à mettre dans l’urne par l’électeur.   Tout électeur atteint d’infirmité ou de handicap physique le mettant dans l’impossibilité d’introduire son bulletin dans l’urne est autorisé à se faire assister par un électeur de son choix ou par un membre du bureau de vote.      Art. 75 (Loi n° 2019-38 du 18 juillet 2019) : A son entrée dans le bureau de vote, l’électeur porteur de sa carte d’électeur biométrique ou de la preuve de son droit de voter par la production d’une décision du Président du Tribunal d’Instance, après avoir fait constater qu’aucune de ses mains ne porte d’empreinte et de trace d’encre indélébile, prend lui- même un bulletin unique mis à sa disposition. Le président ou un membre du bureau de vote lit à haute et intelligible voix les noms et prénoms de l’électeur qui s’apprête à voter. Celui-ci, sans quitter le bureau de vote exprime son choix. Cette opération doit se faire dans l’isoloir.   Il fait ensuite constater au président qu’il n’est porteur que d’un seul bulletin unique qu’il introduit lui-même dans l’urne.   Art. 76 : Le vote par procuration est exceptionnel ; il n’est admis qu’en cas d’incapacité physique ou d’empêchement majeur.   Sont déclarées valables les seules procurations établies par les présidents des commissions électorales locales conformément au modèle défini par la CENI.   Tout électeur mandaté pour voter par procuration doit être muni de la carte d’électeur et de la pièce d’identification de la personne qui l’a mandaté.         Le mandataire doit être inscrit dans le même bureau de vote que le mandant. Il ne peut être détenteur que d’une seule procuration.   La procuration doit être établie en deux (2) exemplaires dont l’un sera remis au mandant et l’autre classé dans les archives de la Commission locale des élections.   Elle doit être numérotée et enregistrée dans un registre spécial.   Toute procuration ne respectant pas les prescriptions du présent article est nulle.   A l’issue du dépouillement, les procurations sont jointes aux bulletins nuls, tels que prévus à l’article 88 ci-dessous et transmis à la juridiction compétente.   Art. 77 : Le vote de chaque électeur est constaté par son identification tel que prévue par l’article 75 ci-dessus, puis par sa signature ou son empreinte digitale apposée sur la liste d’émargement en face de son nom.   De plus, le vote de l’électeur est constaté par l’imprégnation de son pouce gauche à l’encre indélébile.   Tout électeur détenteur d’une procuration dûment mandatée doit procéder aux deux (2) opérations avant de passer son pouce à l’encre indélébile.       L’électeur atteint d’une infirmité le privant de son index ou de son pouce peut apposer l’empreinte de tout autre doigt sur la liste d’émargement. S’il ne dispose d’aucun doigt, la personne qui l’assiste est autorisée par le président de bureau de vote à apposer l’empreinte de son index.         Art. 78 : Dès la clôture du scrutin, la liste d’émargement est signée par tous les membres du bureau de vote.   Cette liste d’émargement est tenue à la disposition de tout électeur qui désire la consulter à la Circonscription électorale, pendant un délai de huit (8) jours à partir de la proclamation des résultats provisoires.   A l’issue du scrutin, les listes d’émargement sont conservées au chef-lieu de la commune sous la responsabilité du Maire, de l’Ambassadeur ou du Consul dans les représentations diplomatiques ou consulaires du Niger à l’étranger.

government_functions.details: The President of Ecuador serves as both head of government and head of state.  The president is directly elected by plurality of at least 40% and a 10% differential to the runner-up vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two consecutive 4-year terms.  The National Assembly shall be comprised of Fifteen (15) Assembly persons elected as representatives of the nation as a whole (national district). Two (2) Assembly persons elected for each province, plus one (1) additional Assembly person for every two hundred thousand (200,000) inhabitants or fraction thereof over one hundred fifty thousand (150,000), on the basis of the last national population census.  The jurisdictional bodies, without detriment to the other bodies with equal powers recognized in the Constitution, are those in charge of administering justice and they shall be as follows: The National Court of Justice. The provincial courts of justice. The courts and tribunals provided for by law. The justices of the peace.

Art. 115.- A las siete horas (07h00), los vocales de la Junta exhibirán las urnas vacías a los electorespresentes y las cerrarán con las seguridades establecidas; procederá luego a recibir los votos.El elector presentará al secretario su cédula de identidad, ciudadanía o pasaporte y una vezverificada la inscripción en el padrón se le proporcionará las papeletas y el elector consignará su votoen forma reservada. Luego de depositar las papeletas en las urnas, firmará el registro, quienes esténimposibilitados de hacerlo imprimirán la huella digital; cumplido el deber cívico del sufragio recibirá elcertificado de votación.El Consejo Nacional Electoral reglamentará la forma de votación que deba ser implementada paralos casos de personas cuya discapacidad impida el ejercicio del sufragio.La Junta adoptará las medidas necesarias para asegurar la reserva del acto de votación.Art. 116.- El lugar donde funcione la Junta Receptora del Voto será considerado como recintoelectoral y en su interior todas las personas deberán acatar las disposiciones que impartan lasautoridades y funcionarios electorales.Art. 117.- Si los delegados de los sujetos políticos formularen observaciones o reclamos a la JuntaReceptora del Voto, esta los resolverá de inmediato y dejará constancia en el acta.Art. 118.- El sufragio terminará a las diecisiete horas (17h00), las personas que se encuentren en lafila de sufragantes no podrán votar pero se les entregará un certificado provisional de presentación.SECCION CUARTAForma de votación en generalArt. 119.- Para expresar su voluntad el elector en el caso de elecciones unipersonales, marcará elcasillero de la candidatura o del binomio de su preferencia.Art. 120.- En las elecciones para representantes a la Asamblea Nacional y al Parlamento Andino asícomo para consejeros regionales, concejales municipales y vocales de las juntas parroquialesrurales, los electores marcarán la casilla que identifique a cada candidato de una sola lista o entrelistas, hasta el máximo de la representación que corresponda elegir.

Art. 116 Para el acto de votación se procederá así:   1)Cada elector acudirá personalmente ante la Junta Receptora de Votos presentando su Cédula de Identidad Ciudadana o su Documento Supletorio de Votación;   2)La Junta Receptora de Votos verificará la validez de la Cédula de Identidad o del Documento Supletorio de votación y si esta corresponde a su portador, se comprobará si el elector se encuentra registrado en la lista del Padrón Electoral para entregarle las boletas electorales correspondientes;   3)El Presidente de la Junta Receptora de Votos le explicará al elector la forma de emitir el voto;   4)El votante marcará en cada boleta electoral con una “X” o cualquier otro signo en el circulo de su preferencia y la introducirá debidamente doblada en la urna electoral correspondiente;   5)Si la “X” o cualquier otro signo hubiese sido marcada en la boleta fuera del circulo, pero se pueda entender la intención del votante, el voto se consignará válido; y   6)Previo al ejercicio del derecho al voto, en el caso que el elector portare el Documento Supletorio de Votación, este quedará retenido en la Junta Receptora de Votos, salvo en la elección presidencial en cuyo caso será devuelto debidamente marcado a fin de ejercer el derecho al voto en la segunda convocatoria si la hubiere.   Art.117 Los miembros de las Juntas Receptoras de Votos, los fiscales acreditados ante ellas y su personal auxiliar, ubicados en las Juntas Receptoras de Votos diferentes de aquellas en la cual se encuentran registrados, podrán votar en ellas previa presentación de su Cédula de Identidad Ciudadana o Documento Supletorio de Votación y credencial. Esto se hará constar en acta.

government_functions.details: The President of Micronesia serves as both the chief of state and head of government. The President is indirectly elected by Congress from among four senators-at-large.   The Micronesian legislature is composed of a unicameral Congress with 14 seats. All members of Congress are directly elected. 10 members are elected by plurality vote in single-seat constituencies and serve 2-year terms. An additional “at large” member is elected from each of the four Micronesian states by proportional representation vote, and these members serve 4-year terms.   The Supreme Court is the highest court of the Micronesian judiciary and consists of up to six judges split into two divisions. These judges are nominated by the President and confirmed by a two-thirds vote of Congress. Judges may serve for life.

government_functions.details:
Australia is a parliamentary democracy that is a part of the British Commonwealth. As such, the chief of state is the British Monarch. The monarchy is hereditary. The monarch appoints an in-country representative called a governor on the recommendation of the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister is the leader of the majority party or majority coalition in government. 

Australian parliament is bicameral, with a 76-seat Senate and a 151-seat House of Representatives. Both houses are directly elected. The Senate is comprised of six senators for each original state (per the Constitution), with a provision that additional seats can be apportioned should new state be recognized. Senators serve six-year terms. The House of Representatives is intende to comprise twice the number of Senators. Seats in the House are apportioned by population.

The highest court in Australia is the High Court of Australia. Additionally, there are a variety of state and territory courts.

voting_methods.instructions: In general, the voter must show the unsigned postal vote certificate (declaration)  and unmarked ballot paper to an authorized witness, must complete and sign the certificate in the presence of the witness, the witness must c, sign and date the certificate and note on it their capacity to act.  Then the voter must mark their paper in the presence of the witness but so as the witness cannot see the vote, fold the paper, seal it in the envelope.  The voter and the witness must both declare on the certificate (which forms part of the envelope) that these steps were completed before the close of the poll.  the person must then post or deliver the envelope to the Divisional Returning Officer for which they are enrolled.  There are some exceptions to some of these requirements for persons registered as a general postal voter or for persons voting from outside Australia.  You can vote early either in person or by post if on election day you: •    are outside the electorate where you are enrolled to vote •    are more than 8km from a polling place •    are travelling •    are unable to leave your workplace to vote •    are seriously ill, infirm or due to give birth shortly (or caring for someone who is) •    are a patient in hospital and can't vote at the hospital •    have religious beliefs that prevent you from attending a polling place •    are in prison serving a sentence of less than three years or otherwise detained •    are a silent elector •    have a reasonable fear for your safety.  While this is technically true, it in practice is not enforced.

You can vote at an early voting center, or if you're overseas, at an overseas voting center.  Where a voter is voting at an early voting center within their district and is on the certified roll they may vote in the same way they do on polling day (that is, they are marked off the roll, they are issued with ballot papers which they mark in a booth and place in the appropriate ballot box.  If not, they must first complete a declaration in front of the issuing officer, mark their voting paper in the presence of the issuing officer without letting the officer see the vote, fold the ballot paper and give it to the issuing officer who puts it into the envelope containing the declaration.  The issuing officer fastens the envelope and secures it in a ballot box.  You can vote early either in person or by post if on election day you: •    are outside the electorate where you are enrolled to vote •    are more than 8km from a polling place •    are travelling •    are unable to leave your workplace to vote •    are seriously ill, infirm or due to give birth shortly (or caring for someone who is) •    are a patient in hospital and can't vote at the hospital •    have religious beliefs that prevent you from attending a polling place •    are in prison serving a sentence of less than three years or otherwise detained •    are a silent elector •    have a reasonable fear for your safety.  While this is technically true, it in practice is not enforced.

For the House, the voter must write the number 1 in the square next to their first preference candidate and thereafter must write the numbers 2.3.4 and so on in the squares next to all remaining candidates without the repetition of any number.    If the final preference is left blank (e.g. with six candidates, five preferences are given AND the final box is left blank) the blank box is taken to be a valid last preference.

government_functions.details: The President of Bulgaria serves as the chief of state, while the Prime Minister is the head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority popular vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is indirectly elected by the National Assembly.  Bulgaria has a unicameral National Assembly (Народно събрание / Narodno Sabranie) with 240 seats. Members of the National Assembly are directly elected by proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies and serve 4-year terms. Parties and coalitions must earn at least 4% of the overall vote to receive a seat.   The high courts of Bulgaria consist of the Supreme Court of Cassation (penal, civil, and commercial legal matters), the Supreme Administrative Court (national government matters), and the Constitutional Court. Cassation and administrative judges are elected by the Supreme Judicial Council (SJC) and confirmed by the President. These judges can serve until age 65. The Constitutional Court is independent of the judiciary branch, and its 12 justices are elected by the National Assembly and confirmed by the President and SJC. Constitutional Court justices serve 9-year terms, and one-third of justices are replaced every 3 years.

voting_methods.instructions: Voters first select the list of a single party (or coalition of parties or isolated independent candidate) and then, within the list, mark one preference for every four seats to be filled in their constituency.  Seats are distributed among lists within each constituency by dividing the total number of votes cast for each list by the electoral quota. The remaining seats are distributed among parties or coalitions of parties that have gained at least one seat in any constituency pursuant to the first distribution or, for single parties, at least 1.8% of all valid votes cast throughout the island (for coalitions of 2 or more parties, the applicable figures are 10% and 20%, respectively). Notwithstanding the above, 3.6% of the total number of votes cast is required for lists of single parties which participate in the second distribution in order to be entitled to a second seat.  Vacancies arising between general elections are filled by the unsuccessful candidates of the same party in the constituency concerned who received the highest number of preferential votes after the last successful candidate.

voting_methods.instructions: A ballot shall be filled out by the voter in a special place, where the presence of other individuals shall not be allowed. A special place must be selected to ensure secrecy of election when filling out the ballot by a voter and control on behalf of the election commission members and observers over the actions of the voter.

Ballots is handed out to the voters included in the voter list, upon presentation of an identity document; Ballot shall be filled out by the voter in a specially equipped booth or other specially equipped place, where no other persons shall be allowed; Voter shall put a mark in the appropriate field of the ballot to indicate a candidate or political party in whose favour the choice was made, or shall indicate his/her attitude by marking the “Against all” field; the marked ballots shall be cast by voters in sealed ballot boxes.

voting_methods.instructions: Voters who wish to vote earlier than the polling day must apply to the Electoral Commissioner in the approved form and present the required evidence, if deemed necessary, to support their case. (Art. 3, sec. 2(a)(b) of Electoral (Early Voting) Regulations 2019)   If the voters' application for early voting gets approval, the casting of votes must be taken in all respects as if it was in the polling station or mobile polling station. (Art. 12 of Electoral (Early Voting) Regulations 2019) Early voters must not vote in person on the polling day or participate in any aspect of proxy voting. (Art. 13 of Electoral (Early Voting) Regulations 2019)  Early voting will be available for a week before Polling day from 12:00 PM on a Thursday (1 week before polling) to 17:00 PM the day before polling. Saturdays from 09:00 AM to 13:00 PM and closed on Sundays. (Nauru Electoral Commission)

Voters must only vote at the polling station in the District where they registered and must sign next to their names on the voter list for confirmation. Upon receiving the ballot paper, they must go to a polling booth and mark their votes correctly. (See sec. 74 of Electoral Act 2016 for the prescribed way of voting.) After voting, voters must fold their ballot paper and place it at the ballot box in the presence of the presiding officer or an electoral official. (sec. 73(1), (2c), (3a,b,c,d) of Electoral Act 2016  Voters who will not be in Nauru on the polling day may still cast their vote through the proxy voting method by applying to the Electoral Commissioner for proxy voting authorization. Proxies must also complete their ballot as they vote for another registered voter and make sure that they do it following the requirements specified in sections 71, 72, 73, and 74 of the Electoral Act of 2016. (sec. 78(1,2,3) of the Electoral Act of 2016.

In the period of early voting, on a daily basis after termination of the voting, the chairperson or deputy chair of the precinct commission glues a sheet of paper on the slot of the ballot box, and signatures of the chair, deputy, and a member of the commission are put on the sheet. At the start of each early voting day the slot is opened in front of observers and media. The ballot box is kept secure by the chair throughout the early voting period. On each day of early voting a protocol is filled out by the precinct commission to account for all ballots; the protocol is put up for general familarization in the premises of the precinct commissions. When receiving the ballot in early voting, voters must sign the voter list and enter the day of the early voting. The voting procedures are the same as for election day. Early voting is not held in the voting precincts formed in health care facilities.

Voters must submit their internal passport or other document determined by the central election commission; if voter is on voter list they are given a ballot and sign the relevant line on the voter list; votes mark their ballot in a polling booth or room, with ballot boxes placed so that the voters approach them only through the booths or premises assigned for secret voting; proxy voting is prohibited and voters must personally mark their ballots; another person can assist voters who are unable to personally mark the ballot, at the voter's discretion (poll workers, candidates or their representatives, election observers or media representatives cannot assist voters); ballots have the option of "against all"; voters who spoil ballots can receive a new ballot.

government_functions.details: The President of Benin serves as chief of state and head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two 5-year terms.  Benin has a unicameral National Assembly with 109 members. All members are directly elected by list proportional representation vote within multi-seat constituencies and serve 5-year terms.  Benin has several high courts with different legal domains. The Supreme Court has 17 judges who are appointed by the President and serve up to two 5-year terms. The Constitutional Court has 7 judges who are appointed by either the National Assembly or the President and serve up to two 5-year terms. The High Court of Justice forms only to try high treason cases involving national government officials. It is formed from 6 judges of the Constitutional Court who are selected by the National Assembly and Supreme Court president.

voting_methods.instructions: Article 80: Tout électeur dont le nom figure sur la liste électorale d’un centre de vote, a l'obligation de prendre part au vote dans le poste auquel il a été rattaché.Toutefois, sous réserve du contrôle de leur carte d'électeur et de leur titre de mission, sont admis à voter en dehors de leur lieu d'inscription, les agents des forces de sécurité et de défense, les journalistes et toutes autres personnes en déplacement pour raison de service.Sont également admis à voter en dehors de leur lieu d'inscription, les candidats à l'élection concernée, les membres de la Commission électorale nationale autonome (CENA), lescoordonnateurs d'arrondissementainsi que les délégués des candidats ou de liste de candidats dûment mandatés.Les béninois rapatriés pour cas de force majeure sont admis à voter par dérogation dans les mêmes conditions que les personnes suscitées.Les nom, prénoms, date et lieu de naissance ainsi que le numéro d’inscription sur la liste électorale, l’indication du lieu et du poste de vote où sont régulièrement inscrites ces personnes doivent être mentionnés sur la liste électorale et au procès-verbal du poste où elles ont voté afin que, lors du décompte des électeurs, ils soient retranchés de la liste électorale de leur circonscription.Article 81: Nul ne peut être admis à voter dans un poste de vote si son nom ne figure sur la liste électorale de ce poste de vote.  Article 84: A son entrée dans la salle du scrutin, l'électeur présente sa carte d’électeur et fait constater son inscription sur la liste électorale. Puis il prend lui-même un bulletin, se rend dans l'isoloir, marque son choix et plie le bulletin de manière à cacher son vote. Il fait ensuite constater qu'il n'est porteur que d'un seul pli; le président le constate sans toucher le pli que l'électeur introduit lui-même dans l'urne.En cas de couplage d’élections, l’électeur après unpremier vote, prend le bulletin prévu pour le second vote, se dirige vers l’isoloir prévu pour la seconde élection, marque son choix et plie le bulletin de manière à cacher son vote. Il fait ensuite constater qu’il n’est porteur que d’un seul pli; le président le constate sans toucher le pli que l’électeur introduit lui-même dans l’urne.Article 85: Chaque poste de vote est doté d'un ou de plusieurs isoloirs. Les isoloirs doivent assurer le secret du vote de chaque électeur. Ils doivent être placés de telle manière que le citoyen puisse cacher son vote.Article 86: L'urne est transparente et présente en outre, des garanties de sécurité et d'inviolabilité.Elle est pourvue d'une seule ouverture destinée à laisser passer le bulletin de vote plié. Elle doit, avant le commencement du scrutin, avoir été vidée, fermée et scellée au vu et au su des membres du poste de vote et des électeurs présents.Une deuxième urne est prévue en cas de couplage d’élections.Article 87: Tout électeur atteint d'infirmité ou d'incapacité physique certaine, le mettant dans l'impossibilité de plier et de glisser son bulletin dans l'urne, est autorisé à se faire assister d'une personne de son choix.Article 88: Le vote de chaque électeur est constaté par l'apposition de l'empreintede son pouce gauche à l'encre indélébile en face de son nom en présence des membres du poste de vote.  http://coslepi.info/wp-content/uploads/2018/09/MIEUX-COMPRENDRE-LE-CODE-ELECTORAL-DU-BENIN-2018.pdf

The table will be open for at least eight (8) hours, unless all the qualified and qualified voters had paid. If there are still voters in line to cast their vote after eight (8) hours, the voting table will continue to be open until everyone has voted.

government_functions.details: The President of Bulgaria serves as the chief of state, while the Prime Minister is the head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority popular vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is indirectly elected by the National Assembly.  Bulgaria has a unicameral National Assembly (Народно събрание / Narodno Sabranie) with 240 seats. Members of the National Assembly are directly elected by proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies and serve 4-year terms. Parties and coalitions must earn at least 4% of the overall vote to receive a seat.   The high courts of Bulgaria consist of the Supreme Court of Cassation (penal, civil, and commercial legal matters), the Supreme Administrative Court (national government matters), and the Constitutional Court. Cassation and administrative judges are elected by the Supreme Judicial Council (SJC) and confirmed by the President. These judges can serve until age 65. The Constitutional Court is independent of the judiciary branch, and its 12 justices are elected by the National Assembly and confirmed by the President and SJC. Constitutional Court justices serve 9-year terms, and one-third of justices are replaced every 3 years.

voting_methods.instructions: Voting is compulsory but there is no sanction for not voting.  Voters vote in person at their designated polling station (though candidates, higher level election officials, and observers can apply for a certificate to vote at any polling station within the respective constitutency). Secrecy of the vote is guaranteed. On arrival at the polling station, voters show their identity card, or in certain cases, their internal passport. The poll worker checks the voter's particulars against the voter register and enters the identity number and type of document shown into the voter register and admits the voter to voting. Any discrepancy in the name shown in the identification document and the voter register, if the permanent address matches, is recorded in the voter register.  If the voter is not found on the voter register he/she can be added to a supplemental list, with proof of residence in the district, and is allowed to vote upon submitting a declaration (to be attached to the voter register) that he/she has not voted and will not vote elsewhere. The law provides for the use of both paper ballot voting and direct recording electronic voting machines, at the voter's option. In past elections, such machines were used on  a limited basis as it was not mandatory and due to limited resources and technical expertise, but a 2020 amendment to the election law now mandates that voters have the option of either paper or machine-based voting. If paper voting, the voter is given a  ballot that is stamped by the poll worker with the commission's seal. The voter proceeds to the voting booth and in private marks the square of the candidate of his/her choice. The voter folds the ballot to keep the vote secret, exits the booth and hands the folded ballot to the poll worker who checks whether the number on the ballot matches the number on the book of ballots and if so, restamps the ballot with the seal of the commission and detaches the counterfoil and deposits it in a separate box. The voter then deposits the ballot in the ballot box, signs the voter register, and his/her identification document is given back and he/she leaves the polling site.  If the voter has spoiled the ballot, he/she can return it folded to the poll worker and a replacement ballot will be issued (only once.) In machine voting, the voter is given access to the voting device and votes by means of a magnetic card, with the device displaying a ballot identical to the paper ballot, as well as an option to vote 'against all'. After voting for the candidate list, he/she can change the choice once before confirming to vote. The voter receives a message that the voting is completed and a control receipt is printed which is to be deposited in a special machine voting box.The voter then returns the magnetic card, signs the voter register, and is given back his/her identification document and leaves the polling site. The fact that the voter voted by machine is noted in the voter register. If the machine voting becomes inoperable, voting proceeds by paper ballots. Mobile (homebound) voting is available for voters with permanent disabililities, based on an advance request before polling day.  The mobile voting is carried out by not less than four poll workers on election day.

Code électoral de 2019:   Article 43  Le vote des nomades a lieu sur deux (2) jours. Le premier jour est celui qui précède le jour du scrutin national dans les conditions fixées à l'alinéa 1 du présent article.   Les tchadiens de l'Étranger votent sur deux (2) jours selon les conditions déterminées par la CENI, qui doivent tenir compte du contexte, de l'environnement et des réalités objectives des représentations diplomatiques et consulaires du Tchad.      Les membres des Forces de défense et de sécurité sont consignés dans leurs casernes le jour du scrutin. Ils votent un jour avant les autres citoyens et en dehors des casernes dans des bureaux définis à l'article 38, et supervisés par la CENI.

Code électoral de 2019:   Article 43 : Le scrutin ne dure qu’un seul jour sur l’étendue du territoire national. Il est ouvert à six (06) heures et clos le même jour à dix-sept (17) heures.      Article 48 : L'électeur, après avoir fait constater et confirmer son identité par la présentation de sa carte biométrique, prend le bulletin unique de vote, se rend à l'isoloir, coche le candidat ou la liste de son choix ou appose son empreinte digitale devant le candidat ou la liste de son choix, plie le bulletin, sort de l'isoloir et introduit le bulletin dans l'urne placée devant le Président du bureau de vote.   En cas d’élections couplées, l’électeur fait les mêmes gestes prévus à l’alinéa précédent mais en ramassant à la fois autant de bulletins qu’il y a d’élections.   Article 49 : Le vote de chaque électeur est constaté par l'apposition de sa signature sur la liste d'émargement. S'il ne peut signer, il y appose son empreinte digitale.   Tout électeur doit, après avoir introduit le bulletin dans l'urne, tremper son doigt dans l'encre indélébile avant de quitter le bureau de vote.   Article 50 : Tout électeur, atteint d'infirmité le mettant dans l'incapacité de voter, est autorisé à se faire assister par un électeur de son choix inscrit sur la même liste électorale que lui.   Article 51 : Les membres du bureau de vote régulièrement inscrits sur la liste électorale sont autorisés à voter dans les bureaux où ils siègent sur simple présentation de leur carte d'électeur.

Artículo 169. Desarrollo de la votación. A las siete horas (7:00 a.m.), el o la Presidente (a) de la Mesa Electoral Receptora, anunciará “empieza la votación”. Seguidamente, se procederá de acuerdo a la secuencia siguiente:1) El o la Presidente(a) requerirá a cada elector la presentación de su Tarjeta de Identidad;2) El o la Presidente (a) mostrará dicha tarjeta a los demás miembros de la mesa para su cotejo con la fotografía que aparece en el cuaderno electoral y la verificación de autenticidad. Seguidamente, la entregará a1 Secretario(a);3) El o la Secretario(a) comprobará que el ciudadano aparece inscrito en el padrón electoral de dicha mesa;4) Una vez comprobado por el Secretario(a) que aparece inscrito en el padrón electoral, los demás miembros de la Mesa Electoral Receptora observarán la mano del elector para comprobar que en sus dedos no existen manchas de tinta indeleble que indique que pudo haber votado en otra Mesa; si las hubiere el Secretario(a) de la Mesa Electoral Receptora retendrá su Tarjeta de Identidad y le ordenará salir del local registrándolo en la hoja de incidencias;5) Si el elector no tuviere impedimento, el o la Presidente(a) firmará junto con el o la Secretario(a) de la Mesa Electoral Receptora en el reverso de las papeletas y las entregará al elector; 6) El o la Secretario(a) retendrá la Tarjeta de Identidad y cualquier aparato digital fotográfico por el tiempo que utilice el elector para votar;7) Seguidamente el elector pasará al lugar privado para marcar las papeletas;8) Enseguida el elector, las doblará de manera que quede oculto el contenido y así las mostrará a los miembros de la Mesa para que éstos verifiquen que contienen las firmas del Presidente(a) y Secretario(a); de tenerlas, se estampará el sello de “ratificado”;9) Efectuado esto el elector depositará cada papeleta en la urna respectiva;10) Seguidamente, uno de los miembros de las Mesa Electoral Receptora examinará el dedo meñique de la mano derecha del votante, o el que corresponda, para ver si tiene residuos grasos o impermeables, procurando eliminarlos si los tuviere y le pondrá tinta indeleble en el mismo;11) El o la Secretario(a) de la mesa hará la anotación respectiva de que el elector votó, consignándolo en el correspondiente Padrón Electoral; y12) Finalmente el Secretario(a) hará entrega al elector de su Tarjeta de Identidad y aparato digital en su caso que le haya retenido quien se retirará de inmediato del local  Artículo 172. Cierre de la Votación. La votación se desarrollará sin interrupción hasta las dieciséis horas (4:00 p.m.);

Voters eligible to vote at their place of residence (mobile voting) submit an advance written application to the precinct election commission, not later than 3 days before election day. Each polling station will have up to three mobile ballot boxes. Mobile voting is conducted by at least two members of the precinct election commission (drawn by lots) together with the operator who received the required number of ballot papers, and together with the sealed mobile ballot boxes. Parties, candidates, observers and media can observe the mobile voting process. A special list of mobile voters is posted outside the polling station two days earlier. The home-bound voter must identify him/herself to the poll workers on the basis of biometric and personal data. Upon identification, the ballot is issued to the voter (no check issued) and the poll worker registers the voter in the paper voter list by putting the series and number of the voter's ID and signs it. The voter signs the voter list upon verification of the entries.  The voter marks the ballot in a special place that allows secrecy of the vote, as well as observation by poll workers and observers. A voter who is unable to fill out the ballot on his/her own due to disability or health condition can request assistance of another voter (but not poll worker, partisan representatives or observers.) In the voter list is noted that the voter voted outside the voting premises.

Only citizens on the voter list have a right to vote on election day. Proxy voting is not permitted.  A voter's identity is checked at the polling station based on his/her biometric and personal data using identification equipment at the polling station. Voter consent is not required. The voter's information is shown on a monitor, visible to partisan representatives and observers. After identification, a check is printed out which the voter hands to the poll worker in exchange for a ballot. If the equipment fails to identify the voter, the voter is not allowed to vote. An official act is to be drawn up with a copy to the voter and another copy to be provided to the relevant state bodies after the official announcement of the election results for taking measures. A ballot is issued to the voter upon presentation of an identity document. When a ballot is issued to a voter, the poll worker registers the voter in the paper voter list, by entering the series and number of the voter's ID and signing the voter list. The voter signs the voter list upon checking the accuracy of the entries. The voter marks the ballot in secret in the voting booth or other specially equipped place. The voter marks the ballot in the square or in the position "Against all" in favour of the candidate or party of choice. If a voter spoils the ballot, a new ballot can be issued; next to the voter's name on the voter list, the poll worker notes that a replacement ballot was provided. Upon verbal notification to the polling commission, voters not able to independently vote can request assistance from another voter who is not a poll worker, candidate, partisan representative, or observer. The voter puts the marked ballot in the automated ballot box. If the automated ballot box breaks down on election day, a spare automated box is to be used and an official act drawn up. If the spare automated ballot box is damaged, voting is to be carried out using a stationary ballot box, and an official act drawn up. If the automated ballot box is repaired it cannot, in any case, be used.

Those who want to vote shall: - Provide an ID to the identification officer. - Receive a stamped ballot paper from the officer - Cast his/her vote. - Ink the index finger of the right hand and put the ballot paper in the ballot box.  - [ ] The Following documents are considered a valid ID: - Family book, if it has his/her picture. - Passport. - National ID - Official Identification document.

government_functions.details: The President of Poland serves as chief of state while the Prime Minister acts as head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and may serve two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is appointed by the President and confirmed by the Sejm.  Poland has a bicameral Parliament composed of a 100-seat Senate and a 460-seat Sejm. Senators are directly elected by plurality vote in single-seat constituencies and serve 4-year terms. Members of the Sejm are directly elected by party-list proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies and serve 4-year terms. Parties must earn at least 5% of the national vote to gain a seat in the Sejm, and coalitions must earn 8% of the vote with minority parties excepted from this standard.  Poland has two high courts: the Supreme Court and the Constitutional Tribunal. The Supreme Court is composed of 121 judges separated into thematic chambers. Supreme Court judges are nominated by the National Judicial Council and confirmed by the President, and they may serve until age 65. The Constitutional Tribunal is composed of 15 judges appointed by the Sejm to serve a 9-year term.

voting_methods.instructions: Proxy voting is prohibited except that voters with a significant or moderate degree of disability within the meaning of the law or who are over 75 can formally give another person their proxy vote (a proxy vote can be taken only from one person or two if immediate family member, and not commission member or partisan agent); voter must provide proof of identity to the election commission (overseas voters must present a valid Polish paassport); a stamped ballot paper is issued and voter confirms receipt with his/her signature on the voter list; voter must mark ballot in the polling booth that guarantees secrecy; for presidential elections the voter must vote for only one candidate by putting an "X" next to the name in the box on the left; voter inserts the ballot in the ballot box located in a visible position, in such a way that the printed side of ballot is not visible;  voters with absentee voting certificates are allowed to vote after being entered in the voter register; upon request by a disabled voter, another person who is not a poll worker or partisan observer can assist the voter to vote.

Overseas voters apply for postal voting at least 15 days before the election day and receive a voting package.  They are to mark the ballot and insert the marked ballot in the ballot paper envelope, seal the envelope and insert it into the return envelope together with the signed declaration (a statement of personal and secret casting of the vote) and return it by mail at his or her own cost to the address of the consul. Voters can also deliver the postal vote in person to the consul. The consul transfers all returned envelopes that it received by the end of voting to the appropriate election commission.

government_functions.details: The President of Poland serves as chief of state while the Prime Minister acts as head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and may serve two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is appointed by the President and confirmed by the Sejm.  Poland has a bicameral Parliament composed of a 100-seat Senate and a 460-seat Sejm. Senators are directly elected by plurality vote in single-seat constituencies and serve 4-year terms. Members of the Sejm are directly elected by party-list proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies and serve 4-year terms. Parties must earn at least 5% of the national vote to gain a seat in the Sejm, and coalitions must earn 8% of the vote with minority parties excepted from this standard.  Poland has two high courts: the Supreme Court and the Constitutional Tribunal. The Supreme Court is composed of 121 judges separated into thematic chambers. Supreme Court judges are nominated by the National Judicial Council and confirmed by the President, and they may serve until age 65. The Constitutional Tribunal is composed of 15 judges appointed by the Sejm to serve a 9-year term.

voting_methods.instructions: Voter has to come to the building fo the relevant constituency commission by filling in a ballot paper. The ballot paper filled up by the voter beforehand has to be put into the envelope, glued up and signed in glued place by two members of the relevant election commission and then it is confirmed by the seal of the election commission and the signature of the voter. The glued envelope is preserved by the secretary of the relevant election commission in the building of the constituency commission prior to the moment of passing of ballots to the PEC. In the day of voting, before the beginning of voting, the chairman of the PEC in the presence of the member of PEC, observers and other persons gives the information about the number of voters, who have Early Voting and then show the envelopes with the ballots and the list of voters, who have Early Voting. After that he opens the envelopes keeping the secrecy of the voters’ will and cast the ballots into the ballot boxes.

voting_methods.instructions: PART VII NON-RESIDENT ELECTORS’ BALLOT 50. (1) In this Part―ballot attendant‖ means an officer appointed under section 53(1); ―ballot officer‖, ―non-resident elector‖ and ―non-resident electors’ roll‖ shall have the meanings assigned to them, respectively, by section 44. (2) Reference in this Part to the serial number of a non-resident elector shall be construed as reference to the serial number of his registration record. (3) A ballot officer may exercise any powers, and perform any duties, of a ballot attendant under any provisions of Part VII and references in any such provisions to a ballot attendant shall be construed accordingly with such modifications to the context as may be necessary for the purpose. 51. Not later than the 14th day before election day, there shall be posted to every non-resident elector—(a) by such ballot officer as shall be provided under section 48(b) with copies of entries in the non-resident electors’ roll which include the name of that non-resident elector; or (b) in any case where there is no such ballot officer, by the Chief Election Officer; a sealed envelope, which shall be directed to the non-resident elector at his address appearing on the non-resident electors’ roll and shall contain the following— (i) an unsealed envelope (hereafter referred to in this Part as the addressed envelope) addressed in the name, and to the office, of the officer issuing the same, which shall be recognisable by him on its return as having been issued under this paragraph; (ii) a declaration of identity in Form 14 which shall bear the serial number of the non-resident elector on its reverse side; (iii) an unsealed envelope (hereinafter referred to in this Part as the ballot envelope) addressed with the words ―To the Chief Election Officer‖ and capable of containing a ballot paper and of being enclosed, together with the last- mentioned form, in the addressed envelope; (iv) a copy of the directions for balloting by non-resident electors as set out in Form 15; (v) a ballot paper stamped with the official mark. 52 .Upon issuing a ballot paper to any non-resident elector under section 51, a ballot officer or the Chief Election Officer, as the case may be, shall—(a) show that a ballot paper has been issued to the non- resident elector, but without showing the particular ballot paper issued, place a mark on such copy of entries in the non- resident electors’ roll as shall be used by him for the purposes of this paragraph; and (b) enter on the counterfoil of the ballot paper the serial number of the non-resident elector. 53. (1)ThereshallbeappointedsuchnumberofofficersastheChief Election Officer may consider requisite for the performance in any country of the functions of ballot attendants under this Act. (2) The Chief Election Officer shall cause notice of the name and address of every ballot attendant to be published in the Gazette and may cause such further publication of the same, for the information of non- resident electors, as the Chief Election Officer considers desirable; and the address of the office of each ballot officer shall be notified under the foregoing provisions of this subsection as being also the address of a ballot attendant. (3) The ballot attendant at every such office as aforesaid shall permit any person having authority by virtue of section 130(1)(f) for promotion of the election of a group of candidates, and designated in writing by their election agent, to attend the balloting there by non- resident electors in the presence of the ballot attendant and shall afford that person, if and when he attends, all such reasonable facilities for observing the said balloting as that attendant can afford consistently with the orderly conduct of the proceedings, the discharge of his duties in connection therewith and the maintenance of the secrecy of the ballot. (4) There shall not be more than one person designated as aforesaid by the election agent of each list of candidates to attend at the same office. 54. Every non-resident elector in receipt of the addressed and ballot envelopes, Form 13 and ballot paper issued to him under section 51(i), (ii), (iii) and (v)— (a) may upon satisfying any ballot attendant as to his Ballot attendants. identity by way of production of his passport, travel document or other proof of such identity, and of the envelope directed to him under section 51, not later than the 9th day before election day— (i) exhibit the said envelopes, Form 14 and ballot paper (unmarked) to the ballot attendant; (ii) secretly mark and fold the ballot paper in the like manner as provided by section 81(2), enclose it in the ballot envelope and seal that envelope, in the presence of the ballot attendant, but so that the ballot attendant does not observe the said manner of marking the ballot paper; and (iii) give the ballot envelope so sealed and Form 14 to the ballot attendant, who shall forthwith complete the said Form in the presence of the non-resident elector and issue to him a receipt in Form 16:  Form 16 Provided that— (a) if the non-resident elector is incapacitated by blindness or other physical cause from personally complying with the foregoing provisions of this paragraph, the ballot attendant may, at the request of the non-resident elector, comply or permit a person appointed by the non-resident elector to comply with any such provisions on his behalf, in his presence and according to his directions; (b) the person so appointed shall be a non-resident elector, who shall, before the form of declaration is given to the ballot attendant under subparagraph (iii) of this paragraph, endorse on the reverse side of the form a certificate in the following terms:―I, .............................................................................................. (names in block letters) hereby certify that the non-resident elector whose serial number appears next hereto is physically incapacitated and voted with my assistance rendered at his request. ............................... (Signature)‖; or  (b) if he prefers so to do, or if no ballot attendant is available, may— (i) secretly mark and fold the ballot paper in the like manner as provided by section 72(2) and enclose it in the ballot envelope; (ii) seal the ballot envelope; (iii) complete Form 13 and enclose it, together with the ballot envelope, in the addressed envelope for posting under section 55(b). 55. For the purpose of causing the vote recorded by him to be cast in the manner provided by section 62(1), every non-resident elector— (a) having complied with section 54(a), shall thereupon surrender to the ballot attendant the addressed envelope exhibited under subparagraph (i) of that paragraph to such attendant, who shall— (i) forthwith, in the presence of the non-resident elector, enclose therein the ballot envelope, and the declaration in the form, given by him under subparagraph (iii) of the said paragraph and seal the addressed envelope; (ii) until its delivery to the officer mentioned in the next following subparagraph, keep the addressed envelope so sealed in safe custody and take every precaution to prevent its being opened or unauthorised access being had thereto; and (iii) be responsible for delivering the addressed envelope not later than the 5th day before election day to the officer to whose office it is so addressed; (b) having complied with section 54(b), shall seal the addressed envelope containing its enclosures under that paragraph and post it so as to be received by the officer to whose office it is so addressed not later than the 7th day before election day.

election_commission_name: High Commission of the Republic in French Polynesia

government_functions.details:
The President of French Polynesia is indirectly elected by the Assembly from among its members. The President may serve up to two 5-year terms.

In the Assembly, 38 members are directly elected via absolute majority, closed-list vote in multi-seat constituencies in up to two rounds. Only lists receiving at least 12.5% of the total vote can advance to the second round, but parties may combine their votes and lists to meet this requirement. The remaining 19 seats are allocated to the party that receives the most votes. All members serve 5-year terms.

Within the French legislature, French Polynesia directly elects three deputies of the National Assembly via absolute majority vote in up to two rounds. French Polynesia indirectly elects two members of the Senate via an electoral college, and one senate seat is contested every three years. Deputies serve 5-year terms, and senators serve 6-year terms.

voting_methods.instructions:
For this voting method, the voter must be French, residing abroad, and registered on a consular electoral list.

The postal voting material will be sent for each round to voters who have activated this option, together with the convocation letter and the candidates' declarations of faith. It will contain: ballot papers; a ballot envelope (colour according to the ballots); an identification envelope (white) to be filled in the voters; a shipping envelope made out to the address of the position that receives their vote. Voters must select the ballot and drag it into the ballot envelope. They must then insert the ballot envelope into the identification envelope (white) on which they indicate their first and last name. Thereafter, paste the identification envelope and sign it. Voters must put the identification envelope and a copy of identification with their signature in the shipping envelope. Note that voters must not insert the copy of the identity document either in the ballot envelope or in the identification envelope (white). They must send the shipping envelope to the consulate – if they would send it by mail, they must not forget to put a stamp. Their vote must reach the consular post before the deadline date and time.

To vote online, the voter must be French, residing abroad, and registered on a consular electoral list.

Voters must log into their voting portal by entering their 12-digit character ID, which they will receive by email, and their 12-character password, which they will receive by SMS.

Upon logging in, voters may cast their votes by entering the 4-digit security code first, then by clicking the "connection" button.

Thereafter, voters may already select the candidates they will vote for, and if they have to change their votes, they may click on the "back" button, select the candidate they wish to vote for, and complete it by clicking the "confirm" button.

Next, voters must enter their 6-digit validation code, which they will receive by email, and click the "vote" button to complete the voting process.

Voters will receive their proof of signing by email in the next hour. To leave the voting portal, voters may click on the "disconnect" button and download the receipt of their vote.

Upon entering the polling room, the voter, after having had his identity ascertained in accordance with established rules and practices or after having proved his right to vote by the production of a decision of the judge of the judicial court ordering his registration or a judgment of the Court of Cassation annulling a judgment which would have pronounced his striking off, takes, himself, an envelope. Without leaving the polling room, he must go in isolation to the part of the room set up to hide it from view while he puts his ballot in the envelope; He then makes the President declare that he is carrying only one envelope; The President notes this without touching the envelope, which the voter himself inserts into the ballot box. In polling stations equipped with a voting machine, the voter shall have his identity ascertained or proof of his right to vote under the conditions provided for in paragraph 1 and have his vote registered by the voting machine.

Note that with the following polling stations will close at a different time: Mahina / Paea / Papeete / Punaauia / Taputapuatea / Uturoa / Rurutu (07:00 pm) Ua Pou / Gambier (07:00 pm; local time is 6:30 pm in Papeete) Faa’a / Taiarapu-Est / Bora Bora (08:00 pm)

campaign_finance.details: Article L52-7 of the Electoral Code states that "a candidate may not use an election financing association and a financial agent at the same time. He may, however, use two or more intermediaries successively. In this case, the candidate must terminate the mandatary's functions or withdraw his agreement to the election financing association in the same manner as the designation or attribution of the agreement. The single deposit account is blocked until the candidate appoints a new financial agent or agrees to a new election finance association. Each association or financial agent, except in the case of the latter's death, shall draw up its management account."

government_functions.details: The President of Cyprus is the head of state and government and is directly elected with the requirement that the President must be Greek Cypriot and the Vice President must be Turkish Cypriot. Both Turkish and Greek Cypriots vote for each position. Note that the Vice Presidency has been vacant for decades due to a boycott of Cyprus' government by Turkish Cypriots.   Cyprus has a unicameral House of Representatives (Vouli Antiprosopon) that with 80 seats total. 56 seats are allocated to Greek Cypriots, 24 are allocated to Turkish Cypriots, and 3 are reserved for religious minority groups. Like the vice presidenct, the seats allocated to Turkish Cypriots are vacant.   The Supreme Court is the highest court in Cyprus and has 12 judges and 1 court president. New judges are recommended by the Supreme Court and appointed by the President.

election_commission_historical_context:
In the eighties, Guatemala faced a very particular historical and political situation, the internal war was still a reality and the Electoral Registry was the entity designated by the Executive to carry out the Elections. It was in 1982 that the history of this Institution began to take shape, the de facto Government of that time, decreed the Organic Law of the Supreme Electoral Tribunal, (Decree 30-83), in which it is already regulated as an autonomous organ, not subordinated to any other authority. The Tribunal is in charge of convening the National Constituent Assembly, which drafted the current Political Constitution of the Republic and formalized the creation of the Supreme Electoral Tribunal.

According to the new Political Constitution of the Republic, the Supreme Electoral Tribunal was created to be responsible for regulating everything related to the exercise of citizens' rights: political organizations, the exercise of political rights and the organization and operation of the electoral authorities.

From its creation to date, the Supreme Electoral Tribunal is responsible for the organization of 20 electoral processes, all of them satisfactorily, because it has guaranteed the respect for the Constitution, the Electoral and Political Parties Law, and the will of the people.

https://tse.org.gt/index.php/homepage/historia

government_functions.details: The President of Guatemala serves as both the chief of state and head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds along with the Vice President. The President serves a single 4-year term and is not eligible for reelection.  Guatemala has a unicameral Congress with 160 seats. 128 members are elected from multi-seat departmental constituencies and 32 additional members are elected in a single, nationwide constituency. All members are directly elected by closed list proportional representation vote and serve 4-year terms.  The Supreme Court of Justice is the highest court within the national judicial system. It is composed of 13 judges nominated by an expert legal panel and elected by members of Congress. Judges serve 5-year terms, and there are no term limits. There is also a Constitutional Court that is independent from the judicial system and rules only on constitutionality. The Constitutional Court consists of 5 active judges and 5 reserve judges. Each active judge is appointed by a different institution: the President, Congress, the Supreme Court, the University of San Carlos, or the Assembly of the College of Attorneys and Notaries. Constitutional Court judges serve 5-year terms, and there are no term limits.

election_name.en_US: Bosnia and Herzegovina House of Representatives 2022

government_functions.details:
The governance structure of Bosnia and Herzegovina (BiH) was established by the 1995 Dayton Accords that ended the Bosnian War. BiH is a parliamentary republic. It is comprised of three administrative divisons: Republika Srpska (primarily Serb), the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina (primarily Bosniak and Croat), and the Brcko District (primarily ethnically mixed). Each of the primary ethnic groups in Bosnia and Herzegovina (Serbs, Bosnians, and Croats) elect a president for a 4-year term. Each of these presidents serves on a rotating basis as the Chairman of the Presidency, with rotations every 8 months. 

BiH has a bicameral national parliament (called the Assembly) that consists of the House of Peoples and the House of Representatives. The House of Peoples has 15 seats, with each of the three main ethnic groups alotted 5 seats each. Members of the House of Peoples are designated by regional parliaments in the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina and Republika Srpska respectively. The House of Representatives is comprised of 42 total seats, which are split between members from Republika Srpska and the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina. 

Notably, both major entities in BiH have their own regional parliamentary systems. In Republika Srpska, there is a unicameral National Assembly with 83 seats. In the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, there is a bicameral parliament with a total of approximately 180 seats split between the two houses. The Brcko District also has its own governance structure, but does not directly feed into the National Assembly in the same way. 

The judiciary in Bosnia and Herzegovina is comprised of the Constitutional Court and the Court of BiH, as well as a variety of cantonal and municipal courts. Members of the Constitutional Court are selected by the President of the European Court of Human Rights in consultation with the tripartite presidency. Note that Republika Srpska has begun the process of splitting away from the jurisdiction of the broader judiciary in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

voting_methods.instructions:
Voters normally vote at the polling station at which they are recorded on the voter register, which is their place of permanent residence (internally displaced persons may vote in their area of displacement if they so choose).                                     

Internally displaced persons have the right to either vote in the polling station of their temporary residence, provided such residence has been kept for at least six months, or in special "absentee" polling stations for the electoral unit where they were registered before being displaced. 

The polling official determines the identify of the voter on the basis of one of three types of valid identification documents. Proxy voting is not allowed. Once the voter is identified, the polling official marks the voter's name in the voter register, the voter signs the voter register next to his or her name (must correspond to signature on ID), and a ballot is issued to the voter. Voters who are not found on the voter list on election day and can present a valid identification card and proof of residence are allowed to vote. 

To cast their vote, the voter proceeds to the polling booth to vote in secret. The voter can choose one of the following options on the ballot: (1) an independent candidate, if any; (2) a political party, coalition or list of independent candidates; or (3) within one list of candidates, mark one or more candidates on the one list chosen by the voter. If the voter spoils his or her ballot, a new ballot can be obtained upon returning the spoiled ballot to the polling station committee. Upon marking the ballot, the voter proceeds to insert it into the sealed ballot box.

A blind, illiterate or bodily incapacitated person can request from the president of the polling station committee to allow another person selected by the voter to assist him or her to sign the voter register and cast his or her ballot. The helper cannot be a polling official or election observer, and can help only one voter; the helper must sign the voter register next to the name of the voter he or she assisted. Homebound voters and those voters confined in places of detention can vote via mobile ballot boxes.

Source: 2001 Election Law Articles 1.4 (2), 3.9 (1-4), 3.16 (6), 3.17 (1-3), 5.1 (1), 5.8 (1), 5.8, 5.10, 5.11 (1-2), 5.12 (1-5), 5.13(1-2), 5.14 (1-3), 5.18 (1-2), 5.19 (1-4), 5.20, 5.21 (2)

Out-of-country voters can choose to vote either in-person at one of the designated embassies or consulates or by mail. They must submit an submit an application to the Central Election Commission of BiH for every elections. Proof of identity of the applicant as prescribed by this law and accurate details of the address abroad, as well as a declaration concerning the voting option: in a diplomatic and consular representation office (DCRO) or by mail, shall be attached to the application, signed by the applicant.

Out-of-country voters wishing to vote by-mail must submit an application to be registered as a by-mail voter for each election to the central election commission for each election. Proof of identity of the applicant by way of a legally acceptable identification document and details of the address abroad must be provided. Those who register for out-of-country voting are removed from the main voter list in their regular polling station.  The manner and procedure of by-mail out-of-country voting is to be regulated by the central election commission. In order for a timely delivered by mail ballot to be counted, it must be returned by a voter who has been determined to be properly registered to vote by mail, sealed in the ballot envelope to ensure secrecy of the person’s vote, and accompanied by a copy of one of the legally acceptable identification documents.

A person registered as an out-of-country voter who has returned from abroad and wants to vote in-person in the country is entitled to vote by 'tendered' ballot. Tendered ballots are put by the voter into a sealed envelope bearing the voters identification information (which is then inserted into the ballox box) and later counted only after the envelope is forwarded to the central election body and the voter's information is checked against the central voter register.

Source: 2001 Election Law Articles 5.21 (1), 5.28 (3)

government_functions.details: The executive power is held by the President of the Republic who is also Head of the Government. The Parliament is made up of a single Assembly, called the National Assembly, whose 65 members hold the title of Deputy.  The National Assembly exercises the legislative power. It alone has the power to pass laws by simple majority. The judicial power is independent of the legislative power and the executive power. It is exercised by the Supreme Court, the Court of Accounts and the other Courts and Tribunals.

In addition, the voter's vote is recorded by the affixing of the imprint of his left thumb in indelible ink in front of his name in the presence of the members of the office.  Civil servants, military and magistrates on a mission, and all other persons traveling for reasons of service may vote outside of their place of registration.  1992 Electoral Law Chapter V Section 2 Article 47 and 49
