Upon receiving the ballot paper from the voting officer, the voter must take the ballot paper to a vacant voting compartment in the voting station. Voters must cast their votes by putting a tick or a cross in the square adjacent to the candidate's name whom the applicant wishes to vote. After voting, the voters must fold the ballot and hand their ballot to the voting station manager or the voting station officer for checking, have an indelible mark on their finger, and place the ballot paper in the ballot box in the presence of the voting station officer; voters must leave the voting station immediately after voting.

government_functions.details:
The governance structure of Bosnia and Herzegovina (BiH) was established by the 1995 Dayton Accords that ended the Bosnian War. BiH is a parliamentary republic. It is comprised of three administrative divisons: Republika Srpska (primarily Serb), the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina (primarily Bosniak and Croat), and the Brcko District (primarily ethnically mixed). Each of the primary ethnic groups in Bosnia and Herzegovina (Serbs, Bosnians, and Croats) elect a president for a 4-year term. Each of these presidents serves on a rotating basis as the Chairman of the Presidency, with rotations every 8 months. 

BiH has a bicameral national parliament (called the Assembly) that consists of the House of Peoples and the House of Representatives. The House of Peoples has 15 seats, with each of the three main ethnic groups alotted 5 seats each. Members of the House of Peoples are designated by regional parliaments in the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina and Republika Srpska respectively. The House of Representatives is comprised of 42 total seats, which are split between members from Republika Srpska and the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina. 

Notably, both major entities in BiH have their own regional parliamentary systems. In Republika Srpska, there is a unicameral National Assembly with 83 seats. In the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, there is a bicameral parliament with a total of approximately 180 seats split between the two houses. The Brcko District also has its own governance structure, but does not directly feed into the National Assembly in the same way. 

The judiciary in Bosnia and Herzegovina is comprised of the Constitutional Court and the Court of BiH, as well as a variety of cantonal and municipal courts. Members of the Constitutional Court are selected by the President of the European Court of Human Rights in consultation with the tripartite presidency. Note that Republika Srpska has begun the process of splitting away from the jurisdiction of the broader judiciary in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

voting_methods.instructions: Out-of-country voters wishing to vote by mail must submit an application to be registered as a by-mail voter for each election to the central election commission for each election. Proof of identity of the applicant by way of a legally acceptable identification document and details of the address abroad must be provided. Those who register for out-of-country voting are removed from the main voter list in their regular polling station.  The manner and procedure of by-mail out-of-country voting is to be regulated by the central election commission. In order for a timely delivered by mail ballot to be counted, it must be returned by a voter who has been determined to be properly registered to vote by mail, sealed in the ballot envelope to ensure secrecy of the person’s vote, and accompanied by a copy of one of the legally acceptable identification documents.  Source: 2001 Election Law Articles 5.21(1) and 5.28(3)

Voters normally vote at the polling station at which they are recorded on the voter register, which is their place of permanent residence (internally displaced persons may vote in their area of displacement if they so choose).                                            Internally displaced persons have the right to either vote in the polling station of their temporary residence, provided such residence has been kept for at least six months, or in special "absentee" polling stations for the electoral unit where they were registered before being displaced.   The polling official determines the identity of the voter on the basis of one of three types of valid identification documents. Proxy voting is not allowed. Once the voter is identified, the polling official marks the voter's name in the voter register, the voter signs the voter register next to his or her name (must correspond to signature on ID), and a ballot is issued to the voter. Voters who are not found on the voter list on election day and  can present a valid identification card and proof of residence are allowed to vote.   To cast their vote, the voter proceeds to the polling booth to vote in secret. The voter marks their one preferred candidate on the ballot. If the voter spoils his or her ballot, a new ballot can be obtained upon returning the spoiled ballot to the polling station committee. Upon marking the ballot, the voter proceeds to insert it into the sealed ballot box.  A person registered as an out-of-country voter who has returned from abroad and wants to vote in-person in the country is entitled to vote by 'tendered' ballot. Tendered ballots are put by the voter into a sealed envelope bearing the voters identification information (which is then inserted into the ballox box) and later counted only after the envelope is forwarded to the central election body and the voter's information is checked against the central voter register.  A blind, illiterate or bodily incapacitated person can request from the president of the polling station committee to allow another person selected by the voter to assist him or her to sign the voter register and cast his or her ballot. The helper cannot be a polling official or election observer, and can help only one voter; the helper must sign the voter register next to the name of the voter he or she assisted.  Homebound voters and those voters confined in places of detention can vote via mobile ballot boxes.  Source: 2001 Election Law Articles 1.4 (2), 3.9 (1-4), 3.16 (6), 3.17 (1-3), 5.1 (1), 5.8 (1), 5.10, 5.11 (1-2), 5.12 (1-5), 5.13 (1-2), 5.14 (1-3), 5.18 (1-2), 5.19 (1-4), 5.20, 5.21 (2)

government_functions.details: In Uzbekistan, the President serves as chief of state, while the Prime Minister serves as head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two 7-year terms. The Prime Minister is nominated by the majority party in the Supreme Assembly and appointed by the President.   Uzbekistan has a bicameral Supreme Assembly consisting of a 100-seat Senate and a 150-seat Legislative Chamber. Members of the Senate are indirectly elected by regional councils (84 members) or appointed by the president (16 members). All members serve 5-year terms. All 150 members of the Legislative Chamber are directly elected by absolute majority vote in single-seat constituencies and serve 5-year terms.  The Supreme Court and Constitutional Court are the highest judicial bodies of Uzbekistan. The Supreme Court has 67 judges, while the Constitutional Court has only 7. Judges for both institutions are nominated by the President and confirmed by the Senate. Judges may serve one term of 10 years.

voting_methods.instructions: Note that military and security personal can be allowed to vote 72 hours early if some conditions are met. (Art 64). There is no proxy voting allowed in CAR. The Code provides for OCV voting when there are more than 200 persons abroad.
Ballot box with one transparent side; Paper ballot; sealed boxes with serial number.

The secrecy of the vote is guaranteed and proxy voting is prohibited. Voters who are on the voter list and who are resident and domiciled in the polling station district are given ballot papers upon presentation of any of the listed identification documents.  Voters domiciled in the polling station district who are not on the list can register on election day, as can persons who do not have a registered domicile or residence. Voters who come with an (absentee) voting certificate can vote in any polling station.  Voters confirm receipt of the ballot by signing the voters lists next to their name. A stamp is affixed on their ID slip or on the document based on which they vote to confirm they have voted. The voter must mark the ballot in a secret voting booth/room only. Voters who are unable to fill in the ballot him/herself can be assisted by someone they invite in the booth (except poll members, partisan agents, and election observers.) The ballots are marked with a "voted" stamp in the chosen circle. Voters can get one replacement ballot if they have spoilt their ballot. The voter is to insert the ballot in the ballot box. On written request, home (mobile) voting is available for voters who cannot come to the polling station due to health or other grounded reason.

election_commission_historical_context: The Autonomous National Electoral Commission (CENA) is a Beninese administrative body responsible for organizing and supervising elections in Benin.  It was created in 1995 to concretize and strengthen the democratic process initiated in Benin since the National Conference of Vital Forces of February 1990, which opened the way to democratic rule.  The very first presidential and legislative elections in 1991 were organized by the Ministry of the Interior, while all others were organized by this non-permanent commission before the 2013 electoral code.  The autonomous national electoral commission has undergone a number of changes in accordance with the electoral laws governing each election.1  In 1990, Benin, after adopting a democratic system following the national conference, undertook reforms to ensure the performance and transparency of the electoral system.  With the end of the era of monolithism imposed by the 1977 Fundamental Law, the election ceased to be a mere formality, a ritual of legitimization and ratification of the choices made by the single party and the National Revolutionary Assembly (NRA), which led to some contestation of the administration [unclear] 2.  The neutrality recognized in the administration was contested, and serious doubts about its ability to organize honest elections gained prominence as a result of the euphoria over the success of the National Conference. The Ministry of the Interior retained its prerogatives with regard to the organization of elections just for the 1990 constituent referendum and the 1991 presidential and legislative elections, assisted by the National Committee in charge of monitoring elections, created by ministerial order No. 130/MISAT/MDN/MF/DC/SA of October 23, 1990. The committee's mission is to monitor the material organization of the referendum and electoral consultations during the transition period, ensure strict compliance with the texts in force, and coordinate the actions of the various ministerial departments involved in organizing the referendum and electoral operations.  After the 1991 elections, there were two antagonistic blocs: the movement organized around the Head of the Executive and the opposition, which controlled the office of the Parliament. On the eve of the 1995 legislative elections, a climate of suspicion and doubt was expressed by the opposition about the ability of the Ministry of the Interior to organize an electoral competition, despite its experience in organizing the 1991 presidential elections and the 1991 legislative elections without major disputes.2  In 1993, the opposition, united in the National Convention of the Forces of Change, petitioned the President of the Republic for the creation of an Independent Electoral Commission, the only guarantee of truly transparent elections. Supported by civil society organizations, despite the disapproval of President Nicephore Soglo, the then Head of State, for the creation of this independent commission, the opposition succeeded in introducing and passing the law creating the Autonomous National Electoral Commission (CENA) in the National Assembly on September 15, 1994, the day before the 1995 legislative elections.  The Head of State's appeal for unconstitutionality dated November 30, 1994 did not succeed in the Constitutional Court, which ruled in favor of the Parliament2.  The promulgation of law N° 94-013 of January 17, 1995, on the general rules for the elections of the President of the Republic and the members of the National Assembly, put an end to all suspicions of electoral fraud in Benin. Law N° 94-014 of January 27, 1995 on the electoral code in the Republic of Benin institutes ANEC and Law N° 94-015 of January 27, 1995 defines its mode of operation

government_functions.details: The President of Benin serves as chief of state and head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two 5-year terms.  Benin has a unicameral National Assembly with 109 members. All members are directly elected by list proportional representation vote within multi-seat constituencies and serve 5-year terms.  Benin has several high courts with different legal domains. The Supreme Court has 17 judges who are appointed by the President and serve up to two 5-year terms. The Constitutional Court has 7 judges who are appointed by either the National Assembly or the President and serve up to two 5-year terms. The High Court of Justice forms only to try high treason cases involving national government officials. It is formed from 6 judges of the Constitutional Court who are selected by the National Assembly and Supreme Court president.

voting_methods.instructions: The voter applies to the Chief Electoral Officer to vote in advance, is issued with a ballot paper and envelope marked "Vote in Advance of Poll".  The applicant then alone and secretly votes by striking out the names of all candidates but the one for whom they wish to vote, places the ballot paper in the envelope, seals it, and then delivers it to the Chief Electoral Officer.  The Chief Electoral Officer shall hold the envelope and the voter's declaration securely until polling day when the envelope will be delivered to the presiding officer of the relevant polling place.  The presiding officer will open the envelopes and, without unfolding the ballot papers, place them in the ballot box,

The voter, having received their ballot papers, shall immediately retire into one of the inner compartments provided for the purpose in the polling place, and shall there alone and secretly vote by marking their ballot papers by striking out, in the case of the village constituency paper,  the name of every candidate except the one for whom they wish to vote, or in the case of the common roll, for those for whom they wish to vote.  They must then fold the papers before leaving the compartment so the contents cannot be seen, and then deposit them so folded in the ballot box.

government_functions.details:
The President of French Polynesia is indirectly elected by the Assembly from among its members. The President may serve up to two 5-year terms.

In the Assembly, 38 members are directly elected via absolute majority, closed-list vote in multi-seat constituencies in up to two rounds. Only lists receiving at least 12.5% of the total vote can advance to the second round, but parties may combine their votes and lists to meet this requirement. The remaining 19 seats are allocated to the party that receives the most votes. All members serve 5-year terms.

Within the French legislature, French Polynesia directly elects three deputies of the National Assembly via absolute majority vote in up to two rounds. French Polynesia indirectly elects two members of the Senate via an electoral college, and one senate seat is contested every three years. Deputies serve 5-year terms, and senators serve 6-year terms.

election_commission_historical_context: Constitution, Section V. Of the Electoral Justice Article 273. Of the Competence The convocation, the judgment, the organization, the direction, the supervision and the surveillance of the acts and issues [cuestiones] derived from the general, departmental and municipal elections as well as of the rights and of the titles of those who are [resulten] elected, correspond exclusively to the Electoral Justice. The issues originating from any type of popular consultation, as well as that relative to the elections and to the functioning of the political parties and movements are equally of its competence. Article 274. Of the Integration The Electoral Justice is integrated by a Superior Electoral Tribunal, by the tribunals, by the courts, by the offices of the Attorney [fiscalia] and by the other organs [organismos] to be specified by the law, which will determine its organization and its functions. Article 275. Of the Superior Tribunal of Electoral Justice The Superior Tribunal of Electoral Justice will be composed of three members, who will be elected and removed in the form established for the Ministers of the Supreme Court of Justice. The members of the Superior Tribunal of Electoral Justice must meet the following requirements: to be of Paraguayan nationality, to be already thirty-five years old, to possess a university degree of lawyer, and, during the term of ten years, at least, to have effectively exercised the profession or performed functions in the judicial magistrature, or exercised [a] university chair in juridical matters, jointly, separately, or alternatively. The laws will establish in which cases its resolutions will be subject to recourse [recurribles] before the Supreme Court of Justice, which will decide [resolverá] in summary proceeding.

government_functions.details: The President of Paraguay serves as both chief of state and head of government. The President is directly elected by plurality vote and serves a single 5-year term. The president and vice president are elected as a slate.  Paraguay has a bicameral consisting of a 45-seat Chamber of Senators and an 80-seat Chamber of Deputies. All 45 senators are directly elected by closed-list proportional representation vote from a single, nationwide constituency. Senators serve 5-year terms. All 80 deputies are directly elected by closed-list proportional vote in 18 multi-seat constituencies (departments). Deputies serve 5-year terms.   The Supreme Court of Justice is Paraguay's highest court. It is made up of 9 justices who are nominated by the Council of Magistrates and confirmed by the Chamber of Senators and the President. Justices may serve until age 75.

The definitive or temporary vacancies of the Chamber of Deputies will be filled by the substitutes elected for the same department, and those of the Chamber of Senators will be filled by the substitutes of the list proclaimed by the Electoral Justice.

voting_methods.instructions: This is designed to help you understand the Voting Procedures during an election. Remember that you are qualified to vote if you are a registered voter and your name appears on the register of voters at your polling.  Opening of the Polling Units: On each Election Day, polling stations will open for Accreditation and Voting from 8:00 am to 2.00 pm. However, voters on the queue before the close of poll at 2:00pm will be accredited and allowed to vote.  Voting Procedure: Voting at the polling unit will be as follows:  Step 1:  At the polling unit, join the queue. An INEC official will check if you are at the correct polling unit and confirm that the PVC presented belongs to you.  Step 2:  An INEC official will confirm if your PVC is genuine using the card reader. You will be asked to place your finger on the card reader.  Step 3:  An INEC official will ask for your PVC and confirm you are listed in the Voters Register. Your name will be ticked and your finger will be inked to confirm you have voted. If your name is not found you cannot vote.  Step 4:  The Presiding officer will stamp, sign and endorse your ballot paper. You will be given the ballot paper rolled with the printed side inwards and directed to the voting cubicle.  Step 5:  Stain your finger with the ink given and mark the box for your preferred candidate/party. Roll the ballot paper in the manner you were given and flatten it.  Step 6:  Leave the voting cubicle and drop the ballot paper in the ballot box in full view of people at the Polling Unit.  Step 7:  Leave the Polling Unit or wait if you so choose, in an orderly and peaceful manner, to watch the process up to declaration of result.  N.B: The result of each Polling Unit shall be pasted at the unit for everyone to see.  Your right as a voter:  On each Election Day, you have the right to:  Access the polling station Receive information on the voting procedures from the poll officials Vote in secret. Responsibility of the Voter:  Obey all lawful instructions from the INEC and Security Officials on election duty. Leave the polling unit or wait if you so choose in an orderly and peaceful manner. Encourage other voters to do likewise.

government_functions.details: Turkey is a presidential republic. The President serves as both the chief of state and head of government. The president is directly elected for a 5-year term and is eligible to serve two terms.   Turkey has a unicameral Grand National Assembly (Buyuk Millet Meclisi) which has 600 members. Members are directly elected in multi-seat constituencies to serve 5-year terms.   The highest courts are the Constitutional Court (Anayasa Mahkemesi), Court of Cassation, and the Council of State.

election_commission_historical_context: Election management is divided into three levels in Montenegro; the State Election Commission (SEC) at the national level, Municipal Election Commissions (MECs) at the sub-national level, and Polling Boards (PBs) at the polling station level. The SEC and MECs are permanent bodies that serve four-year terms, and MECs manage the appointment of the PBs for each election. Article 18 of the Law on Election Counselors and Members of Parliament determines that election management bodies should operate in both permanent composition (standard appointed members) and extended composition. The Parliament appoints the permanent composition of the SEC, consisting of 10 members and a president. The SEC includes four members from the parliamentary majority, four from the parliamentary opposition, one from the minority entity that received the most votes in the previous election, and one from civil society or academia. The SEC’s main responsibilities include coordinating MECs, overseeing election materials, reviewing and publishing official candidate lists, and ascertaining and publishing election results.  Municipal assemblies appoint the permanent composition of MECs, consisting of a president and four permanent members. In extended composition, the same nominating entity that submits a candidate for the presidency also nominates an individual’s membership in the extended composition. MECs determine the number and location of polling stations across the country in addition to determining the number of ballots needed for each polling station. The presidential election is administered by the SEC, 25 MECs, and approximately 1,200 PBs.

government_functions.details:
Montenegro is a parliamentary republic. The Prime Minister is nominated by the president and approved by the Assembly. The President is directly elected in a two rounds of voting if necessarily. Voters in Montenegro must have resided in the country for a minimum of 10 of the past 15 years. 

The unicameral Skupstina or Assembly has 81 seats with all members directly elected in a single nationwide constituency. Members serve for four years unless snap elections are called by the President of Montenegro, the government, or a minimum of 25 members of parliament. 

The judiciary is comprised of the Supreme Court (Vrhovni Sud), which has 17 members including a court president and deputy president, as well as the Constitutional Court (Ustavni Sud).

voting_methods.instructions: Article 67 Voters shall cast their votes at polling stations in which they have been included into the extract from the electoral register. As an exception to the provision of para.1 of this Article, voters may vote by post outside of the polling station in which they have been included into the extract from the electoral register, under the conditions laid down in this Law. The manner of voting outside of the polling station, as well as the number of voters who have thus exercised their voting right shall be entered into a record of polling board work. More detailed rules on postal voting shall be laid down by the State Election Commission.  Article 85 Voters who are unable, due to old age, disability, inpatient or outpatient medical treatment, to vote at the polling station where their names are on the extract from the electoral register and who wish to vote, shall submit an application to vote by post to the polling board, using the prescribed form. Voters who wish to vote by post shall personally sign the form referred to in para.1 of this Article. The application to vote by post shall be submitted to the polling board at the polling station at the latest until 13:00h on polling day. The application to vote by post may be submitted to the polling board at the polling station only by the person authorised by the signature of the postal voting applicant to do so. One person may not submit to the polling board more than one application to vote by post, except where he is doing so for two or more voters voting by post and living in the same household. The authorisation to deliver the application to vote by post to the polling board shall be an integral part of the form referred to in para.1 of this Article. The form referred to in para.1 of this Article shall be prescribed by the State Election Commission. ID card or passport of the voter wishing to vote by post shall be submitted to the polling board together with the application to vote by post and the authorisation to deliver the application to vote by post to the polling board. Article 85a Upon receipt of the application to vote by post, the polling board shall check the identity of the person who brought the application to vote by post, ascertain if the person wishing to vote by post is on the electoral register and evaluate the reasons for postal voting.

Article 80 Voters shall state their name and surname to the polling board and prove their identity via a biometric ID card or passport. Voters may not vote without presenting evidence of their identity. Having ascertained the identity of a voter, polling board presiding officer or member shall circle the ordinal number under which voter has been included into the extract from the candidate list, explain to him how to vote and hand over the ballot paper.

government_functions.details:
Australia is a parliamentary democracy that is a part of the British Commonwealth. As such, the chief of state is the British Monarch. The monarchy is hereditary. The monarch appoints an in-country representative called a governor on the recommendation of the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister is the leader of the majority party or majority coalition in government. 

Australian parliament is bicameral, with a 76-seat Senate and a 151-seat House of Representatives. Both houses are directly elected. The Senate is comprised of six senators for each original state (per the Constitution), with a provision that additional seats can be apportioned should new state be recognized. Senators serve six-year terms. The House of Representatives is intende to comprise twice the number of Senators. Seats in the House are apportioned by population.

The highest court in Australia is the High Court of Australia. Additionally, there are a variety of state and territory courts.

government_functions.details: The President of Ecuador serves as both head of government and head of state.  The president is directly elected by plurality of at least 40% and a 10% differential to the runner-up vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two consecutive 4-year terms.  The National Assembly shall be comprised of Fifteen (15) Assembly persons elected as representatives of the nation as a whole (national district). Two (2) Assembly persons elected for each province, plus one (1) additional Assembly person for every two hundred thousand (200,000) inhabitants or fraction thereof over one hundred fifty thousand (150,000), on the basis of the last national population census.  The jurisdictional bodies, without detriment to the other bodies with equal powers recognized in the Constitution, are those in charge of administering justice and they shall be as follows: The National Court of Justice. The provincial courts of justice. The courts and tribunals provided for by law. The justices of the peace.

The President of Guatemala serves as both the chief of state and head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds along with the Vice President. The President serves a single 4-year term and is not eligible for reelection.  Guatemala has a unicameral Congress with 160 seats. 128 members are elected from multi-seat departmental constituencies and 32 additional members are elected in a single, nationwide constituency. All members are directly elected by closed list proportional representation vote and serve 4-year terms.  The Supreme Court of Justice is the highest court within the national judicial system. It is composed of 13 judges nominated by an expert legal panel and elected by members of Congress. Judges serve 5-year terms, and there are no term limits. There is also a Constitutional Court that is independent from the judicial system and rules only on constitutionality. The Constitutional Court consists of 5 active judges and 5 reserve judges. Each active judge is appointed by a different institution: the President, Congress, the Supreme Court, the University of San Carlos, or the Assembly of the College of Attorneys and Notaries. Constitutional Court judges serve 5-year terms, and there are no term limits.

voting_methods.instructions: Secrecy of the vote is guaranteed and proxy voting is not allowed. Voters must prove their identity with a biometric ID card or passport. Electronic voter identification devices are to be used at polling stations and each voter is to be identified electronically. Upon receiving a stamped ballot voters are to sign the printed extract of the voter register and poll worker is to circle the ordinal number. Voters are to be explained how to vote; they must circle the ordinal number or name of the chosen competitor. Voters must mark the ballot only in a private polling booth. If a voter votes outside the booth or shows anyone his/her ballot, the polling board is to invalidate the ballot.  Voters must fold the ballot personally, and leave the counterfoil unobstructed, and while holding the ballot folded ballot in their hands, they are to go to the ballot box and allow the designated poll worker to detach the counterfoil from the ballot. The poll worker is to personally sign the overleaf of the counterfoil and store the counterfoils in serial number order. The voter is to put the ballot in the ballot box. A disabled or illiterate voter can be assisted by a person of their choice in marking the ballot  (not by a poll worker or partisan representative).

government_functions.details:
The Czech Republic or Czechia is a parliamentary republic. The President is directly elected and serves a five-year term. The President appoints the Prime Minister. 

Czech parliament consists of the 81-seat Senate and the 200-seat Chamber of Deputies. Both houses are directly elected. 

The judiciary is comprised of the Supreme Court, the Supreme Administrative Court, and the Constitutional Court. Supreme Court judges are proposed by the lower house of parliament and are appointed for life.

voting_methods.instructions:
Out-of-country voting is available in-person at embassies/consulates or by postal voting for eligible voters permanently or temporarily abroad. According to the website of the election management body, in-person voting abroad is held on election day from 9:00 am - 5:00 pm (local time).  Voting procedures are the same as at a polling station in Slovenia.

Persons enrolled in the voter register of citizens who do not have permanent residence in Slovenia (i.e. those with permanent residence abroad) will be sent the postal ballot paper in due time. Persons who are (or will be) temporarily abroad on election day and wish to vote by post must notify the national authorities no later than thirty days prior to the election day.

Persons enrolled in the voter register of citizens who do not have permanent residence in Slovenia (i.e. those with permanent residence abroad) will be sent the postal ballot paper in due time. Persons who are (or will be) temporarily abroad on election day and wish to vote by post must notify the national authorities no later than thirty days prior to the election day.  Voters who are in detention, prison, in a hospital, or in a social protection institution for institutional care and wish to vote by post must submit their intention to the local electoral commission or the constituency electoral commission at least ten days prior to polling day (or within five days for those entering detention facilities, social care institutions, or hospitals, or declared to have a disability after the deadline). The postal voting materials will be sent to the address indicated in the voter register or in the application and will include instructions on the method of voting by post.   A postal vote is cast on an official empty ballot paper containing the mark of the constituency and of the electoral district, and voters express their will by entering, personally or otherwise, in the appropriate space on the ballot paper the name and surname of the candidate for whom they are voting, or the name of the list of candidates for which they are voting.  Postal voters must send the completed ballot paper and personally signed voting card to the address of the competent local electoral commission (the address will already by printed on the return envelope enclosed). According to the website of the election management body, postal voters abroad can choose to deliver the postal ballot to the Slovenian embassy/consulate where the polling station is located (deliver before that polling station closes on election day.)  Source: 1992 National Assembly Elections Act Articles 81 and 82

Voters who will be absent on polling day may vote early at a special polling station at the headquarters of the local electoral commission where they are listed in the voter register (at the administrative unit where they are registered as a permanent resident). Voting procedures are the same as those applicable to election day voting. After each closure of early voting, ballot boxes and other voting material shall be sealed; they shall be opened for each resumption of early voting and prior to the establishment of the results of the voting.  Source: 1992 National Assembly Elections Act Article 69

Voters usually vote at the polling station at which they are registered to vote, that is where they have permanent residence (or if they do not have permanent residence, in the place of their, or one of their parent's, last permanent residence). However, a voter can apply with the local electoral commission up to three days before election day for absentee voting if they will not be at their district of registered permanent residence on election day, including voters who permanently reside abroad and are to be in Slovenia on election day. Absentee voting allows a voter to vote outside the regular polling station where he or she has permanent residence, at a designated polling station without territorial jurisdiction.  Hungarian and Italian national community voters residing outside of their bilingual municipalities have the opportunity to vote for their respective deputy in their place of residence anywhere in Slovenia and abroad.  At the polling station, voters give their name and surname (and if necessary their address) and the election committee official will determine the voter's identity using any personal identification document that shows the voter's personal data, or in some other manner. Proxy voting is not allowed. The electoral official then circles the serial number before the name on the voter register and the voter signs next to his or her name. The ballot paper(s) is then handed to the voter. Voters are entitled to one ballot, except members of the Italian and Hungarian national communities (which each have one deputy in the parliament) are entitled to a regular ballot and a ballot to vote for their respective ethnic miniority deputy, provided that the person is registered as a minority voter.  If requested by the voter, the election official must explain the technical aspects of the voting. If by mistake, a voter is not entered on the voter register, he or she may vote on the basis of a certificate issued by the competent body stating that he or she is enrolled as a voter in the area of that polling station. If the name of a person who wishes to vote has already been circled on the voter register and there is a signature next to the name, or if there is a note that the person is registered to vote by another method, this fact should be entered in the records, but the voter will not be allowed to vote.  Once issued the ballot(s), voters proceed to vote in secret in the polling booth as follows: (1) for the general ballot, the voter shall vote by circling the serial number before the name of the (one) candidate for whom he or she wishes to vote and (2) for the Hungarian and Italian national community ballot, the minority voter shall vote by circling the serial number before the name of the (one) candidate for whom he or she wishes to vote. The voter then proceeds to insert the ballot(s) in the ballot box.  Persons with disabilities can be assisted in voting by a person of their choice. Voters who are disabled or illiterate and not able to vote independently, can be assisted by a person of their choice to complete and cast the ballot paper(s).  Mobile voting is available for ill (and disabled?) voters who cannot vote in person at the polling station where they are registered to vote, whereby the election committee visits their home to facilitate their voting. Applications for mobile voting must be made no later than three days before polling day.  Source: 1992 National Assembly Elections Act Articles 7-9, 71-75, 79a

voting_methods.instructions: In general, the voter must show the unsigned postal vote certificate (declaration)  and unmarked ballot paper to an authorized witness, must complete and sign the certificate in the presence of the witness, the witness must c, sign and date the certificate and note on it their capacity to act.  Then the voter must mark their paper in the presence of the witness but so as the witness cannot see the vote, fold the paper, seal it in the envelope.  The voter and the witness must both declare on the certificate (which forms part of the envelope) that these steps were completed before the close of the poll.  the person must then post or deliver the envelope to the Divisional Returning Officer for which they are enrolled.  There are some exceptions to some of these requirements for persons registered as a general postal voter or for persons voting from outside Australia.

You can vote at an early voting center, or if you're overseas, at an overseas voting center.  Where a voter is voting at an early voting center within their district and is on the certified roll they may vote in the same way they do on polling day (that is, they are marked off the roll, they are issued with ballot papers which they mark in a booth and place in the appropriate ballot box.  If not, they must first complete a declaration in front of the issuing officer, mark their voting paper in the presence of the issuing officer without letting the officer see the vote, fold the ballot paper and give it to the issuing officer who puts it into the envelope containing the declaration.  The issuing officer fastens the envelope and secures it in a ballot box.  You can vote early either in person or by post if on election day you: •    are outside the electorate where you are enrolled to vote •    are more than 8km from a polling place •    are travelling •    are unable to leave your workplace to vote •    are seriously ill, infirm or due to give birth shortly (or caring for someone who is) •    are a patient in hospital and can't vote at the hospital •    have religious beliefs that prevent you from attending a polling place •    are in prison serving a sentence of less than three years or otherwise detained •    are a silent elector •    have a reasonable fear for your safety.  While this is technically true, it in practice is not enforced.

The Senate ballot paper is divided into two parts.  'Above the line' the party or groups contesting the election are listed.  'Below the line' all the candidates contesting the election are listed  (including those who have been nominated by the parties and groups listed above the line).  A voter may choose to vote above or below the line.  If voting above the line, the voter is accepting the order of candidates as determined by the parties or groups.  The voter indicates their preferences by writing the number 1 against the first preference and must mark at least 6 preferences (or if there are fewer than six parties or groups, all of them). If the voter chooses to vote below the line, they must mark their preferences by writing the numbers 1 up to, at least, 12 (unless there are fewer than 12 candidates).  For Senate, Above The Line papers with a single '1'  and Below The Line papers with a sequence of at least 1 through 6 (or in either case any number of additional preferences above those minimums) are considered formal for the purposes of counting.

voting_methods.instructions:
Voters abroad can vote either in person at diplomatic representations 24 days before election day or by mail 45 days before election day.

If you are outside Sweden, you can vote by post or in advance at many Swedish embassies and consulates. To vote by post, you must use special materials that you can order from the Swedish Election Authority, your municipality, or a Swedish embassy or consulate. You can send a postal ballot from abroad from 28 July for the 2022 elections. You can vote in advance at a Swedish embassy or consulate from 18 August.

Voters can vote in advance in designated polling stations during 18 days before the election day.  Vote in advance in either your own or another municipality You can vote in advance at any voting location in Sweden. Advance voting in Sweden will take place from 24 August 2022 up to election day. You must bring your voting card with you when voting in advance. You can find out where to vote in advance from your municipality or on val.se.

Who can vote? To be eligible to vote, an individual must be at least 18 years old on election day. The details listed in the Swedish Population Register 30 days before election day determine whether you are eligible to vote, and which electoral district you belong to.  You are eligible to vote in Riksdag elections if you are: a Swedish citizen, and you are or have been listed in the Swedish Population Register. You are entitled to vote in local council elections for your municipality and region if you are: a Swedish citizen, and you are listed in the Swedish Population Register a citizen of an EU country, Iceland or Norway, and you are listed in the Swedish Population Register a citizen of any other country, and you have been listed in the Swedish Population Register for three consecutive years before election day Those who are eligible to vote receive a voting card Those who are eligible to vote are sent a voting card by post about three weeks before election day. Your voting card will state the elections in which you are entitled to vote, as well as the name, address and opening hours of your polling station. If your voting card is missing, you can order a new one from your municipality or the Swedish Election Authority.  Ballot papers Ballot papers are yellow for Riksdag elections, white for municipal council elections and blue for regional council elections. There are ballot papers at every voting location.  Voting for a party You vote primarily for a party. The name of the party is on the ballot paper. If you cannot find a ballot paper for your party of choice, you can write the name of the party on a blank ballot paper.  Specifying a candidate If you want a particular candidate to be elected, you can put a cross in the check box before that candidate’s name on your named ballot paper. You can only put a cross in one check box for one candidate. You can also specify a candidate by stating both the name of a party and your preferred candidate on a blank ballot paper.

voting_methods.instructions: Voters wishing to vote by mail must attend in person at an Electoral Commission office in their district, establish their identity and eligibility (authenticated by a document from their superior or employer).  They are issued with ballot paper and envelopes which they complete there and then.  The Electoral Commission then posts the ballot, voter card and supporting document to the voter's polling station.  The voter marks with a cross the square corresponding to the candidacy for which the voter votes, or does not indicate any, and then folds the paper in four and hands to the president of the polling place who puts it in the ballot box.  Postal voting is limited to military personnel or security force officers who are unable to attend because of duties or health workers, seafarers, airport staff who are presumed unable to attend at a polling place because of professional responsibiities.  See Art 124 & 125 of the Electoral Law

A voter must vote at the polling place for which they are registered (Art 105).  To vote they must be registered in the census book and have their identity recognised by polling place officials (Art 107).  The voter marks with a cross the square corresponding to the candidacy for which the voter votes, or does not indicate any, and then folds the paper in four and hands to the president of the polling place who puts it in the ballot box.   See Art 105, 107 & 122 of the Electoral Law

voting_methods.instructions: After voter registration, the ballot will be stamped with the elections stamp and the Supervisory Board stamp by the official responsible for registration and the Supervisory Board monitor, respectively. After separating [the ballot from the registration paper], the ballot will be returned to the voter. After obtaining the ballot, the voter will write on the ballot the first and last name and other specifics of his or her preferred candidate or candidates. In case the first and last names of the candidates have already been printed on the ballot, the voter will place a mark in front of the names of his/her preferred candidates, and after dropping the ballot in the ballot box, will leave through the exit door of the voting station. Needless to say, the election registration papers and the special supervisory section [of the ballot] will be kept after being stamped under the joint observation of the voting station staff and supervisors of the Guardian Council.

government_functions.details: Kazakhstan is a unitary state with a presidential form of government. The President is the head of the state and is directly elected by simple majority popular vote for a 7 year term. The Prime Minister and Deputy Prime Ministers are approved by the lower house of parliament following nomination by the President.   Kazakh parliament is a bicameral system that consists of the 50-sear Senate and the 98-seat Mazhilis. 40 Senate members are indirectly elected by oblast-level assemblies and 10 members are appointed by decree of the President. Members of the Mazhilis are directly elected.   The highest levels of the judiciary are comprised of the Supreme Council of the Republic (44 members) and the Constitutional Council (7 members, including a chairperson).

voting_methods.instructions: Each voter must vote personally; proxy voting is prohibited. When a voter changes his/her residence before the election day, the precinct election commission can issue an absentee voting certificate, on request by 6:00 pm of the day before the vote, to the voter to allow him/her to be included on the voter list, and to vote, at the polling station where he/she resides. Ballot papers are issued to voters on the voter register who submit an identification document. Voters sign the voter register to confirm receipt of the ballot, and the ballot issuer also signs the voter register against the name of the voter who is given the ballot.  Voters must mark the ballot(with the chosen political party) using a pen in a polling booth.  Voters who cannot independently fill in a ballot can be assisted by a person whom he/she trusts (but not a poll worker, public official, candidate proxy, journalist, or election observer). Mobile voting can be requested in writing, not later than 12:00 am on election day, by voters who cannot come to the polling station due to state of health or having to care for an ill family member, as well as voters living in remote areas where no polling station exists.  The secrecy of the vote is guaranteed. Ballots shall be filled in by voters in a polling booth. While filling in the ballots, the presence of anybody in the polling booth, except the voter, shall be forbidden. Note that Kazakhstan has two time zones: Kazakhstan Eastern Standard Time, which is 6 hours ahead of Greenwich Mean Time (GMT6).  Kazakhstan Western Standard Time (merged with Kazakhstan CentralStandard Time) is 5 hours ahead of Greenwich Mean Time (GMT+5).

voting_methods.instructions: On Polling, Counting and Results Summation- Article 7 Head of the polling & counting committee shall at 7:00 am invite the voters to start flowing into the polling and counting room. Every voter shall exercise his/her right to vote as follows: A . When the voter appears before the polling and counting committee, the committee shall verify his/her identity and make sure that his/her name is registered in the final voter list for that district by checking the computer and the hard-copies of the list. The list shall be marked electronically and by hand to indicate that the voter has exercised his/her right to vote. B . The chair of the polling and counting committee or one of its two members shall give the actual voter a ballot paper. C . The actual voter shall: ( i ) mark in the designated place the name, number or emblem of one of the lists standing for election in that electoral district; ( ii ) mark in the designated place of one or more of the candidate names in that specific list. E . The actual voter shall put the ballot paper in the designated ballot box, which must be visible to the committee and to all persons present. F . The actual voter shall put his/her finger in the designated ink. G . Notwithstanding the provisions of paragraphs (b), (c), (d) and (e) of this Article, the Board may decide to conduct the polling and/or counting process electronically, for which the terms and conditions shall be set out in special executive instructions issued for that purpose.ـ

voting_methods.instructions: Early voting as such is not available for voters. Ill and incapacitated voters who have been approved for home/mobile voting (and voters in prisons and detention facilities and non-family based care institutions) are visited by the Election Board which brings a special ballot box. The voter must be alone when they cast the vote. After they vote, they put the ballot in an envelope, they seal the envelope and put it in the ballot box.

Secrecy of the vote is guaranteed and proxy voting is prohibited.  Only one voter at a time can approach to vote; when a voter approaches, he/she proves his/her identity with a valid identity card or passport and the poll worker inserts the submitted identity document in the technical equipment; the equipment will indicate if the voter is registered at the polling station and if she/he has already voted; if the voter is registered at the polling station and has a proper identity document and has not voted, his/her photo and voter list ordinal number will appear on the screen (if the voter is regsitered but at a different polling station, the equipment will display the number of the correct polling station); with an ultraviolet lamp, the poll worker checks whether there is an indelible mark on the voters' nail and thumb of the right hand; if the voter has not voted and is in the correct polling station with a valid identity document, he/she deposits a fingerprint from the right index finger onto the equipment; the ordinal number of the voter on the voter list is circled by the poll worker and the voter signs the list and he/she is given a ballot; after receiving the ballot, an indelible spray is put on the thumbnail of the right hand; after marking the ballot by circling the number of the preferred contestant, the voter puts the ballot in the ballot box. If a voter is not allowed to vote for any reason, the Electoral Board must provide the voter with written reasons using the template. Due to physical disability or illiteracy, a voter can ask another person to assist him/her with voting (if voter does not have someone to assist the polling committee appoints another person from among the voters, but not a poll worker, partisan representative or observer, and the same person cannot assist more than two voters).  Home (mobile voting) is also available for incapacitated or ill voters who are unable to vote at the polling station, whereby the day before election day a special ballot box is brought to the house of the voter who applied for home voting.  Voters' identities during mobile voting can be confirmed without the use of technical equipment.

government_functions.details: The President of Ecuador serves as both head of government and head of state.  The president is directly elected by plurality of at least 40% and a 10% differential to the runner-up vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two consecutive 4-year terms.  The National Assembly shall be comprised of Fifteen (15) Assembly persons elected as representatives of the nation as a whole (national district). Two (2) Assembly persons elected for each province, plus one (1) additional Assembly person for every two hundred thousand (200,000) inhabitants or fraction thereof over one hundred fifty thousand (150,000), on the basis of the last national population census.  The jurisdictional bodies, without detriment to the other bodies with equal powers recognized in the Constitution, are those in charge of administering justice and they shall be as follows: The National Court of Justice. The provincial courts of justice. The courts and tribunals provided for by law. The justices of the peace.

election_commission_historical_context:
Election Commission Historical Context:

In the eighties, Guatemala faced a very particular historical and political situation, the internal war was still a reality and the Electoral Registry was the entity designated by the Executive to carry out the Elections. It was in 1982 that the history of this Institution began to take shape, the de facto Government of that time, decreed the Organic Law of the Supreme Electoral Tribunal, (Decree 30-83), in which it is already regulated as an autonomous organ, not subordinated to any other authority. The Tribunal is in charge of convening the National Constituent Assembly, which drafted the current Political Constitution of the Republic and formalized the creation of the Supreme Electoral Tribunal.

According to the new Political Constitution of the Republic, the Supreme Electoral Tribunal was created to be responsible for regulating everything related to the exercise of citizens' rights: political organizations, the exercise of political rights and the organization and operation of the electoral authorities.

From its creation to date, the Supreme Electoral Tribunal is responsible for the organization of 20 electoral processes, all of them satisfactorily, because it has guaranteed the respect for the Constitution, the Electoral and Political Parties Law, and the will of the people.

government_functions.details: The President of Guatemala serves as both the chief of state and head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds along with the Vice President. The President serves a single 4-year term and is not eligible for reelection.  Guatemala has a unicameral Congress with 160 seats. 128 members are elected from multi-seat departmental constituencies and 32 additional members are elected in a single, nationwide constituency. All members are directly elected by closed list proportional representation vote and serve 4-year terms.  The Supreme Court of Justice is the highest court within the national judicial system. It is composed of 13 judges nominated by an expert legal panel and elected by members of Congress. Judges serve 5-year terms, and there are no term limits. There is also a Constitutional Court that is independent from the judicial system and rules only on constitutionality. The Constitutional Court consists of 5 active judges and 5 reserve judges. Each active judge is appointed by a different institution: the President, Congress, the Supreme Court, the University of San Carlos, or the Assembly of the College of Attorneys and Notaries. Constitutional Court judges serve 5-year terms, and there are no term limits.

election_commission_historical_context: In the 2020 parliamentary elections, there were a variety of issues reported with the delivery of overseas postal ballot papers which triggered public discussions about the vulnerability of the postal voting process. Errors occurred due to incorrect information provided by some voters, mishandling of documents by administrators, and different conditions provided by foreign postal services. Some stakeholders expressed concerns about the capacity of some municipalities to properly manage postal voting and the transparency of the process at the Ministry of Interior, which oversees the postal voting process, due to the lack of clearly stipulated procedures on the handling of ballots and the lack of information on practical arrangements put into place. Some stakeholders pointed out the lack of information campaigns on postal voting by the election administration. Public calls were made for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to consider providing technical assitance and faciilating voter information abroad. In November 2022, amendments to the election law elaborate on the procedures for oversesas postal voting which will take effect for the 2023 election.

government_functions.details:
Slovakia is a parliamentary republic. The President is the chief of state and is directly elected by an absolute majority popular vote in two rounds if necessary. The President must be nominated by no less than 15 member of the National Council, per the Constitution. The President selects the Prime Minister (typically, the leader of the winning party or coalition). The Prime Minster must win a vote of confidence in the National Council prior to being officially confirmed. 

Parliament consists of the unicameral National Council. The Council has 150 seats, all of which are directly elected to serve four-year terms. 

The judiciary is comprised of the Supreme Court of the Slovak Republic and the Constitutional Court of the Slovak Republic.

voting_methods.instructions:
Voters can find ballots for postal elections on the website of the Ministry of the Interior of the Slovak Republic https://www.minv.sk/?nr23-hl . The voter prints the ballot of the political entity to which he wants to cast his vote. If the data on this ballot is given on two pages, he will print both sides of the ballot, if possible on both sides .  

The voter receives two envelopes - an envelope for voting with an imprint of the official stamp of the Ministry of the Interior of the Slovak Republic and a returnable envelope marked with the slogan "ELECTION BY MAIL". It contains the address of the seat of the Ministry of the Interior of the Slovak Republic as the addressee, the address of the voter as the sender and a unique identification code. Each return envelope must contain only one voting envelope. In the event that the return envelope contains multiple ballot envelopes, all of these envelopes will be invalid. Any number of sealed return envelopes from multiple voters may be sent in one package. 

The postage for sending the return envelope is paid by the sender.  

A voter from abroad can send a returnable envelope from abroad in any way - classic mail, registered mail and courier service. The shipment of the courier service (courier envelope) must contain a return envelope in which the reporting envelope will be inserted. He can also send a returnable envelope from Slovakia or personally deliver it to the office of the Ministry of the Interior of the Slovak Republic at Drieňová Street 22 in Bratislava, no later than Friday, September 29 by 12:00 p.m.

Upon arrival at the polling station, the voter is obliged to prove his identity to the district election commission by presenting his identity card. If the voter was issued a voting card at his request, he shall submit the voting card together with the ID card, which will be taken away by the district election commission.  Then the precinct election commission circles the voter's serial number in the voter list and issues ballot papers and an empty envelope bearing the stamp of the municipality's official stamp to the voter. Receipt of ballots and envelopes is confirmed by the voter in the voter list with a handwritten signature.  Before voting , each voter must go to a special area designated for editing ballots. A voter who does not enter this space will not be allowed to vote by the district election commission. In a special space designated for editing ballots, the voter selects one ballot of the candidate subject to which he has decided to cast his vote. This ballot can be placed in an envelope without further modification,   or on the selected ballot, the voter can mark which candidate he prefers by circling the candidate's serial number. A voter can circle the serial number of a maximum of four candidates.

campaign_finance.details: arties may receive donations, in-kind contributions, membership fees, and loans or revenues from assets, up to an aggregate of approx. EUR 3.5 million per parliamentary term. Non-compliance is subject to party liquiation. Public subsidies are provided based on votes, activity and mandates. A yearly limit of approx. EUR 10,000 for membership fees per member is in place, while a donor, both individual and legal entity, may donate up to EUR 300,000 in financial or in-kind contributions. Anonymous and foreign donations, as well as donations from state institutions are not allowed.  The expenditure limit per part for the election campaign is set at approx. EUR 3 million including coasts incurred 180 days before teh announcement of elections. Dedicatedl bank account must be used by parties to receive donations and for campaign expenses. Details of all transactions through the account are made available for public scrutiny. Only bank transfers from identifiable donors are permitted and funds have to be returned by parties in the case of cash payments. Third parties are banned from incurring campaign-related expenses.  The State Election Commission (SEC) permits oversight of political party financing an the overall control of elecction campaign financing. Parties must publish annual reports verified by the SEC with the support of specialized auditors selected by lottery. Parties are required to publish by 31 march on their website a detailed list of donations, membership fees, and in-kind contributions for the preceding calendary year if the value of any of those is higher than two minimum monthly wages at the time of acceptance.  The list of loans should be published within 30 days of concluding loan agreements. Parties are required to submit to the Ministry of Interior (MoI) a report on campaign expenditures within 30 days after elections. The disclosure of campaign incomes is not required. The  MoI performs oversight tasks with the support of its district offices. It monitors the dedicated bank accounts and can perform checks. The law does not require the MoI to publish reports on its oversight activities. The MoI may impose fines on parties for campaign finance violations, with the SEC serving as an appeal body against such fines.

voting_methods.instructions: The casting of votes by the voter in election or referendums shall be by marking the ballot intended for that purpose. Presiding Officer must ascertain the identity of the voters himself/herself, after which he/she shall hand them the ballot or ballots specified by NEA subject to the electoral system or the subject of the referendum. The ballot must be stamped with the Seal of the Polling Station or the signature or seal of its Presiding Officer and must indicate the date of the election or referendum. The voter must step behind the curtain set up for that purpose in the elections hall, his/her opinion shall be recorded on the ballot, and then the ballot shall be deposited in the ballot box pursuant to the procedures determined by NEA. ... The voter shall sign against his/her name in writing or by thumbprint in the Roll List of Voters of the Polling Station where the names of all voters registered therein are indicated. The Secretary of the Polling Station shall sign next to the name of the voter who has expressed his/her opinion.

voting_methods.instructions:
Out of country voting is allowed via proxy voting. The form states that the following are sufficient grounds - Illness, working away, on a course, holiday (give details). The absentee voter has to comply with the requirements and steps for voting via proxy.

A ballot paper marked with the official mark shall be delivered to the proxy voter, who must proceed into one of the compartments in the polling station,  and there secretly mark the ballot paper and fold it up so as to conceal the vote, and shall then show to the presiding officer the back of the paper, so as to disclose the official mark, and put the ballot paper so folded up into the ballot box in the presence of the presiding officer. The proxy shall immediately leave the polling station after he or she has put the ballot paper into the ballot box.

There is no specific start and end date. Voter can  download the postal vote application form to request for ballot. This form has to be sent to the Returning Officer to arrive by noon on Wednesday 4th October 2023. The  voter must make sure that there is enough time to receive and return the ballot so that it arrives back by 10 pm on 12 October 2023.

Voters must fill in the postal vote application form, which can be downloaded from the internet.

A ballot paper marked with the official mark shall be delivered to a voter or to a proxy voter, who must proceed into one of the compartments in the polling station,  and there secretly mark the ballot paper and fold it up so as to conceal the vote, and shall then show to the presiding officer the back of the paper, so as to disclose the official mark, and put the ballot paper so folded up into the ballot box in the presence of the presiding officer. Voter or proxy shall immediately leave the polling station after he or she has put the ballot paper into the ballot box.

campaign_finance.details: The law (Parliament Act, Section 14(1) and 15(1)) sets a limit on the campaign expenditure and the the election agent of every candidate is required to make a return containing a full statement under the appropriate head of all expenditure incurred in connection with the election by or on behalf of the candidate supported by vouchers for all payments in excess of £2. Such return shall be accompanied by a declaration made before a justice of the peace.

institution.term_details: Although not specified in the law, the term of the members start  on the day after the day of the return of that writ and ends at the close of polling day at the next general election. This means the term is 3 years, approximately, as elections are called and held every 3 years.

voting_methods.instructions:
Overseas voters have multiple options for obtaining their voting papers. They can either download the papers from the Electoral Commission's website, apply to have the papers posted to their overseas address, or vote in person at a designated overseas voting place. When it comes to returning the voting papers, overseas voters can choose to upload them to a secure server on the Commission's website, post them directly to the Commission, or post/hand deliver them to the nearest designated overseas voting place. These methods ensure that overseas voters can obtain and return their voting papers conveniently and securely.

Votes returned using the overseas upload service need to be received by the Commission before 7pm on election day. Postal votes need to be postmarked in another country before or on the day before election day and received by the Commission or a Returning Officer before noon on the Tuesday 10 days after the election.

A limited service for advance voters leaving New Zealand before advance voting starts will be available from the Returning Officer from two and a half weeks before election day.

Voters can vote at a voting place from 9am to 7pm on election day. The doors close at 7pm - anyone inside the voting place at 7pm is allowed to complete their vote.

If the voter is not enrolled they can complete an enrolment form at the voting place or enrol online at vote.nz.

Voters do not have to be enrolled in the electorate to vote at a voting place in the electorate. A voter enrolled in any electorate can vote at any voting place anywhere in the country.

Upon receiving a ballot paper, the voter is required to promptly proceed to one of the designated inner compartments provided for privacy. Inside the compartment, the voter must cast their vote alone and in secret. This involves marking their party vote by placing a tick within the circle adjacent to the name of the desired party. Similarly, the electorate vote is indicated by placing a tick within the circle just before the name of the preferred constituency candidate. Following these steps ensures the voter's choices are accurately recorded while maintaining the confidentiality of their ballot.

campaign_finance.details: For Political Parties: NZEC requires political parties to report yearly donations and loans over a certain amount. Limits apply for receiving anonymous donations and overseas donations. From 1 January 2023 parties will have the following new obligations to report in their annual returns due by 30 April 2024, and onwards: - the name and address of donors for donations and contributions over $5,000; - the number and total donations under $1,500 that are not made anonymously; - separately reporting on the total amount of monetary and in-kind donations. For Candidates: Candidates  must report donations to their election campaign that are over $1,500 and from 1 January 2023, candidate loans. Limits apply for receiving donations anonymously or from overseas.

election_commission_historical_context: In the Argentine Republic the knowledge of electoral matters has been entrusted to the Judiciary of the Nation.  Prior to the creation of the National Electoral Chamber in 1962, Decree 11.976/45 was issued during the de facto government, which approved the "Organic Statute of the Political Parties and established the creation of the "Federal Electoral Court".  However, the referred Statute was repealed and the Federal Electoral Court -whose members had resigned in full two days before- was dissolved. In 1962, by decree 7.163/62 the National Electoral Chamber was created.  This regulation placed special emphasis on the "convenience of having a specialized court in charge of resolving the issues arising from the application of the electoral and political parties laws".  Thus, and even with some differences with the current regime, the National Electoral Chamber was created. At that time, the Court was composed of five judges and an attorney general, and its presidency was permanent.  The following year, it was established -by decree-law 6.407/63- that the National Electoral Justice "would integrate the Judicial Power of the Nation, as a court specialized in legal-political and electoral matters".  It was also established that the National Electoral Chamber would act as "court of appeal with respect to the national electoral judges".  The creation of the electoral jurisdiction was later ratified by law 16.478 -which provided that the decrees issued with force of law by the de facto government, between March 29, 1962 and October 12, 1963, would continue to be in force- and, fundamentally, through the sanction of law 16.652.  This 1964 law provided for the intervention of the National Electoral Justice in all matters relating to the organization, recognition, operation and expiration of political parties, as well as in all contentious issues arising from the application of such law.  It should be recalled that by virtue of the coup d'état of June 28, 1966, the dissolution of the political parties was decreed. Months later, Law 17.014 was enacted, which determined the legal suppression of the National Electoral Chamber.  The magistrates of the National Electoral Chamber became judges of the National Chamber of Appeals for Peace and the National Chamber of Appeals for Economic Criminal Matters.  The electoral secretariats changed their name to "Registries of Enrollment Records" and the then National Registry of Enrollment as well as the Registry of Letters of Citizenship were in charge of the National Court of First Instance in Federal Criminal and Correctional Matters No. 1 of the Federal Capital. In 1971, Law 19,108 was enacted to create an "Electoral Chamber" within the National Court of Appeals in Federal and Contentious-Administrative Matters of the Federal Capital.  Subsequently, by virtue of the enactment of Law 19.277, and prior to the appointment of its members, the "Electoral Chamber" was transformed into the National Electoral Chamber, with its current structure of three judges forming a single chamber.  Translated with DeepL

government_functions.details: The President of Argentina serves as both chief of state and head of government. The President is directly elected by qualified plurality vote in up to two rounds. To be elected, a candidate must receive either 45% of the overall vote or 40% of the vote and a 10-point lead over the closest opponent. The President may serve up to two 4-year terms.  Argentina has a bicameral National Congress with a 72-seat Senate and a 257-seat Chamber of Deputies. In the Senate, all 72 members are directly elected from multi-seat constituencies. Each constituency (province) awards 2 seats to the party highest-polling party and 1 seat to the second-place party. All members serve 6-year terms, and one-third of seats are up for election every 2 years. In the Chamber of Deputies, all 257 members are directly elected by party-list proportional representation vote from multi-seat constituencies. Members serve 4-year terms, and half the seats are up for election every 2 years.   The Supreme Court is the highest court in the Argentinian judiciary. It is composed of four judges who are nominated by the President and approved by a two-thirds vote of the Senate. Judges may serve until age 75.
