government_functions.details:
Switzerland is a federal republic. The President, Vice President, and second Vice President are elected by Parliament from the Federal Council to serve 1-year, non-consecutive terms. The Federal Council is an entity comprised of 7 federal councillors. These councillors are indirectly elected by the Federal Assembly for a 4-year term. 

Switzerland has a bicameral parliament that consists of the Council of States (comprised of 46 members that represent Cantons) and the National Council (which has open elections). Both houses have equal standing under the Constitution. Jointly, parliament is called the Federal Assembly. 

The Federal Supreme Court is the highest level of the judiciary. Judges serve for six-year terms.

prominent_political_groups.data: 2011 FDP.The Liberals (34.0%), 2011 Green Party (17.6%), 2011 Social Democratic Party (33.1%), 2011 Swiss People's Party (31.6%), 2011 Christian Democratic People's Party (23.2%),

voting_methods.instructions:
For Council of States elections, citizens abroad registered to vote in a canton are permitted to vote in that canton's Council of States elections only if the canton's law allows it (half  of the cantons allow it). Swiss citizens abroad must join the Register of the Swiss Abroad and be registered on the electoral roll of their last commune of residence (or place of origin if they have never lived in Switzerland) by filling out a form online or at an embassy. Once registered for the first time, the person remains in the register unless the voting materials to the voter were returned undeliverable for three times in a row.

If canton law allows citizens to vote from overseas, they must vote by postal vote in the same manner as in-country postal voting.

Online voting is only through federally approved pilots in the cantons, which are currently restricted to a maximum of 10 per cent of the country's electorate. This limit does not apply to Swiss citizens living abroad but out-of-country voters can vote online only if their canton of registration is utilizing online voting.

The federal legislation provides minimum standards for internet voting pilots to be introduced and implemented  by cantons. Comprehensive end-to-end testing of internet voting systems  must take place before the Federal Counil can approve their use. The law includes requirements for publishing the source code, providing voter information, and allowing voters to familiarize with and to test internet voting outside of an election. The legislation requires that verification of eligibility to vote and voting secrecy be guaranteed and abuses prevented in the use of online voting system. All internet voting systems are required to provide voters with the possiblity to individually verify that their vote has been cast as intended. Eligible voters will receive codes and their voter identification card that will allow them to check that their ballot is recorded correctly and corresponds to their intention. The federal authorities have also undertaken measures to promote cyber security and data protection in online voting systems.

All voters automatically receive the official voting materials by post ahead of election day; if they choose to vote by post, they can do so as soon as the voting materials are received between three to four weeks before the election day.  All cantons are required to provide a postal voting option, including to citizens residing abroad. 

The delivery by post of the official voting materials to all voters is mandated for between three to four weeks prior to election day, to be sent by the commune in which the voter is registered to vote. The cantons are mandated to enact provisions regulating postal voting, including to guarantee the verification of eligibility to vote, voting secrecy and the counting of all the votes, and to prevent abuses. Voters who choose to vote by post, follow the postal voting instructions in the voting materials sent to them.  The voter must send their identification card, using a double envelope system, with the ballot to prevent the possibility of voting additionally at a polling station. Once the voter has filled out his/her ballot these are put into an anonymous return envelope provided in the package. This first anonymous envelope and the identification card are placed into the return envelope and then sent back to the municipality.  In some municipalities, the envelope can be returned directly to the municipality mailbox. Otherwise, the envelope is to be returned by post; in some cantons postage does not have to be paid.

Under federal law, cantons are obliged to provide early voting at polling stations for a minimum of two of the four days immediately prior to election day.  Cantonal law specifies the time that all or certain polling stations will be open for advance voting. Instead of opening polling stations on advance polling days, the canton can allow voters to hand over their ballot paper in a sealed envelope at a public office.

The manner of early voting is the same as for voting on election day, whereby the voter brings the ballots that were sent to him/her by post ahead of the election day to cast at the polling station or to hand  over in a sealed envelope at a public office, whichever means is provided by the canton. The cantons are mandated to enact the required provisions relating to the preservation of voting secrecy and the prevention of abuses in early voting processes.

All voters receive the official voting materials by post to their home address between three to four weeks ahead of election day by the commune in which the voter is registered to vote. The Federal Chancellory is required by law to issue brief instructions on voting procedures prior to each general elecction, which are delivered along with the voting materials to voters in cantons with a system of proportional representation. If the voter wishes to vote in-person (rather than postal vote), he/she takes the ballots that weree previously received by post and drops them off at the polling station where they are registered to vote. At the  polling station, the voter must present his/her identification card. Votes may be cast by proxy at the polling station provided the cantonal law permits this for cantonal elections. Persons who are unable to write may have their ballot paper completed in accordance with their instructions by a person of their chose who is eligible to vote. Voting secrecy must be preserved in the voting process. In cantons where the proportional list system is used for the National Council elections, voters may cross out names on party lists or write names twice, split their vote between parties or draw up their own lists on a blank ballot combining candidates from different lists within the constituency.

campaign_finance.details: Under federal law, political parties represented in the Federal Assembly are obliged to declare all income, as well as donations above CHF15,000. Organizers of election campaigns for the National Council have to declare donations above CHF15,000 (including in-kind donations) and expenses if more than CHF50,000 has been spent. Those elected to the Council of States must declare donations above CHF15,000 and expenses if more than CHF50,000 has been spent. A final statement of campaign income must be submitted for these campaigns. Anonymous political donations and donations from abroad (except from Swiss citizens) are generally prohibited, with the exception of those funding campaigns for the Council of States. The Swiss Federal Audit Office checks whether the declarations are complete and submitted on time. It carries out sample checks on the accuracy of the information provided. It reports any infringements to the prosecution authorities. Persons or organisations prosecuted face a fine of up to CHF 40,000. Some cantons have adopted their own legislation on campaign finance.

government_functions.details:
The President of Liberia is both the head of state and government. The President is elected  to serve a six-year term and can serve up to two terms.

Liberia has a bicameral legislative system, which consists of the Senate and the House of Representatives. The Senate has 30 members, two from each county, who are elected to serve nine-year terms. The House of Representatives has 73 members, who are elected to serve six-year terms.

The judicial branch is headed by the Supreme Court, which is the highest court in the country. Other courts include circuit courts, magistrate courts, and special courts.

The voter shall then fold the ballot paper forthwith and place the same in the official ballot box. He/she shall then leave the polling place.

campaign_finance.details: Donations from foreign interests to candidates and political parties are banned. Contributions from anonymous sources, funds belonging to a corporation, a labour organization, a bank, etc are not allowed. Political parties and candidates shall not utilize public resourses for campaign activities and shall not receive any contribution resulting from an abuse of state resources. There is a limit to campaign contributions. (Source: 2016 NEC Campaign Finance Regulations)

election_commission_historical_context: At least two months before the date of the legislative, European or general communal elections, the Government in Council shall set up a centralizing office responsible for determining the result of the elections in an unofficial manner on the day of the elections and for disseminating this provisional result. Art. 2. The organization of the centralizing office is ensured by state officials to be appointed by the Government Council upon proposal of the Prime Minister, Minister of State, in case of legislative or European elections, or of the Minister of the Interior in case of general communal elections. The person in charge of the management of the centralizing office and his deputy are appointed by the Government Council from among these civil servants following the same procedure. Art. 3. The centralizing office may appoint a sufficient number of agents to ensure the prompt and complete establishment of the unofficial results of the elections. The person in charge of the management of the centralizing office chooses these agents among the State personnel. Art. 4. The mission of the governmental centralizing office is to obtain the results of the elections by municipality from the main polling stations as soon as the polling stations close. In the case of legislative or European elections, the centralizing office determines, on the basis of these results, by any means, the unofficial result of the elections. It ensures the dissemination of partial results and the final unofficial result. In the case of general municipal elections, the centralizing office disseminates the results by municipality, if necessary after having itself determined them on the basis of the information received. Art . 5 . In order to carry out this task, the centralizing office: - In the case of a general municipal election, the central electoral office will be informed of the results of the main polling station of each municipality; if necessary, it will be informed of the results of each polling station of a municipality; for this purpose, the members of the central electoral office are authorized to obtain copies of the minutes of the polling stations; - The president of the centralizing office shall give, before polling day, the necessary instructions to the presidents of the main polling stations and the polling stations to ensure the smooth and prompt conduct of the operations for determining the unofficial result; - implement all the necessary mechanisms to ensure the rapid and efficient transmission of the results achieved in each municipality and to determine, if necessary, partial results and the final unofficial result of the elections (Reg. g.-d. of June 18, 2018) "Art. 6. The members of the centralizing office and the agents who are assistant to them are each entitled to an allowance of 30 euros per hour. For the organizational work prior to the day of the election, the members of the office responsible for the direction and organization of the office are entitled to an additional flat-rate allowance of 150 euros."

government_functions.details: The hereditary Grand Duke is the chief of state of Luxembourg, while the Prime Minister serves as the head of government. The Prime Minister, typically the Chamber of Deputies majority leader. is appointed by the monarch.  The legislature consists of a unicameral Chamber of Deputies with 60 seats. All members are directly elected by party-list proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies and serve 5-year terms.  The Supreme Court of Justice (27 judges) and the Constitutional Court (9 judges) are the highest judicial institutions of Luxembourg.  Judges in these bodies are appointed by the Grand Duke and may serve for life.

voting_methods.instructions:
In-country voters can request mail-in ballots up to 15 days before election day by writing to the government of their current commune of residence or via a secure web form. Completed ballots must be received by 14h on election day.

Loi du 8 mars 2018, Art. 168-170

Overseas voters can request a mail-in ballot up to 30 days before election day by writing to the government of their most recent commune of residence (or the Luxembourg City government if they have never lived in Luxembourg) or via a secure web form.

Completed ballots must be received by 14h on election day.

Voters must present their ID card, passport, residency permit, or residency letter to polling staff.

Loi du 8 mars 2018, Art. 74

government_functions.details:
Oman is a sultanate. The Sultan is also the Prime Minister and is unelected. The Sultan must be a male descendent of Sayyid Turki bin Said bin Sultan and must be the legitimate son of Omani Muslim parents. Heirs to the Sultanate are determined by the Royal Family Council, which is constitutionally enshrined. The cabinet is appointed by the Sultan. 

Oman has a bicameral parliament called the Council of Oman. It is comprised of the Council of State and the Consultative Council. Members of the Council of State are directly appointed by the monarch. Members of the Consultative Council are elected by simple majority vote to serve 4-year terms. Members must be meet several requirements prior to running for office. 

The highest court in Oman is the Supreme Court. The judiciary is supervised by the Supreme Council, which has supervisory powers over the judicial system, as well as auxilliary bodies.

prominent_political_groups.data: 2019 Independents (100.0%),

voting_methods.instructions: Voters must register (or verify their registration) via elections.om or the "Election" ( Intekhaab / انتخاب) app.  On election day, voters will vote online via the Election app, providing an image of their ID card and their face to verify their identity.

campaign_finance.details: Oman does not allow political parties, and there are no campaign finance laws. A 2022 decision o fthe MInsiter of the Interior specifies the rules for election campaigns, which states that financing of the campaigns is the candidates' responsibility.  The decision also states that candidates must pay a campaign fee which will be refunded following the removal of the campaign advertising a day before the date set for voting.

The creation of the electoral jurisdiction was later ratified by law 16.478 -which provided that the decrees issued with force of law by the de facto government, between March 29, 1962 and October 12, 1963, would continue to be in force- and, fundamentally, through the sanction of law 16.652.  This 1964 law provided for the intervention of the National Electoral Justice in all matters relating to the organization, recognition, operation and expiration of political parties, as well as in all contentious issues arising from the application of such law.  It should be recalled that by virtue of the coup d'état of June 28, 1966, the dissolution of the political parties was decreed. Months later, Law 17.014 was enacted, which determined the legal suppression of the National Electoral Chamber.  The magistrates of the National Electoral Chamber became judges of the National Chamber of Appeals for Peace and the National Chamber of Appeals for Economic Criminal Matters.  The electoral secretariats changed their name to "Registries of Enrollment Records" and the then National Registry of Enrollment as well as the Registry of Letters of Citizenship were in charge of the National Court of First Instance in Federal Criminal and Correctional Matters No. 1 of the Federal Capital. In 1971, Law 19,108 was enacted to create an "Electoral Chamber" within the National Court of Appeals in Federal and Contentious-Administrative Matters of the Federal Capital.  Subsequently, by virtue of the enactment of Law 19.277, and prior to the appointment of its members, the "Electoral Chamber" was transformed into the National Electoral Chamber, with its current structure of three judges forming a single chamber.

government_functions.details: The President of Argentina serves as both chief of state and head of government. The President is directly elected by qualified plurality vote in up to two rounds. To be elected, a candidate must receive either 45% of the overall vote or 40% of the vote and a 10-point lead over the closest opponent. The President may serve up to two 4-year terms.  Argentina has a bicameral National Congress with a 72-seat Senate and a 257-seat Chamber of Deputies. In the Senate, all 72 members are directly elected from multi-seat constituencies. Each constituency (province) awards 2 seats to the party highest-polling party and 1 seat to the second-place party. All members serve 6-year terms, and one-third of seats are up for election every 2 years. In the Chamber of Deputies, all 257 members are directly elected by party-list proportional representation vote from multi-seat constituencies. Members serve 4-year terms, and half the seats are up for election every 2 years.   The Supreme Court is the highest court in the Argentinian judiciary. It is composed of four judges who are nominated by the President and approved by a two-thirds vote of the Senate. Judges may serve until age 75.

voting_methods.instructions: Every voter is entitled to vote by mail upon application for a polling card (postal ballot package) submitted in writing or personally to the relevant local authority. The deadline for application is 18:00 on the second day before election day.   Upon receiving the postal voting package, the voter votes by postal ballot by sending a sealed official return envelope containing his or her signed polling card and in a separate sealed ballot paper envelope, his or her ballot paper. The voter is required to mark the ballot and put it in the ballot paper envelope without being observed and must affirm on the polling card that he or she personally marked the ballot. A postal voter with a disability or who is illiterate can be assisted by a person of choice of at least 16 years old who does not have a conflict of interest. The helper must affirm on the polling card that he/she marked the ballot according to the intent of the voter. Helpers are bound to keep the vote secret.  The voted postal ballot packaged can be mailed free of charge or directly handed in at the relevant authority.  A voter in possession of a polling card can (instead of postal voting) choose to vote in person at any polling station of the constituency in which the polling card was issued.

At the polling station, only voters in the voter register (or who have a polling card) can vote.  A voter casts a ballot in the polling station in the  constituency where he/she is on the voter register (or at any polling station in the constituency where the polling card was issued). Proxy voting is not permitted. Measures must be taken to ensure that the voter can cast the vote and fold the ballot paper without being observed, either a voting booth or room adjoining the main room.  Upon entering the polling station, the voter is given an official ballot paper and may be requested to show his/her voter notice.  In the voting booth, the voter casts the two votes by twice marking the ballot with a cross or other sign to clearly indicate the candidate and party list of choice. The two votes are cast on one ballot that has two parts - one part for the constituency candidate and one part for the party list. The voter then folds the ballot paper to ensure the secrecy of the vote, and approaches the table of the electoral board and hands over his/her voter's notice and identification document ( identification document is not strictly required, unless the voter does not have a voter's notice or if the poll worker otherwise requests). If the voter's notice or identification document is not presented the voter is not allowed to cast the ballot. The poll worker checks the voter's information against the voter register and if present and not marked as voted, marks in the voter register that the voter has voted and allows the voter to proceed to put the ballot in the locked ballot box. If the voter is not in the voter register (or does not produce a polling card if present in the polling register as having received a postal voting package), he/she is not allowed to vote. Other grounds for refusing the voter to cast the ballot is if the voter marked or folded the ballot outside the booth or otherwise jeoparidized the secrecy of the vote. If a voters spoils her/his ballot, another ballot can be requested provided that the voter  destroys the spoiiled ballot in the presence of a poll worker. Voting machines can be used instead of ballot papers and ballot boxes to facilitate the casting and counting of votes.  A voter who is illiterate or has a disability can request a person to assist provided the person does not have a conflict of interest. The person assisting is bound to mark the ballot according to the intent of the voter and must keep the ballot choice secret.   Only voters who arrive before the end of polling hours and are inside the polling station or in front of it due to lack of space shall be permitted to cast their votes.

government_functions.details:
The President of Liberia is both the head of state and government. The President is elected  to serve a six-year term and can serve up to two terms.

Liberia has a bicameral legislative system, which consists of the Senate and the House of Representatives. The Senate has 30 members, two from each county, who are elected to serve nine-year terms. The House of Representatives has 73 members, who are elected to serve six-year terms.

The judicial branch is headed by the Supreme Court, which is the highest court in the country. Other courts include circuit courts, magistrate courts, and special courts.

voting_methods.instructions: Voters residing abroad who wish to receive a postal ballot are required to actively register with the municipality of The Hague by post or electronically not later than six weeks prior to the polling day. The overseas voter register is permanent, so that voters do not need to register anew for each election. Registered out-of-country electors may also designate a proxy upon application to the mayor of The Hague at least six weeks before the polling day. Registered postal voter receive a postal vote certificate (not a voting pass) as proof of being allowed to vote by post. The postal voting packages are mailed out to out-of-country voters. Postal voters have the option of downloading their postal ballot electronically but must mark and cast the ballots in hard copy. To allow for voters to print the ballot themselves, in past elections the postal ballot was much smaller than the in-person ballot, with numbers for places on the list but not all the candidates' names. The postal voting package includes the ballot, the ballot envelope, the return envelope with the pre-printed return address, a postal vote certificate containing a declaration to be signed by the person that he or she has personally completed the ballot paper, and voting instructions. In the return envelope, voters send back the ballot in the ballot envelope, as well as signed postal vote certificate, which they received separately. The postal voter colours the white spot in front of the name/number of the candidate of her or his choice, in red, blue or black. The ballot is then folded and put in the ballot envelope. The voter then signs the postal vote certificate declaring that he or she has completed the ballot paper personally. The voter encloses a copy of an approved identity document, which must be valid.  The postal ballot certificate, copy of ID, and envelope containing the ballot paper are then placed in the accompanying return envelope which is closed and returned (with adequate stamps). The postal ballots can be mailed to The Hague municipality or dropped off at a designated Dutch diplomatic or consular mission or other overseas location serving as a collection point for votes abroad, Dutch representations at the Carribean countries of the Kingdom of the Netherlands, or collection points designated by the Ministry of Defence at military missions outside The Netherlands. The votes handed in to these collection points are counted at the collection points and the results transmitted electronically to The Hague district election committee. The oveseas ballots are counted by the The Hague district election committee and count in the results of The Hague municipality.

Everyone eligible to vote will receive an invitation to cast their vote sent to their home address no later than 14 days prior to election day. This invitation includes the voter's poll card (voting pass) which allows the voter to cast their vote in the polling station of their choice within the borders of the municipality in which he or she is registered. The poll card (voting pass) is a personalized document with security features against copying. Voters can request a replacement in case of loss, including on election day. Voters may also request, by written or oral application to the  municipality where he or she is registered, to vote at any other location in the country, in which case they are issued a voter's (absentee) pass. Such requests in writing must be received no later than five days before polling day or in case of oral request, by 12 noon on the day before voting.  Municipal authorities can set up mobile polling stations that move from designated location to designated location on election day during certain times. Any voter unable to cast their vote in person on election day, including voters residing abroad, may appoint a proxy to vote on their behalf. No justification is required to request a proxy vote, but voters cannot request a proxy in a polling station. Appointing a proxy may be done by simply providing the chosen proxy who resides in the same municipality with a signed voting pass or voter's (absentee) pass. A proxy residing outside the voter's municipality may be authorized through an application to the mayor received no later than five days before the polling day, in which case a certificate of authorization is issued to the proxy. A proxy may cast the additional vote in a polling station only together with her or his vote, upon presentation of the signed voting or voter's pass and (copy of) the identification document of the represented person. One person can be the proxy of only up to two persons. Prisoners can only vote by proxy. All voters casting votes must show an authorized identification document to the poll worker. Any such identification may not have expired by more than five years. The voter must also hand in his/her poll card (voting pass) or voter's (absentee) pass to the poll worker before voting. Upon doing so, the poll worker checks that the voting pass has not been invalidated (according to the list of invalid passes) and that it corresponds to the identity document. If the pass is not on the invalid list and the pass and identification correspond then the voter is issued a ballot paper and the poll worker directs the voter  to the polling booth. The poll worker retains and cancels the voting pass. Proxy voters who have a certificate of authorization are to hand it over to the poll worker. Polling stations do not keep voters lists (the retention of voting passes prevents multiple voting.) The polling booths must have instructions on voting, established by ministerial order. Voters are required to mark the ballot in secret in the polling booth with a red pencil.  In each electoral district, votes are cast for the candidates whose names appear on the lists of candidates for that electoral district. Voters can vote for a list or have the option to cast a preferential vote for a candidate of choice.  The voter colours in the white spot opposite the name of the candidate of her or his choice. The voter then folds the ballot paper, leaves the polling booth, and inserts the ballot in the ballot box next to the electoral committee's table. If the voter does not put the ballot in the box, the chairperson shall make a note of it. If a voter makes a mistake when completing the ballot paper, he or she can return it to the chairperson and, on request, will be provided (once) with a new ballot paper. The law provides that if a voter requires help because of her or his physical condition, the electoral committee should allow him or her to avail themself of assistance.  Voters are allowed to remain in the polling station while the electoral committee is in session, provided they do not create a disturbance or hinder the progress of the session.

campaign_finance.details: The political finance system in the Netherlands includes both public and private funding. Parliamentary parties receive public funding in proportion to their representation, while all parties and candidates may receive unlimited contributions from private individuals and legal entities. Individual anonymous donations of up to EUR 1,000 each and any donations from abroad are allowed. The law does not impose expenditure ceilings related to campaign on either parties or candidates.  Parties must record all contributions over EUR 1,000, both monetary and in-kind. A few weeks prior to each election, participating political parties and candidates must disclose to the Ministry of Interior the donors for their contributions of over EUR 4,500 in recent years and parties must disclose their recent loans of over EUR 25,000 in a calendar year. The law requires that these reports be made public seven days before an election.  Parliamentary parties must submit their annual financial reports certified by an auditor by 1 July (for the previous year) to the Ministry of Interior. The Ministry of Interior publishes the reports in the Government Gazette and on its website, although the law does not provide a deadline for publishing. There are no requirements for reporting on campaign expenditures before or after an election, other than in the party's annual party finance reports.  The Ministry of Interior, with the assistance of an advisory body - the Commission on Politcal Party Finance - oversees political and campaign finance. The Commission consists of three members appointed by the Ministry of Interior for up to two four-year terms, none of whom represent the governing bodies. The Commission meets once a year and upon request by the Ministry of Interior provides opinion on issues related to political finance. The Commission reviews the parties' annual reports and the electoral contestants' financial reports and advises the Ministry of Interior on their compliance with the law.   In the case of infringements of political finance rules, the Ministry of Interior, under the advice of the Commission, can impose a range of administrative fines, up to EUR 25,000 for not keeping records on contributions and loans, receiving anonymous donations over EUR 1,000, or not submitting the required reports. Where a political party is a recipient of public funding, the amount of the fines can be withdrawn from the state subsidies. In cases involving criminal convictions, eligibility for state subsidies is suspended for up to four years.

government_functions.details: The President of Argentina serves as both chief of state and head of government. The President is directly elected by qualified plurality vote in up to two rounds. To be elected, a candidate must receive either 45% of the overall vote or 40% of the vote and a 10-point lead over the closest opponent. The President may serve up to two 4-year terms.  Argentina has a bicameral National Congress with a 72-seat Senate and a 257-seat Chamber of Deputies. In the Senate, all 72 members are directly elected from multi-seat constituencies. Each constituency (province) awards 2 seats to the party highest-polling party and 1 seat to the second-place party. All members serve 6-year terms, and one-third of seats are up for election every 2 years. In the Chamber of Deputies, all 257 members are directly elected by party-list proportional representation vote from multi-seat constituencies. Members serve 4-year terms, and half the seats are up for election every 2 years.   The Supreme Court is the highest court in the Argentinian judiciary. It is composed of four judges who are nominated by the President and approved by a two-thirds vote of the Senate. Judges may serve until age 75.

election_commission_historical_context: Post Independence – 1980-2004  After independence in 1980, the new government of Zimbabwe introduced a democratic, non-racist electoral system based upon universal adult suffrage. A new electoral management structure was established consisting of the Delimitation Commission, responsible for the delimitation of electoral districts, and the Electoral Supervisory Commission (ESC), charged with supervising the conduct of elections. The management of elections was done at this stage by the Registrar-General of Elections under the supervision of the ESC. The Registrar-General registered voters and compiled voter registers, conducted the voting process and the counting and collation of votes, and announced the results of the election. The Election Directorate provided logistical support to the Registrar-General in the management of the electoral process.  2004 Restructuring  In 2004 the electoral management system was re-structured. This re-structuring was based on recommendations by the Electoral Supervisory Commission, by the political parties and by civil society organisations. The reforms also took account of the Principles and Guidelines Governing Democratic Elections adopted by the SADC Heads of State and Governments in Mauritius in 2004. The Zimbabwe Electoral Commission (ZEC) was then established as an independent body in line with the recommendation in the SADC Principles and Guidelines Governing Democratic Elections that elections should be run by an independent management body and not by a government department like that of the Registrar-General.  The Electoral Supervisory Commission was then abolished in 2005 by Constitutional Amendment No. 17. ZEC became the body responsible for running elections and this function was no longer performed by the Registrar-General. To reflect the new system, the title of the Registrar-General of Elections was changed to that of the Registrar-General of Voters. The function of the Registrar-General of Voters in relation to elections was now only to register voters under the supervision of ZEC. ZEC was responsible for compiling voters rolls and providing copies of these rolls to those requesting them.  The Present ZEC  ZEC was constituted in terms of Chapter 12 Section 238 of the Constitution of Zimbabwe. There are nine Commissioners, who hold office for a term of six years. There is a Chairperson and a Deputy-Chairperson both of whom are appointed on a full time basis. Four of the eight Commissioners other than the Chairperson must be women.  The Chairperson is appointed by the President after consultation with the Judicial Service Commission and the Parliamentary Committee on Standing Rules and Orders. The Chairperson must be a judge or former judge of the Supreme Court or the High Court, or a person qualified for appointment as such the other eight members are appointed by the President from a list of not fewer than twelve nominees submitted by the Parliamentary Committee on Standing Rules and Orders.  In respect of the eight Commissioners appointed under this new system, the Parliamentary Committee on Standing Rules and Orders first invites applications for these posts. It then shortlists applicants. The shortlisted applicants are subjected to a vigorous public interview process by a panel of Parliamentarians. The Constitution provisions requires that Commissioners be chosen “for their integrity and their experience and competence in the conduct of affairs in the public or private sector.”

government_functions.details: The head of state and government is the president, who is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds. The president can serve no more than two 5-year terms. The president is assisted by two vice presidents.  The parliament consists of the National Assembly and the Senate. The National Assembly normally has 210 members, all of whom are directly elected. For the first two parliaments elected after the promulgation of the 2013 constitution, however, the National Assembly has 270 seats, with the 60 additional seats reserved for women—6 from each of the 8 provinces and the 2 cities with provincial status—elected through a system of proportional representation. The Senate comprises 80 members: 60 (6 from each of the 8 provinces and the 2 cities with provincial status) elected by a party-list system of proportional representation, with men and women being listed alternately on every list; 16 traditional chiefs elected by the provincial assemblies of chiefs in the 8 provinces; 2 seats for the president and deputy president of the National Council of Chiefs (the administrative body of traditional chiefs); and 2 representatives of people with disabilities. All parliament members serve five-year terms.  The highest courts of the Zimbabwean judiciary are the Supreme Court (5 judges) and Constitutional Court (7 judges). Supreme Court judges may serve until age 70, while Constitutional Court judges serve a single 15-year term.  Judges from both courts are appointed by the President.

voting_methods.instructions: PART XIV  POSTAL VOTING  [Part XIV (sections 71 – 80) substituted by Act 3 of 2012]  71 Interpretation in Part XIV  The reference in section 73(2)(b)(ii) to a “letter” includes a reference to a letter sent by way of elec- tronic mail, under the following conditions—      (a)  thesender(thatis,thepersonreferredtoin73(2)(b)(ii)(A)or(B)andrecipient(thatis,theappli- cant for a postal vote) must both use official electronic mail addresses; and      (b)  theelectronicmailsentbysendermustbeauthenticatedbytheelectronicsignatureofthesender; and      (c)  theelectronicmailmustbeembodiedinahardcopyprintedbytherecipient,whichcopyshallbe the “letter” referred to in 73(2)(b)(ii).     72 Personswhomayvotebypost  Where an election is to be held in a constituency, a person who is registered as a voter on the roll for that constituency shall be entitled to vote by post in terms of this Part if, on all polling days in the election, he or she will be—      (a)  on duty as a member of a disciplined force or as an electoral officer; or      (b)  on duty in the service of the Government outside Zimbabwe; or      (c)  outside Zimbabwe as the spouse of a person referred to in paragraph (b);     and so unable to vote at a polling station in the constituency.  For cut offs, see articles 73-79 Electoral Act

57 Mannerofvoting  The voting at an election shall be by ballot which shall be conducted in substance and as nearly as pos- sible in the following manner—      (a)  every ballot paper shall be in the form prescribed and there shall be printed on every ballot pa- per—         (i)  in type of equal size, the names of all the duly nominated candidates at the election in alphabetical order of surnames; and         (ii)  the symbols, if any, specified by the duly nominated candidates at the election in terms of paragraph (b) of subsection (1) of section forty-six, each printed to a size that permits the vertical extremities or the horizontal extremities or both such extremities to touch oppo- site sides of the appropriate square on the ballot paper; and         (iii)  in capital letters of equal size, the abbreviation of every political party for which a duly nominated candidate at the election is standing or which is sponsoring such a candidate, where the candidate concerned specified the abbreviation in his or her nomination paper in terms of paragraph (c) of subsection (1) of section forty-six; and         (iv)  a passport-sized photograph of the candidate; and [Subparagraph amended by Act 17 of 2007]         (v)  such other particulars as may be prescribed;           (b)  beforetheballotpaperishandedtotheapplicant,thepresidingofficershallmarktheballotpaper   with the official mark;      (c)  when the person claiming the vote has received the ballot paper he or she shall—         (i)  take the paper to the compartment provided for the purpose; and         (ii)  then signify the candidate for whom he or she desires to vote by secretly placing a cross    in the rectangle opposite the name of that candidate or, if there is more than one such rec-    tangle, in the rectangle nearest to the right-hand side of the ballot paper; and         (iii)  then fold the ballot paper so that the official mark is visible and the names of the candi- dates and the cross made by him or her are not visible and drop the ballot paper in the bal-    lot box placed in front of the presiding officer:   Provided that, if he or she has spoilt the ballot paper, he or she may return it to the    presiding officer in terms of section fifty-eight and shall deal with the second ballot paper given to him or her in accordance with this paragraph.

voting_methods.instructions:
This voting method is for registered voters who reside outside of the Republic or will be outside of the Republic on the day of the election. 

If the Chief Electoral Officer is satisfied that prima-facie an applicant for postal ballot paper is entitled to the same, the latter will receive a ballot paper; a ballot envelope, in a form approved by the Chief Electoral Officer; a form of affidavit for completion by the applicant verifying his right to vote in the election and his right to a postal vote, in a form approved by the Chief Electoral Officer; and a covering reply envelope marked “Postal Ballot Paper Enclosed.”

The postal voter shall mark the ballot paper in the usual way, so that no person can see or know how it is marked (except as allowed by Section 174 of this Chapter). The voter shall deposit the ballot paper in the ballot envelope and securely seal it. He or she must also complete the affidavit, and swear it before a person authorized to administer oaths in the place where the applicant is, and enclose the ballot envelope and the affidavit in the covering reply envelope.

The covering reply envelope must be placed in the mail and be postmarked on or before the date of the election; provided, however, that in no event will a covering reply envelope that is received through the mail be accepted on or after fourteen (14) days after the date of the election.

Upon entering the polling place, the voter shall state his or her name in full and his address to the election officials and present his or her RMI national ID or any of the following: valid passport, valid driver's license, or any other identification documents produced to the satisfaction of the election official.  

Another election official will check the voters list to confirm is he or she is a registered voter, and if so, the official will announce the name and address as shown in the list. 

If the person cannot present any of the required forms of identification, that person must provide verification as to the identity by the oral confirmation from one poll watcher representing each of the candidates in the electoral district for which the voter is registered to vote in; two registered voters eligible to vote in the electoral district for which the voter is registered to vote in; and one of the electoral officials. (Part VIII, Sec. 173, Subsection 1(a)(b)(c) of the Elections and Referenda Act 1980) 
 
The voter shall mark his ballot paper in accordance with procedures laid down in the electoral instructions, but in such a way that the secrecy of the ballot is not infringed (except as allowed by Section 174 of this Chapter - Assistance to certain voters). (Part VIII, Sec. 173, Subsection 5 of the Elections and Referenda Act 1980) 
 
The voter (except those to whom Subsection (2) of this Section applies) must, prior to receiving ballot laterals from the election official, sign his name next to his printed name as it appears on the list of voters as provided in, accordance with Section 128. (Part VIII, Sec. 173, Subsection 6(a) of the Elections and Referenda Act 1980) 
 
Note that the voter who signs on the list of voters in accordance with Subsection 6(a) of this Section shall be deemed to be signing an affidavit, under penalty of law, as to the truthfulness of the facts stated in the voters list. (Part VIII, Sec. 173, Subsection 6(c) of the Elections and Referenda Act 1980)

election_commission_historical_context: The Central Electoral Board is the highest body of the Electoral Administration. It is permanent and has its headquarters in the Congress of Deputies in Madrid.  It is composed of eight Magistrates of the Supreme Court, appointed by means of insaculation by the General Council of the Judiciary; and five active professors of Law or Political Science and Sociology, appointed at the joint proposal of the parties, federations, coalitions or groups of voters with representation in the Congress of Deputies.  These appointments must be made within ninety days following the constitutive session of the Congress of Deputies. The Members are appointed by Royal Decree and continue in office until the new Central Electoral Board takes office at the beginning of the following Legislature. These elect, from among the Members of judicial origin, the President and the Vice President of the Board in the constitutive session.  The Secretary of the Central Electoral Board is the Secretary General of the Congress of Deputies. The Director of the Electoral Census Office is a non-voting member of the Central Electoral Board.  Source: http://www.juntaelectoralcentral.es/cs/jec/admelectoral/jecentral

government_functions.details: The King, a hereditary monarch, is the Spanish chief of state, while the President is the head of government. The President, typically the leader of the largest congressional party or coalition, is nominated by the King and elected by the Congress of Deputies.  The legislature (Cortes Generales) is composed of a Senate with 265 seats and a Congress of Deputies with 348 seats. Senators serve 4-year terms and are directly elected by plurality vote in multi-seat constituencies (208 seats) or indirectly elected by autonomous community legislatures (57 seats). Deputies serve 4-year terms and are directly elected via closed-list proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies (348 seats) or directly elected by plurality vote (2 seats in Ceuta and Melilla).  The Spanish judiciary is headed by the Supreme Court (president and 79 judges organized into thematic chambers) and the Constitutional Court (12 judges). Supreme Court judges are nominated by the General Council of the Judiciary Power (CGPJ) and appointed by the King. These judges may serve until they are 70 years old. Constitutional Court judges are nominated by the legislature, president, and CGPJ and appointed by the King to serve 9-year terms.

voting_methods.instructions: Article 75. Exercise of the vote by persons living abroad 1. In elections for Deputies, Senators, members of the Legislative Assemblies of the Autonomous Communities, members of the Assemblies of the Autonomous Cities of Ceuta and Melilla and Deputies to the European Parliament, when in the latter case the election is chosen in Spain, the Provincial Delegations of the Electoral Census Office shall send, ex officio, to the address of registration of each person of Spanish nationality registered in the census of resident-absent voters living abroad, the following documentation:  (a) The voting envelope or, as the case may be, the voting envelopes for each process called, with adequate security systems.  b) Two identical certificates of being registered in the census of absentee resident voters living abroad, except in the case of concurrent elections with scrutiny in different electoral boards, in which case the corresponding ones shall be sent according to said electoral concurrence.  c) The envelope or envelopes in which the address of the competent Electoral Board and the envelope in which the address of the Consular Post or Consular Section of the Diplomatic Mission in which he/she is registered shall appear,  d) An information sheet on how to exercise the right to vote and the address of the official website where the final candidacies shall be displayed, and where downloadable sets of ballots shall be available, with all the competing candidacies, as well as any other information on the electoral processes in progress, and  e) The list of centers authorized for the deposit of votes in ballot boxes in the area of their consular demarcation.  2. The ballot or ballots of the voters registered in the census of absent residents living abroad for each process called shall correspond to the official ballot, as well as to a downloadable model ballot approved by the Electoral Board. The information sheet that shall accompany the documentation referred to in the previous section shall contain the instructions for obtaining a set of ballots telematically in an accessible manner, with all the competing candidacies, as well as the means by which the voters shall be able to know the proclaimed candidacies.  In order to guarantee the secrecy of the vote, only the complete set of ballots may be downloaded telematically.  The Public Administrations shall guarantee the material and technical means to provide the voters with access to the information on the electoral process and to the downloadable ballots.  3. The electoral documentation referred to in the first paragraph shall be sent by registered mail as from the eighteenth day and before the twenty-fifth day following the call for elections.  The Provincial Delegations of the Electoral Census Office shall also send the official ballots to the address of registration of absentee voters living abroad, as of the twenty-ninth day and no later than the thirty-third day following the call, in those provinces where the proclamation of candidates has not been challenged, and in the remaining provinces, no later than the thirty-ninth day.  The downloadable ballots shall be available after the resolution of the appeals filed against the proclamation of candidacies and no later than the fifth day after the proclamation of candidacies.  The Public Administrations shall provide the necessary means in each case so that the mailings provided for in paragraphs 1, 3 and 8 of this Article are carried out in the quickest, safest and most efficient manner, including the diplomatic pouch and forwarding by internal mail of the corresponding country, to the extent that the Electoral Roll Office and the consular administration deem it necessary and possible.

Only OCV voters can vote by mail. 7. Voters who choose to exercise their right to vote by mail shall include in the envelope addressed to the corresponding Electoral Board, in addition to the voting envelope or envelopes, one of the certificates of being registered in the census, on the back of which shall be the signature and passport or National Identity Card number of the voter, a photocopy of the passport or National Identity Card issued by the Spanish authorities or a certificate of nationality or, failing this, a certificate of registration in the Consular Register issued by the Consular Office or the Consular Section of the Diplomatic Mission of Spain in the country of residence. All of the above shall be placed in the envelope addressed to the Consular Post or Consular Section of the Diplomatic Mission to which each voter is attached, and the other certificate of being registered in the census shall be included in this envelope. The documentation thus ordered shall be sent personally by the voter by postal mail, certified when possible, to the Consular Post or Consular Section of the Diplomatic Mission to which each voter is attached, no later than the fifth day prior to the day of the election.  Envelopes received by mail at the Consular Post or Consular Section of the Diplomatic Mission before the final proclamation of candidatures shall not be valid. Those arriving after the second day prior to the day of the election shall not be valid either. This deadline shall not be extended in order to ensure that the votes arrive in time to be counted by the Electoral Boards.

Article 32 LOREG 1. Registration in the electoral roll is compulsory. In addition to the name and surname, the only data necessary for the identification of the voter in the act of voting, without prejudice to the provisions of Article 85, the number of the National Identity Card shall be included among the remaining census data.  2. The Municipal Councils shall process the registration of the residents in their municipal district ex officio.  3. The Consular Posts and Consular Sections of the Diplomatic Missions shall ex officio process the registration of Spaniards residing in their demarcation in the manner established by regulation.

voting_methods.instructions: The voter must return to the Consular Office of ballot papers voted in the following mode:  1) Insert only the ballots voted into the small color envelope and close it;  2) insert the small envelope in the envelope already stamped with the address of the Consular Office;  3) insert the electoral certificate coupon into the envelope already stamped;  4) Close the envelope that has already been stamped and send it to the Consular Office so that it arrives within the day and time mentioned.  DON'T ADD THE SENDER on the already stamped envelope

The voter goes to the polling station identified in their personal electoral card along with a suitable identification card and hands the card and identification to the polling officials.  The polling officials verify their identity and location on the electoral rolls.  The officials provide the voter with a pencil and two ballot papers, one for the Senate and one for the Chamber of Deputies, and direct the voter to a booth to vote in secret.  The voter marks their paper.  They must use a pencil to mark their papers.  In either contest, they can vote by marking either a candidate contesting the single constituency or the closed list linked to it or both.  A single mark on the candidate will also operate as a vote for the linked closed list and vice versa.  Voters cannot split their vote between a candidate linked to one list or coalition and a different list or coalition.   After voting they hand their ballots and the pencil to the polling officials who, while protecting the secrecy of the vote, undertake a check to confirm the ballots were those that the voter was issued.  The officials return the voter their election card and identification.

voting_methods.instructions: Voters wanting to vote by mail must apply for a postal ballot with the Fiji Electoral Office and the application must be received no later than 21 days before polling; once approved, during the polling, the voter must use the Voter Instruction Booklet to identify the number of the candidate voters would like to vote for, and circle or tick or cross the number of the candidate on the ballot paper. After voting, voters must fold the ballot paper and place it inside the Secret Envelope, seal it, and put it inside the Transmission Envelope. Voters must complete and sign the Declaration Form at the back of the Transmission Envelope, place it in the Return Envelope then send it by the courier to the address printed in front of the Return Envelope. (Fijian Elections Office: Election Information Booklet)

The voter shall vote by use of a secret envelope, as prescribed for postal voting. After having voted, the voter must fold the pre-poll ballot paper and insert it in the secret envelope and seal the secret envelope; the voter must put the completed and sealed envelope into a ballot box and must not mark the secret envelope in any manner.

After the identification process, and upon the receipt of the ballot paper, the voters must: -retire to a voting screen -secretly mark their vote on the ballot paper in the way prescribed in section 54 (by placing a circle around, or a tick or a cross on the number of their preferred candidate on the ballot paper) -fold the ballot paper to conceal their vote -after voters have marked their vote and before they placed the ballot paper in the ballot box, have one finger marked with an indelible substance -deposit the ballot paper in a ballot box in the presence of the Presiding Officer or a designated election official

government_functions.details: In Uzbekistan, the President serves as chief of state, while the Prime Minister serves as head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two 7-year terms. The Prime Minister is nominated by the majority party in the Supreme Assembly and appointed by the President.   Uzbekistan has a bicameral Supreme Assembly consisting of a 100-seat Senate and a 150-seat Legislative Chamber. Members of the Senate are indirectly elected by regional councils (84 members) or appointed by the president (16 members). All members serve 5-year terms. All 150 members of the Legislative Chamber are directly elected by absolute majority vote in single-seat constituencies and serve 5-year terms.  The Supreme Court and Constitutional Court are the highest judicial bodies of Uzbekistan. The Supreme Court has 67 judges, while the Constitutional Court has only 7. Judges for both institutions are nominated by the President and confirmed by the Senate. Judges may serve one term of 10 years.

government_functions.details:
The Czech Republic or Czechia is a parliamentary republic. The President is directly elected and serves a five-year term. The President appoints the Prime Minister. 

Czech parliament consists of the 81-seat Senate and the 200-seat Chamber of Deputies. Both houses are directly elected. 

The judiciary is comprised of the Supreme Court, the Supreme Administrative Court, and the Constitutional Court. Supreme Court judges are proposed by the lower house of parliament and are appointed for life.

voting_methods.instructions:
Ballots for the presidential election are printed separately for each candidate; voters will receive the ballots no later than 3 days before the day of the first round of elections amd for any second round, voters will only receive their ballots at the polling station. Voters are required to vote at the electoral district in which they are registered in the voter lists. However, a voter can apply for an absentee voting certificate which allows them to vote in a polling station outside the electoral district in which they are registered, either on the terriroty of the Czech Republic or at a diplomatic mission abroad (the certificate must be handed in at the polling station where they choose to vote). At a polling station, the voter must prove his/her identity and citizenship of the Czech Republic with the necessary document. Each voter must vote in person; No proxy voting is allowed. The voter receives an empty official envelope, stamped with the official stamp of the district election commission. Upon request, the commission will also issue the voter a set of ballots.  With the official envelope and the ballots, the voter must go to the area designated for inserting the ballot into the official envelope. Otherwise, the voter will not be allowed to vote. The voter places one ballot for the candidate for whom she/he has decided to vote in the official envelope. The ballot cannot be modified in any way. The voter votes by inserting the official envelope with the selected ballot into the ballot box in front of the precinct election commission. Assisted voting is allowed for voters who are disabled or illiterate, but only another voter (not a poll worker) can assist.  Mobile voting is also available for home-bound voters upon request. Voting also takes place in medical and similar facilities, according to special voter lists.

The stamp on the official envelope is the stamp of a munucipal authority or an embassy. The commissions do not have its own stamp. The voter has to be in the designated area alone, except for the people with disabilites.

A voter can vote abroad in a special electoral district at the embassies and consular offices of the Czech Republic. Out-of-country voting is possible in two ways. Firstly, on the basis of registration in a special list of voters maintained by the embassy/consulate (in case of a long-term stay), with a registration deadline of no later than 40 days before the election day.  An absentee voting certificate can be issued for a voter who is registered at an embassy/consulate which allows them to vote at another embassy/consulate or polling station on the territory of the Czech Republic. Voters with a permanent residence in the Czech Republic but who register at an embassy will be removed from the permanent list of voters kept by the respective municipal office (when removed from the special voters list at an embassy/consullate, the voter will be put back on the permanent voter list in the Czech Republic.) Secondly, a voter with permanent residence in the Czech Republic can vote at any embassy abroad using a standard absentee voting certificate which they apply for ahead of the election. The Ministry of Interior sends the ballot papers electronically to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, which forwards them to the diplomatic missions no later than 3 days before the election day. The diplomatic missions are to secure the printing or copying of the ballot papers. Voters who vote at diplomatic missions are to receive the ballots papers in the polling station. The method of voting at diplomatic missions is the same as for voting inside the territory of the Czech Republic. 

2012 Presidential Elections Act, Article 28(5), 31, 33

campaign_finance.details: The law provides for a mixed campaign finance system, including both public and private financing. Political parties receive public funding for the reimbursement of campaign expenses and for their regular activities proportionally to the number of votes received in the parliamentary elections and the number of seats obtained. The laws do not restrict sources for private campaign funding, but prohibit anonymous contributions and set overall campaign spending limits for each election type. For the first round of the presidential election, maximum campaign expenses for each candidate are set at CZK 40 million, while the total expenses for each of the two candidates reaching a potential second round are set at CZK 50 million. The limits include in-kind donations and campaign expenses incurred by third parties (a third party can spend up to CZK 1,800,000 per campaign.) Contestants must open a dedicated bank account to carry out campaign-related transactions. Each contestant as well as third parties are subject to public disclosure of campaign income and expenses on their specially dedicated websites, including publication of detailed financial reports 90 days after the promulgation of the election results and submission of the reports to a supervisory body. The oversight body registers third parties for their campaign activities, publishes the campaign finance reports on its website, and applies sanctions for potential infringements.

government_functions.details:
Slovakia is a parliamentary republic. The President is the chief of state and is directly elected by an absolute majority popular vote in two rounds if necessary. The President must be nominated by no less than 15 member of the National Council, per the Constitution. The President selects the Prime Minister (typically, the leader of the winning party or coalition). The Prime Minster must win a vote of confidence in the National Council prior to being officially confirmed. 

Parliament consists of the unicameral National Council. The Council has 150 seats, all of which are directly elected to serve four-year terms. 

The judiciary is comprised of the Supreme Court of the Slovak Republic and the Constitutional Court of the Slovak Republic.

The President of Micronesia serves as both the chief of state and head of government. The President is indirectly elected by Congress from among four senators-at-large.   The Micronesian legislature is composed of a unicameral Congress with 14 seats. All members of Congress are directly elected. 10 members are elected by plurality vote in single-seat constituencies and serve 2-year terms. An additional “at large” member is elected from each of the four Micronesian states by proportional representation vote, and these members serve 4-year terms.   The Supreme Court is the highest court of the Micronesian judiciary and consists of up to six judges split into two divisions. These judges are nominated by the President and confirmed by a two-thirds vote of Congress. Judges may serve for life.

election_commission_historical_context:
Election commissions are the state election management bodies that organize preparation and holding of elections in the Republic of Kazakhstan. The term of office of the election commissions is five years.

The unified system of election commissions is formed of:


 
 the Central Election Commission of the Republic (hereinafter – the CEC);
 
 
 territorial election commissions;
 
 
 precinct election commissions.
 


The CEC heads the unified system of election commissions of the Republic and is a permanent body. It is responsible for preparation of matters relating to application of penalties to MPs, the rules of parliamentary ethics as well as termination of powers of MPs, deprivation of their powers and immunity.

President of the Republic of Kazakhstan appoints the CEC Chairperson and two members for a term of five years, each of Parliament chambers independently without participation of other chamber appoints two CEC members for a term of five years. Deputy Chairperson and Secretary of the CEC are elected at the first session of the commission.

The Central Election Commission has its office. Expenditures for the CEC and its office are financed from the republican budget.

If within the deadlines set by maslikhat there were no proposals from political parties then the maslikhat shall form the election commission upon proposals of other public associations and higher election commissions.

The higher election commission is eligible to appoint a member of election commission instead of retired one till the election of a member of election commission by maslikhat in the order to be established in the law on elections.

A political party may nominate to the election commission candidatures, who are not members of this political party.

Political parties, which don’t have a representative in election commission, are eligible to delegate to the relevant election commission their representative with advisory vote for the period of election campaign.

The main authorities of election commissions of the Republic of Kazakhstan

The Central Election Commission shall:


 
 carry out on the territory of the Republic the control on implementation of the electoral legislation and ensure its unified application; take decisions within its competence to be binding on the entire territory of the Republic;
 
 
 organize preparation and conduct of elections of the President and deputies of the Mazhilis of Parliament; direct the organization and conduct of election of deputies of the Senate of Parliament;
 
 
 during organization and conduct of elections of maslikhats and other bodies of local self-government provide methodological guidance to territorial election commissions and monitor their activities on compliance to the requirements of electoral legislation.

government_functions.details: Kazakhstan is a unitary state with a presidential form of government. The President is the head of the state and is directly elected by simple majority popular vote for a 7 year term. The Prime Minister and Deputy Prime Ministers are approved by the lower house of parliament following nomination by the President.   Kazakh parliament is a bicameral system that consists of the 50-sear Senate and the 98-seat Mazhilis. 40 Senate members are indirectly elected by oblast-level assemblies and 10 members are appointed by decree of the President. Members of the Mazhilis are directly elected.   The highest levels of the judiciary are comprised of the Supreme Council of the Republic (44 members) and the Constitutional Council (7 members, including a chairperson).
