voting_methods.instructions: The election law provides for the establishment of two special polling places in other territories: one in Guam and one in Honolulu. The law expressly prohibits the establishment of any other special polling places abroad.   Voters who will be in those territories on election day can apply in writing to the national election commissioner of the state of registration not later than 30 days prior to the election day to vote at one of those special polling places on election day. The notice requirement can be waived if the person had applied in an earlier election for such absentee voting at that special polling place on a default basis. At the out-of-country polling place, the voter must present himself or herself as they would at a polling place inside Micronesia and the ballots are to be issued in the same manner. The election legislation does not elaborate procedures on the manner of voting, which may be included in regulations issued by the national election board.

Postal voting is available for voters who will be outside their state of registration on the election day, either inside Micronesia or out-of-country. A request to vote by mail should be sent to the national commissioner of the state in which the voter is registered. Alternatively, if the voter resides in a foreign country where Micronesia maintains an embassy or consulate, he or she can send the request to the embassy or consultate which shall then forward the request to the national election director or his or her designee, for verification and processing.  A postal voters shall indicate on the request form whether he or she intends to pick up the postal ballot at the embassy/consulate.  Within two days of receipt, the national election commissioner shall mail back to the requester the postal ballot provided the printed ballots are available, or otherwise to send them no later than five days after the postal ballots are printed. Ten days before the election day, the embassies/consulates are to be provided with sufficient postal ballots for voters to pick up if requested. Voters who request postal ballots are to be struck off the signature list for that voter's regular polling place. Postal ballot packages include an official ballot, a ballot envelope, an affidavit, and a covering reply envelope. The postal voter marks the ballot in the usual manner provided by law and in secret. The voter then inserts the ballot in the envelope and securely seals the envelope. Then the voter completes and executes the affidavit. The ballot envelope and the affidavit are to be enclosed and sealed in the covering reply envelope . The envelope is to be posted to the national election commissioner of the state that issued the postal ballot or the voter can deliver the envelope to the embassy/consulate where he or she had requested the postal ballot, if he or she had done so. All postal ballots must be received by the national election commissioner or the embassy/consulate, as applicable, by the established closing hour of the polls on election day. Postal ballots received at a post office in Micronesia must be stamped with the time and date of receipt.

Registered voters who will be travelling outside their state of registration (to another state or out of the country) on election day may cast a ballot at a designated 'traveller polling place' prior to their departure from the state.  Not more than 30 days and not less than one day prior to the election day, the voter must submit in person to the national election commissioner of the state of registration a written request to cast a ballot prior to travelling outside his or her state of registration. The voter must submit proof, in the form of an airline or passenger ship ticket, of his or her travel plans. Upon approval, the voter is issued the same voting materials that are issued to postal voters. The law provides that the same procedures for marking, returning, and disposition of the postal ballots shall apply to the marking, returning and disposition of the traveller's advance ballots. However, at the same time, the law provides that the traveller's ballot is to be 'cast' at a designated traveller polling place, where he or she must present himself or herself as they would in a regular polling place. As such, it is unclear whether the voter posts the ballot or must deliver it to the traveller polling place. The national election director or his or her designee shall strike out or delete the entry of the  early voter on the signature list for that voter's regular polling place.

In general, voters must vote at the polling place where they appear on the so-called signature list (essentially a voter list). However, voters who will be absent from their electoral district on election day but will be within their state can apply in writing not later than seven days before the election day to vote at any polling place within their state (their name will be deleted from the signature list of their regular polling place). Also, a voter who has a voter identification card may vote in any polling place within their state without having to submit a written request.  In addition, voters who will be outside of their state on election day but within the country can apply in writing not later than 30 days prior to the election day to vote at a special designated polling place in the state where they will be located on election day.  In certain circumstances, the 7-day and 30-day notice requirements can be waived, including if the person had applied in an earlier election for absentee voting in that same polling place on a default basis.  A person appearing at any regular or special polling place to vote shall report his or her full name to the election board members. If the person has been issued a voter identification card, he or she must present it to the election board members in order to vote. If the person has not been issued a voter identification card, then he or she shall present other proof of identity. An election board member checks the signature list  to determine whether or not the person appearing is a registered voter for that election district and if so, shall announce the name appearing on the list. Once the person's identity is established and entry has been found on the list, the voter shall sign his or her full name next to his or her entry on the list. An election board member issues the person an official ballot, and, if the person has presented a voter identification card, marks the card so as to indicate that the person has already voted. If a person's name does not appear on the signature list they cannot vote except in the following circumstances where they will be added to a supplemental signature list. The circumstances are: the voter presenting a valid voter identification card for that polling place and which does not indicate that the person has already voted; the voter's name appears on the national voter register but is not on the signature list at that polling place in the election district where he or she resides and has voted in at least one prior election and is not listed in any other polling place; the voter's name appears on the national voter register and on a signature list of a polling place in an election district where he or she does not reside and the voter did not apply for absentee voting. Any election board member, poll watcher or registered voter may challenge the identity or eligibility to vote of any person that appears at the polling place to vote on election day, by fileing an oral or written complaint. The board member is to give the challenged voter time to present witnesses and an explanation, if any, provided the decision is made prior to the close of polls. The decision may be appealed to the national election commissioner of the respective state, whose decision can be further appealed to the national election director. An election board member must record in the official log book for the polling place, the identifying informaton of any person who is not allowed to cast a ballot, and the reason for the disallowance. The person not allowed to vote shall then sign the log book next to the entry. The election legislation does not elaborate the procedures for the manner of voting, other than stating that all national elections shall be by secret ballot, which may be included in regulations issued by the national election board. The election law does provide that write-in votes may be used in national elections, whereby any name written upon a ballot shall be counted as a vote for that person. The law further provides that any voter who spoils a ballot may return it to a member of the election board and receive another one in its place, provided that the number of ballots given to him or her does not exceed three in all. Mobile voting also takes place on election day (or the day before the election day), whereby voters who are confined to their homes, hospitals or places of incarceration can submit a written request not more than 120 days before election day to vote at their place of confinement. If the voter is unable to personally complete or deliver the request form then the voter can request the assistance of a family  member. Mobile voters must vote in their place of confinement in secrecy, but any mobile voter who, by reason of physical disability, is unable to mark their ballot, is authorized to receive assistance to mark it.  Mobile voters and the election officials who assist these voters to vote may be required to submit an affidavit or other written statements to the national election director.

campaign_finance.details: Political parties are neither recognized nor banned in Micronesia, and there is no legislation regulating campaign finance matters.  There are no political parties in Micronesia.

election_commission_historical_context: During the 2018 House of Assembly elections, the Elections and Boundaries Commission conducted both the primary and secondary level elections in a generally well-organized, professional and timely manner despite some budgetary constraints. However, the closing of polling stations and transportation of ballots to central counting centers, rather than holding counting at polling station level, had the potential to compromise the security of the ballot as well as transparency and credibility of the counting process.
source: Preliminary Statement of the African Union Election Observation Mission to the 2018 General Elections in the Kingdom of Eswatini

government_functions.details:
Eswatini is an absolute monarchy. The Monarch is the chief of state and the monarchy is hereditary. The successor to the monarchy is determined by Swazi law and custom and is called the Crown Prince or Umntfwana. The Prime Minister is appointed by the monarch from among the members of the House of Assembly. 

The legislative branch is bicameral. The Senate has 30 total seats. 10 seats are indirectly elected by the House of Assembly. The other 20 seats are appointed by the monarchy. In the House of Assembly, the majority of members are directly elected, although 10 members are directly appointed by the monarch. Per the Constitution, there is a maximum of 76 seats in the Assembly, however, there is a provision wherein 4 of these seats can be allocated to ensure representation of women. These seats are elected by members of the Assembly.

The judiciary is comprised of the Supreme Court (which has a chief justice and at least 4 justices) and the High Court. The Supreme Court has jurisdiction over all constitutional matters. Justices of both courts are appointed by the monarch with the advice of the Judicial Service Commission.

prominent_political_groups.data: 1998 Non-partisans (100.0%), 2018 Independents (100.0%),

voting_methods.instructions: Out-of-country registered voters may cast a ballot in person at a diplomatic mission in their country of residence. These include the office of each Ambassador, High Commissioner, and Trade Representative, as the case may be. The election legislation does not provide specific locations, times or instructions for out-of-country voting. These will likely be specified in regulations adopted by the election commission.

Electors vote at specified polling stations in the chiefdom where they are registered  as a voter unless a special polling arrangement has been prescribed. Electors vote first in the primary elections among their chiefdom's candidates and then on another day in the secondary elections among the winning chiefdom candidates within that constituency. Voting is only in person. On arrival at the polling station, a voter presents his/her voter ID card to an election official. The official then checks for the voter's name in the voter register. If the voter is registered but does not have a voter card, he/she must prove to the presiding officer that he/she is the one whose name appears on the voter register. The election official is also required to determine that the voter has not already voted in the election by checking that the voter's name is not marked off the voter register (in past elections, indelible ink on the index finger has also been used). Next, the election official issues the voter an ordinary ballot. A  tendered ballot is issued if the voter's name on the register is already marked as voted and the voter properly answers a set of specified questions and makes and signs a declaration that he/she has not already voted (the voter's registration number is put on the back of the tendered ballot and entered on the tendered ballots register).  The presiding officer can refuse to issue a ballot paper to the voter if an objection by declarationn on oath is made by a candidate, agent or voter on grounds that the person is impersonating a dead or incapacitated voter and the election officer is not satisfied of the person's claimed identity; the refusal can be appealed to the returning officer. Next, the election official calls out the number of the voter on the voter register, enters the number in the space provided on the counterfoil of the issued ballot, tears out the ballot paper and marks it with the official mark on the back of the ballot, folds the ballot paper in four so that the face of the ballot is on the inside and the official mark on the outside, then unfolds it and hands it to the voter, and draws a line in red ink through the number and name or photograph of the voter in the voter register as evidence that the ballot has been issued. Voting is by secret ballot in both primary and secondary elections. The voter goes immediately with the ballot paper to an unoccupied polling booth and in secret puts a marks on the picture of one candidate of his/her choice. The voter then folds the ballot so that the face of it is on the inside and places it in the respective ballot box. If the election officer has any doubt that the ballot was not the one issued at the polling station, he/she may require the voter to show the presiding officer the number and official mark on the back of the ballot paper before it is inserted in the ballot box.  Tendered ballots are placed the presiding officer in a separate envelope. Any voter who is illiterate or has a physical disability can request the presiding officer to assist or to allow a person accompanying that voter to assist him/her cast a ballot. The assisting person is bound to keep the secrecy of the vote. The presiding officer is to record in the voter register that the voter has been assisted by him/her or an accompanying person and the reason for doing so. A voter who inadvertently spoils his/his ballot paper may return it to the presiding officer for a new ballot paper. After voting, a voter must immediately leave the polling station.

campaign_finance.details: A candidate who intends to spend money in his/her campaign is required to open an election expenses account where all resources, including donations, have to be deposited, and from which all expenses are to be paid. The law forbids candidates to receive funds from proscribed organizations and donors outside the country. Three days after the primary election, candidates are to disclose to the election commission the amount of funds available and expected to finance his/her campaign in the secondary election. The Minister of Justice is to prescribe the maximum amount a candidate can use on election expenses, to be approved by parliament. Within 90 days after the secondary election, candidates are to submit a report on their campaign expenses.  The law allows the head of the election commission to search any premises without a court-issued search warrant or notice in relation to the inspection of candidates' expenses.

election_issues: Immigration; climate/environment; economy; energy; social policy

government_functions.details:
Switzerland is a federal republic. The President, Vice President, and second Vice President are elected by Parliament from the Federal Council to serve 1-year, non-consecutive terms. The Federal Council is an entity comprised of 7 federal councillors. These councillors are indirectly elected by the Federal Assembly for a 4-year term. 

Switzerland has a bicameral parliament that consists of the Council of States (comprised of 46 members that represent Cantons) and the National Council (which has open elections). Both houses have equal standing under the Constitution. Jointly, parliament is called the Federal Assembly. 

The Federal Supreme Court is the highest level of the judiciary. Judges serve for six-year terms.

voting_methods.instructions:
For National Council elections, citizens resident abroad can register to vote in the canton in which they last reside (of their canton of citizenship otherwise) and are able to vote no matter how long since, or whether they ever have, lived in Switzerland. Swiss citizens abroad must join the Register of the Swiss Abroad and be registered on the electoral roll of their last commune of residence (or place of origin if they have never lived in Switzerland) by filling out a form online or at an embassy. Once registered for the first time, the person remains in the register unless the voting materials to the voter were returned undeliverable for three times in a row.

Swiss citizens abroad can vote by post in the same manner as in-country postal voting, and those registered in cantons participating in federal online voting pilot projects may also cast their vote online.

Online voting is only through federally approved pilots in the cantons, which are currently restricted to a maximum of 10 per cent of the country's electorate. This limit does not apply to Swiss citizens living abroad but out-of-country voters can vote online only if their canton of registration is utilizing online voting.

The federal legislation provides minimum standards for internet voting pilots to be introduced and implemented  by cantons. Comprehensive end-to-end testing of internet voting systems  must take place before the Federal Counil can approve their use. The law includes requirements for publishing the source code, providing voter information, and allowing voters to familiarize with and to test internet voting outside of an election. The legislation requires that verification of eligibility to vote and voting secrecy be guaranteed and abuses prevented in the use of online voting system. All internet voting systems are required to provide voters with the possiblity to individually verify that their vote has been cast as intended. Eligible voters will receive codes and their voter identification card that will allow them to check that their ballot is recorded correctly and corresponds to their intention. The federal authorities have also undertaken measures to promote cyber security and data protection in online voting systems.

All voters automatically receive the official voting materials by post ahead of election day; if they choose to vote by post, they can do so as soon as the voting materials are received between three to four weeks before the election day.  All cantons are required to provide a postal voting option, including to citizens residing abroad. 

The delivery by post of the official voting materials to all voters is mandated for between three to four weeks prior to election day, to be sent by the commune in which the voter is registered to vote. The cantons are mandated to enact provisions regulating postal voting, including to guarantee the verification of eligibility to vote, voting secrecy and the counting of all the votes, and to prevent abuses. Voters who choose to vote by post, follow the postal voting instructions in the voting materials sent to them.  The voter must send their identification card, using a double envelope system, with the ballot to prevent the possibility of voting additionally at a polling station. Once the voter has filled out his/her ballot these are put into an anonymous return envelope provided in the package. This first anonymous envelope and the identification card are placed into the return envelope and then sent back to the municipality.  In some municipalities, the envelope can be returned directly to the municipality mailbox. Otherwise, the envelope is to be returned by post; in some cantons postage does not have to be paid.

Under federal law, cantons are obliged to provide early voting at polling stations for a minimum of two of the four days immediately prior to election day.  Cantonal law specifies the time that all or certain polling stations will be open for advance voting. Instead of opening polling stations on advance polling days, the canton can allow voters to hand over their ballot paper in a sealed envelope at a public office.

The manner of early voting is the same as for voting on election day, whereby the voter brings the ballots that were sent to him/her by post ahead of the election day to cast at the polling station or to hand  over in a sealed envelope at a public office, whichever means is provided by the canton. The cantons are mandated to enact the required provisions relating to the preservation of voting secrecy and the prevention of abuses in early voting processes.

All voters receive the official voting materials by post to their home address between three to four weeks ahead of election day by the commune in which the voter is registered to vote. The Federal Chancellory is required by law to issue brief instructions on voting procedures prior to each general elecction, which are delivered along with the voting materials to voters in cantons with a system of proportional representation. If the voter wishes to vote in-person (rather than postal vote), he/she takes the ballots that weree previously received by post and drops them off at the polling station where they are registered to vote. At the  polling station, the voter must present his/her identification card. Votes may be cast by proxy at the polling station provided the cantonal law permits this for cantonal elections. Persons who are unable to write may have their ballot paper completed in accordance with their instructions by a person of their chose who is eligible to vote. Voting secrecy must be preserved in the voting process. In cantons where the proportional list system is used for the National Council elections, voters may cross out names on party lists or write names twice, split their vote between parties or draw up their own lists on a blank ballot combining candidates from different lists within the constituency.

campaign_finance.details: Under federal law, political parties represented in the Federal Assembly are obliged to declare all income, as well as donations above CHF15,000. Organizers of election campaigns for the National Council have to declare donations above CHF15,000 (including in-kind donations) and expenses if more than CHF50,000 has been spent. Those elected to the Council of States must declare donations above CHF15,000 and expenses if more than CHF50,000 has been spent. A final statement of campaign income must be submitted for these campaigns. Anonymous political donations and donations from abroad (except from Swiss citizens) are generally prohibited, with the exception of those funding campaigns for the Council of States. The Swiss Federal Audit Office checks whether the declarations are complete and submitted on time. It carries out sample checks on the accuracy of the information provided. It reports any infringements to the prosecution authorities. Persons or organisations prosecuted face a fine of up to CHF 40,000. Some cantons have adopted their own legislation on campaign finance.

election_name.en_US: Democratic Republic of the Congo President 2023

election_commission_historical_context: The Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) is an institution in Support of Democracy, enshrined in the Organic Law No. 10/013 of 28 July 2010 on the organization, powers and functioning of this Institution. The Constitution establishes an Electoral Commission to conduct the DRC’s first democratic election since 1960. Article 154 of the Constitution establishes the Commission, which is made up of twenty-one members. The chairperson is nominated by civil society and his/her appointment is ratified by the National Assembly. The other Commissioners are jointly designated by different entities from the Inter-Congolese Dialogue and must also be ratified by the National Assembly. The Commissioners are appointed for the duration of the transition period and can only be removed from office for failure to discharge their functions, misappropriation of public funds or conviction of high treason or corruption. The Commission has a Plenary Assembly which is responsible for its management. This Assembly consists of the chairperson and seven other Commissioners. The latter supervise different special units within the Commission while the chairperson is the overall supervisor of these special units. These special units of the commission are divided into: Electoral and civic education; Voters and candidates registration; Logistics; Electoral training; Legal and contentious matters; Polling operations and collecting results; Communication and public relations. The Constitution grants the Commission legal personality and further provides that it shall be autonomous and impartial in the performance of its mandate. Article 6 of the Constitution spells out the functions of the Commission. It is tasked with the responsibility to freely and fairly conduct and supervise elections during the transition period. In addition to administrative autonomy, the Constitution also guarantees the Commission financial autonomy. The Commission has its own budget. CENI is an organization of independent Congolese public law; it is neutral and has legal personality. It has administrative and financial autonomy. It has its own budget and employment of staff may be supplemented by external inputs. The Independent National Electoral Commission has the independence of action in relation to the other institutions of the Republic. However, in the exercise of its mission, it benefits from the collaboration of these institutions.

government_functions.details: The President of the DRC serves as chief of state while the Prime Minister acts as head of government. The President is directly elected by plurality vote and may serve two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is appointed by the President.  The DRC has a bicameral Parliament composed of a 109-seat Senate and a 500-seat National Assembly. Within the Senate, 108 members are indirectly elected by provincial assemblies and serve 5-year terms. The final member is former president Joseph Kabila who is allowed to serve for life. Within the National Assembly, 439 members are elected by proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies, and 61 members are elected by plurality vote in single-seat constituencies. All members are directly elected and serve 5-year terms.  The DRC has two high courts: the Court of Cassation and the Constitutional Court. The Court of Cassation has 26 judges who are nominated by the Judicial Service Council. The Constitutional Court has 9 judges who are nominated by either the President, the Judicial Service Council, or the Parliament and appointed by the President. Constitutional Court judges serve a 9-year term.

institution.term_details: Article 73 The ballot for the election of the President of the Republic is convoked by the Independent National Electoral Commission, ninety days before the expiration of the mandate of the President in office. Article 74 The elected President of the Republic enters into his functions within the ten days which follow the proclamation of the definitive results of the presidential election.

government_functions.details: The President of Poland serves as chief of state while the Prime Minister acts as head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and may serve two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is appointed by the President and confirmed by the Sejm.  Poland has a bicameral Parliament composed of a 100-seat Senate and a 460-seat Sejm. Senators are directly elected by plurality vote in single-seat constituencies and serve 4-year terms. Members of the Sejm are directly elected by party-list proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies and serve 4-year terms. Parties must earn at least 5% of the national vote to gain a seat in the Sejm, and coalitions must earn 8% of the vote with minority parties excepted from this standard.  Poland has two high courts: the Supreme Court and the Constitutional Tribunal. The Supreme Court is composed of 121 judges separated into thematic chambers. Supreme Court judges are nominated by the National Judicial Council and confirmed by the President, and they may serve until age 65. The Constitutional Tribunal is composed of 15 judges appointed by the Sejm to serve a 9-year term.

voting_methods.instructions: Any eligible voter residing abroad, temporarily or permanently, can cast a vote from outside Poland. Citizens  who will be out of the country on election day can apply for an absentee voting certificate and vote at any polling station abroad.  There are 402 overseas polling places. Overseas voters can cast votes in-person at polling stations established at embassies/consulates (and possible other locations) or, 15 days before the election day, can apply for postal voting to the respective consul and receive a voting package sent out not later than 10 days before election day.  The number and offices of the overseas polling stations  are determined by the minister of foreign affairs in consultation with the National Election Commission, on the basis of establishing a polling station where there are at least 15 registered voters and establishing at least one polling station within the territorial responsiblity of the consultate to facilitate postal voting. Voters living abroad and holding a valid Polish passport (or valid ID in countries where Polish citizens can enter with only a Polish ID card) can be entered into the voter list compiled by the respective consulate, based on personal application lodged verbally, in writing, or by phone, fax or electronically. The foreign ministry, in consultaton with the National Election Commission, is to issue a regulation that will ensure that an overseas voter is entered on only one voter list.  Voters in possession of an absentee voting certificate issued in Poland can vote abroad at any polling station.  Citizens permanently living abroad can be entered on the voter list of a consultate on election, provided the voter presents proof of permament residence abroad in which case the commission places its seal and date of votong on the free page of the passport dedicated to visas and enters the passport number and validity date in the remarks section of the voter list.  The in-person oveseas voting process is the same as for in-country voting, except for the Polish passport requirement in countries where Polish citizens cannot enter without a passport and proxy voting is not permitted in overseas voting. For overseas postal voting, the voting package includes an addressed return envelope, the ballot paper(s), a ballot paper envelope, a statement of personal and secret casting of the vote, and voting instructions. The postal voter is to mark the ballot, and insert the marked ballot into the ballot paper envelope, seal the envelope and insert it into the return envelope together with the signed declaration (a statement of personal and secret casting of the vote) and return it by mail at his or her own cost to the address of the consul. Voters can also deliver the postal vote in the envelope in person to the respective consul. The consul transfers all returned envelopes that it received by the end of voting time to the appropriate election commission.

In-country postal voting is limited to those who can produce a disability certificate or who are at least 60 years old or who are in mandatory quarantine or isolation on election day.  Eligible in-country postal voters must apply for postal voting at least 12 days before the election day and receive a voting package which includes an addressed return envelope, the ballot paper(s), a ballot paper envelope, a declaration of personal and secret casting of the vote, and voting instructions. The postal voter is to mark the ballot, and insert the marked ballot into the ballot paper envelope, seal the envelope and insert it into the return envelope together with the signed declaration and return it by mail at his or her own cost or drop it off at the office of the designated operator or the respective post office.  Voters can also choose to have their marked ballot picked up at their place of residence provided that they request this service at the time of collecting the voting package.  Voters must provide documentary proof of identity when returning postal ballots.

Citizens are included in the voter list at their permanent place of residence. Until voter lists are finalized, voters can apply to obtain an Absentee Voting Certficate, enabling them to vote at any polling station. These voters are removed from the voter list in their place of residence and added to the supplementary voter list of the precinct where the vote was cast on election day. On the day of voting, the precinct election commission can add omitted persons to the voter list with proof of permanent residence on the territory of the given voting circuit, provided that the office of the municipality has confirmed that it has not received a notice of this person’s forfeiture of the right to vote or notice of the inclusion of that person on the roll of voters of another voting circuit. Proxy voting is prohibited except that voters with a significant or moderate degree of disability within the meaning of the law or who are over 60 can formally give another person their proxy vote (a proxy vote can be taken only from one person or two if immediate family member, and cannot be given to election commission members or partisan agents). Upon arrival at the polling station, a voter must provide proof of identity to the election commission. A stamped ballot paper is issued and the voter confirms receipt with his/her signature on the voter list. The voter must mark the ballot in the polling booth that guarantees secrecy. For Sejm elections, the voter must vote for only one candidate list with an "X" in the box to the left side next to the name of one of the candidates from this list, which indicates this candidates priority in obtaining the mandate; for Senat elections, the voter puts an "X" in the box to the left of the chosen candidate. The voter inserts the ballot in the ballot box located in a visible position, in such a way that the printed side of ballot is not visible. Upon request by a disabled voter, another person who is not a poll worker or partisan observer can assist the voter to vote.

campaign_finance.details: Political parties that received more than three percent of the votes cast (six percent for coalition) in the previous Sejm elections are entitled to annual public funding. Each political party, coalition and voters' group that obtains at least one seat in the Sejm, Senat or European Palriament is eligible for a subsequent one-time state subsidy. The subsidy is proportionate to the number of mandates obtained and is calculated on the basis of the entity's campaign expenses, which are not to exceed the spending limit. All campaigns must be financed through electoral committees; voters' electoral committees may be financed from private donations or loans, while party and coalition electoral committees are financed only from the designated electoral funds of political parties. The law permits candidates' contributions (up to 45 times the minimum monthly salary) as well as private donations from citizens  with permanent domicile in the country (up to 15 times the minimum monthly salary). Anonymous donations and contributions from foreign sources and legal entities are prohibited. Electoral committees may accept in-kind contributions to their campaigns from individuals. There is no obligation for interim financial reporting to any institutions during elections. However, all electoral committees are required to declare, on their websites, loans and private donations exceeding one minimum monthly salary every sevens days of receipt subject to a fine for non-compliance. Sources of funding of politcal parties' electoral funds are reported only within the parties' annual reports submitted to the National Election Commission (NEC). Failure to submit the annual report is subject to deregistration of the party. A spending limit is calculated for each electoral committee based on the number of registered voters and the number of mandates contested by that committee. An electoral committee that fields candidates in all constituencies is allowed to spend up to PLN 26.1 million in Sejm elections and PLN 5.7 million in Senat elections. An electoral committee's spending on campaign advertising may not exceed 80 percent of the expenditure limit. Third parties (other than voters) must receive the consent of an electoral committee in order to campaign, although there is no sanction for doing so without consent and there is no clear regulation on the reporting of third party contributions.  The NEC exercises oversight over party and campaign financing. Electoral Committees must submit financial reports on campaign income and expenditures, together with an external audit of the financial report, to the NEC within three months of the elections. Rejection of the report by teh NEC on the basis of detected violations of campaign finance regulations leads to a decrease in state subsidies, as well as other sanctions of specific irregularities. The amount of subsidies for the respective party is decreased by threefold the amount of incorrectly spent or received funding, up to 75 percent of the total due amount of the subsidy. Parties whose annual financial reports are rejected by the SEC for any type of irregularities are deprived of public funding for three years.  The current oversight system lacks mechanisms to monitor and investigate potential violations during the campaign, such as undisclosed spending and misuse of public resources.

election_commission_name: National Electoral Chamber (Cámara Nacional Electoral / CNE)

government_functions.details: The President of Argentina serves as both chief of state and head of government. The President is directly elected by qualified plurality vote in up to two rounds. To be elected, a candidate must receive either 45% of the overall vote or 40% of the vote and a 10-point lead over the closest opponent. The President may serve up to two 4-year terms.  Argentina has a bicameral National Congress with a 72-seat Senate and a 257-seat Chamber of Deputies. In the Senate, all 72 members are directly elected from multi-seat constituencies. Each constituency (province) awards 2 seats to the party highest-polling party and 1 seat to the second-place party. All members serve 6-year terms, and one-third of seats are up for election every 2 years. In the Chamber of Deputies, all 257 members are directly elected by party-list proportional representation vote from multi-seat constituencies. Members serve 4-year terms, and half the seats are up for election every 2 years.   The Supreme Court is the highest court in the Argentinian judiciary. It is composed of four judges who are nominated by the President and approved by a two-thirds vote of the Senate. Judges may serve until age 75.

election_commission_historical_context:
Post Independence – 1980-2004

After independence in 1980, the new government of Zimbabwe introduced a democratic, non-racist electoral system based upon universal adult suffrage. A new electoral management structure was established consisting of the Delimitation Commission, responsible for the delimitation of electoral districts, and the Electoral Supervisory Commission (ESC), charged with supervising the conduct of elections. The management of elections was done at this stage by the Registrar-General of Elections under the supervision of the ESC. The Registrar-General registered voters and compiled voter registers, conducted the voting process and the counting and collation of votes, and announced the results of the election. The Election Directorate provided logistical support to the Registrar-General in the management of the electoral process.

2004 Restructuring

In 2004 the electoral management system was re-structured. This re-structuring was based on recommendations by the Electoral Supervisory Commission, by the political parties and by civil society organisations. The reforms also took account of the Principles and Guidelines Governing Democratic Elections adopted by the SADC Heads of State and Governments in Mauritius in 2004. The Zimbabwe Electoral Commission (ZEC) was then established as an independent body in line with the recommendation in the SADC Principles and Guidelines Governing Democratic Elections that elections should be run by an independent management body and not by a government department like that of the Registrar-General.

The Electoral Supervisory Commission was then abolished in 2005 by Constitutional Amendment No. 17. ZEC became the body responsible for running elections and this function was no longer performed by the Registrar-General. To reflect the new system, the title of the Registrar-General of Elections was changed to that of the Registrar-General of Voters. The function of the Registrar-General of Voters in relation to elections was now only to register voters under the supervision of ZEC. ZEC was responsible for compiling voters rolls and providing copies of these rolls to those requesting them.

The Present ZEC

ZEC was constituted in terms of Chapter 12 Section 238 of the Constitution of Zimbabwe. There are nine Commissioners, who hold office for a term of six years. There is a Chairperson and a Deputy-Chairperson both of whom are appointed on a full time basis. Four of the eight Commissioners other than the Chairperson must be women.

The Chairperson is appointed by the President after consultation with the Judicial Service Commission and the Parliamentary Committee on Standing Rules and Orders. The Chairperson must be a judge or former judge of the Supreme Court or the High Court, or a person qualified for appointment as such the other eight members are appointed by the President from a list of not fewer than twelve nominees submitted by the Parliamentary Committee on Standing Rules and Orders.

In respect of the eight Commissioners appointed under this new system, the Parliamentary Committee on Standing Rules and Orders first invites applications for these posts. It then shortlists applicants. The shortlisted applicants are subjected to a vigorous public interview process by a panel of Parliamentarians. The Constitution provisions requires that Commissioners be chosen “for their integrity and their experience and competence in the conduct of affairs in the public or pri

government_functions.details: The head of state and government is the president, who is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds. The president can serve no more than two 5-year terms. The president is assisted by two vice presidents.  The parliament consists of the National Assembly and the Senate. The National Assembly normally has 210 members, all of whom are directly elected. For the first two parliaments elected after the promulgation of the 2013 constitution, however, the National Assembly has 270 seats, with the 60 additional seats reserved for women—6 from each of the 8 provinces and the 2 cities with provincial status—elected through a system of proportional representation. The Senate comprises 80 members: 60 (6 from each of the 8 provinces and the 2 cities with provincial status) elected by a party-list system of proportional representation, with men and women being listed alternately on every list; 16 traditional chiefs elected by the provincial assemblies of chiefs in the 8 provinces; 2 seats for the president and deputy president of the National Council of Chiefs (the administrative body of traditional chiefs); and 2 representatives of people with disabilities. All parliament members serve five-year terms.  The highest courts of the Zimbabwean judiciary are the Supreme Court (5 judges) and Constitutional Court (7 judges). Supreme Court judges may serve until age 70, while Constitutional Court judges serve a single 15-year term.  Judges from both courts are appointed by the President.

government_functions.details: The President of Ecuador serves as both head of government and head of state.  The president is directly elected by plurality of at least 40% and a 10% differential to the runner-up vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two consecutive 4-year terms.  The National Assembly shall be comprised of Fifteen (15) Assembly persons elected as representatives of the nation as a whole (national district). Two (2) Assembly persons elected for each province, plus one (1) additional Assembly person for every two hundred thousand (200,000) inhabitants or fraction thereof over one hundred fifty thousand (150,000), on the basis of the last national population census.  The jurisdictional bodies, without detriment to the other bodies with equal powers recognized in the Constitution, are those in charge of administering justice and they shall be as follows: The National Court of Justice. The provincial courts of justice. The courts and tribunals provided for by law. The justices of the peace.

government_functions.details: The President of Nigeria serves as the chief executive, head of state, and commander-in-chief of the armed forces. The Vice President is elected together with the President.  Nigeria has a bicameral assembly. The Senate has 109 seats and the House of Representatives has 360 seats. Both assemblies are directly elected by a simple majority vote.   The Supreme Court are appointed by the President on the advice of the National Judicial Council and confirmed by the Senate.

voting_methods.instructions: This is designed to help you understand the Voting Procedures during an election. Remember that you are qualified to vote if you are a registered voter and your name appears on the register of voters at your polling.  Opening of the Polling Units: On each Election Day, polling stations will open for Accreditation and Voting from 8:00 am to 2.00 pm. However, voters on the queue before the close of poll at 2:00pm will be accredited and allowed to vote.  Voting Procedure: Voting at the polling unit will be as follows:  Step 1:  At the polling unit, join the queue. An INEC official will check if you are at the correct polling unit and confirm that the PVC presented belongs to you.  Step 2:  An INEC official will confirm if your PVC is genuine using the card reader. You will be asked to place your finger on the card reader.  Step 3:  An INEC official will ask for your PVC and confirm you are listed in the Voters Register. Your name will be ticked and your finger will be inked to confirm you have voted. If your name is not found you cannot vote.  Step 4:  The Presiding officer will stamp, sign and endorse your ballot paper. You will be given the ballot paper rolled with the printed side inwards and directed to the voting cubicle.  Step 5:  Stain your finger with the ink given and mark the box for your preferred candidate/party. Roll the ballot paper in the manner you were given and flatten it.  Step 6:  Leave the voting cubicle and drop the ballot paper in the ballot box in full view of people at the Polling Unit.  Step 7:  Leave the Polling Unit or wait if you so choose, in an orderly and peaceful manner, to watch the process up to declaration of result.  N.B: The result of each Polling Unit shall be pasted at the unit for everyone to see.  Your right as a voter:  On each Election Day, you have the right to:  Access the polling station Receive information on the voting procedures from the poll officials Vote in secret. Responsibility of the Voter:  Obey all lawful instructions from the INEC and Security Officials on election duty. Leave the polling unit or wait if you so choose in an orderly and peaceful manner. Encourage other voters to do likewise.

election_commission_historical_context: In the Argentine Republic the knowledge of electoral matters has been entrusted to the Judiciary of the Nation.  Prior to the creation of the National Electoral Chamber in 1962, Decree 11.976/45 was issued during the de facto government, which approved the "Organic Statute of the Political Parties and established the creation of the "Federal Electoral Court".  However, the referred Statute was repealed and the Federal Electoral Court -whose members had resigned in full two days before- was dissolved. In 1962, by decree 7.163/62 the National Electoral Chamber was created.  This regulation placed special emphasis on the "convenience of having a specialized court in charge of resolving the issues arising from the application of the electoral and political parties laws".  Thus, and even with some differences with the current regime, the National Electoral Chamber was created. At that time, the Court was composed of five judges and an attorney general, and its presidency was permanent.  The following year, it was established -by decree-law 6.407/63- that the National Electoral Justice "would integrate the Judicial Power of the Nation, as a court specialized in legal-political and electoral matters".  It was also established that the National Electoral Chamber would act as "court of appeal with respect to the national electoral judges".  The creation of the electoral jurisdiction was later ratified by law 16.478 -which provided that the decrees issued with force of law by the de facto government, between March 29, 1962 and October 12, 1963, would continue to be in force- and, fundamentally, through the sanction of law 16.652.  This 1964 law provided for the intervention of the National Electoral Justice in all matters relating to the organization, recognition, operation and expiration of political parties, as well as in all contentious issues arising from the application of such law.  It should be recalled that by virtue of the coup d'état of June 28, 1966, the dissolution of the political parties was decreed. Months later, Law 17.014 was enacted, which determined the legal suppression of the National Electoral Chamber.  The magistrates of the National Electoral Chamber became judges of the National Chamber of Appeals for Peace and the National Chamber of Appeals for Economic Criminal Matters.  The electoral secretariats changed their name to "Registries of Enrollment Records" and the then National Registry of Enrollment as well as the Registry of Letters of Citizenship were in charge of the National Court of First Instance in Federal Criminal and Correctional Matters No. 1 of the Federal Capital. In 1971, Law 19,108 was enacted to create an "Electoral Chamber" within the National Court of Appeals in Federal and Contentious-Administrative Matters of the Federal Capital.  Subsequently, by virtue of the enactment of Law 19.277, and prior to the appointment of its members, the "Electoral Chamber" was transformed into the National Electoral Chamber, with its current structure of three judges forming a single chamber.

government_functions.details: The President of Argentina serves as both chief of state and head of government. The President is directly elected by qualified plurality vote in up to two rounds. To be elected, a candidate must receive either 45% of the overall vote or 40% of the vote and a 10-point lead over the closest opponent. The President may serve up to two 4-year terms.  Argentina has a bicameral National Congress with a 72-seat Senate and a 257-seat Chamber of Deputies. In the Senate, all 72 members are directly elected from multi-seat constituencies. Each constituency (province) awards 2 seats to the party highest-polling party and 1 seat to the second-place party. All members serve 6-year terms, and one-third of seats are up for election every 2 years. In the Chamber of Deputies, all 257 members are directly elected by party-list proportional representation vote from multi-seat constituencies. Members serve 4-year terms, and half the seats are up for election every 2 years.   The Supreme Court is the highest court in the Argentinian judiciary. It is composed of four judges who are nominated by the President and approved by a two-thirds vote of the Senate. Judges may serve until age 75.

institution.name: Argentinian Presidency
institution.term_details: Article 90 The President and Vice President shall remain in office for a term of four years and may be reelected or succeed each other for only one consecutive term. If they have been reelected or succeeded each other, they may not be elected to either office, except after the interval of a term.

government_functions.details:
Serbia is a parliamentary democracy in which the President serves as head of state. The President is directly elected and serves 5-year terms. 

The legislature is the unicameral Serbian National Assembly. It has 250 seats, and members serve 4-year terms. The Prime Minister serves as head of government.

The invitation to vote shall be delivered to the voter who votes abroad by the diplomatic and consular mission.

The polling board shall hand out a ballot paper to a voter for whom it has established, by a UV lamp check, that he/she has not voted at another polling station, and whose identity it has established by inspecting his / her ID card or other appropriate public document containing a photograph and UMCN (e.g. travel document, military ID card, or other document in accordance with the instructions of the Republic Electoral Commission) and who is entered in the excerpt from the electoral roll.

The annual report on the financing of the political entity shall include information on origin, amount and structure of all raised and spent funds from public and private sources, credits and loans. Political entities referred to in paragraph 1 of this article are required to publish annual reports on the financing of the political entity on their websites within eight days of their submission to the Agency. Annual reports on the financing of the political entity shall be published on the website of the Agency within seven days from receiving such report duly submitted in the prescribed form. The director of the Agency shall specify the content and the manner of submission of the annual report on the financing of the political entity.

government_functions.details: The President of Madagascar serves as chief of state, while the Prime Minister acts as head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is nominated by the National Assembly and confirmed by the President.  Madagascar has a bicameral Parliament composed of an 18-seat Senate and a 151-seat National Assembly. Within the Senate, 12 members are indirectly elected by subnational leaders, and 6 are appointed by the President. All senators serve 5-year terms. Within the National Assembly, 87 members are elected by plurality vote in single-seat constituencies, and 64 members are elected by closed-list proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies. All assembly members are directly elected and serve 5-year terms.  Madagascar has three high courts. The Supreme Court is composed of 11 judges and deals with intragovernmental administrative and financial cases. Supreme Court judges are appointed by the President and Ministry of Justice officials to serve up to two 3-year terms. The High Constitutional Court is composed of 9 judges selected by either the President, the Parliament, or the Council of Magistrates. These judges serve a 7-year term. The High Court of Justice is convened only to try national officials for treason and other grave offenses and is composed of judges from the Supreme Court, several lower courts, members of the National Assembly, and members of the High Council for the Defense of Democracy.

institution.name: Malagasy Presidency
institution.term_details: Article 45 The President of the Republic is the Head of State. He is elected by universal direct suffrage for a mandate of five years renewable one sole time. Article 46 Any candidate to the functions of President of the Republic must be of Malagasy nationality, enjoy their civil and political rights, be at least thirty-five years old at the date of the closure of the presentation of the candidatures, and reside on the territory of the Republic of Madagascar for at least six months before the day of the deadline established for the presentation of the candidatures. The President of the Republic in office who stands as a candidate to the Presidential elections resigns from his position sixty days before the date of the Presidential ballot. In this case, the President of the Senate exercises the current Presidential attributions until the investiture of the new President. In the case that the President of the Senate stands as a candidate himself, the functions of Head of the State are exercised by the Government, jointly.
